Mr. MALLORY, in his speech here to night, before a great Union crowd, spoke to this effect: There was no ground, no reason, no cause for the secession movement. Secession or revolution is nothing but war a lawless struggle of arms. The seceders commenced the war, are prosecuting the war, are directly responsible for the war.

The Fifth Regiment of Maine will leave Portland for New-York on Wednesday next, via the Fall River Line from Boston. Extra trains and boats, as with all regiments going by this Line, will be provided, obviating any interference with passengers on the regular boat of that day.

The Third and Fourth Ohio Regiments, Cols. MORROW and ANDREWS, fully armed and equipped, left Camp Dannison, yesterday afternoon, for Virginia. Gen. McCLELLAN and Staff were at Parkersburgh, yesterday, en route for Grafton.

BOARD OF EDUCATION THE NORMAL SCHOOL. A special meeting of the Board of Education was held, on Thursday, for the purpose of considering the propriety of abolishing the Normal School. The sum of $2,500 has always been appropriated annually for the support of this school; but a great many of the members of the Board are now in favor of abolishing it altogether. The matter was referred to a Committee of five for report.

The schooner John N. Genin, Capt. PHILLIPS, employed as a Government transport, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing news from Fort Pickens to the 29th of May, Fort Jefferson, Tortugas, to June 9, and Key West to the 10th.

After a brief period of decadence, the old Union has begun to grow again. We rejoice to welcome, to-day, the return of the Old Dominion to the family of States. Let the star of the old flag that represents Virginia, be burnished anew and made to shine with a fresh lustre. Let the fatted calf be killed, and let us eat and be merry; for the dead is alive again, and the lost is found.

H.C. SPENCER, our Consul at Paris, has been ordered to close the consulate, and to deposit the papers and records of the office with the American Minister. Mr. SPENCER has been proved to entertain quite too much sympathy for the rebels.

An able article upon the "State of the Country" has appeared in the Southern Presbyterian Review, and been republished in the NewYork Observer. It is said to be the work of Rev. Dr. THORNWELL, and is the ablest exposition of the more candid Southern view of secession which has yet been published. As such, it is worthy of careful attention.

The regiment which yesterday made a reconnoissance towards Great Bethel, returned late in the evening, having gone to the neighborhood of Little Bethel. They brought back no intelligence of importance. In is understood, however, that the Confederates are concentrating a large force at Yorktown.

The Eleventh Anniversary of the Hudson River Baptist Association South was held with the Mount Olivet Baptist Church, Yonkers, on Tuesday and Wednesday. The anniversary sermon was preached by Rev. W.S. NICKELS, of New York. Rev. JOHN DOWLING, D.D., was elected Moderator, Rev. C.C. NORTEN was reelected Clerk, and JAMES L. HASTIN, Assistant Clerk, and J.M. BRUCE, Jr. Treasurer.

The bridge-burning traitor who lately governed Missouri is still in full flight no one knows where. The last seen of him was on Wednesday, at the little town of Syracuse, on the line of the Pacific Railroad, but he was then on horse, sweeping southwestwardly at a hot and furious pace, apparently making for the Indian Territory west of Arkansas.

Some details of Mr. COBB'S scheme of cotton financiering have reached us. It is proposed, it seems, to relieve each planter at once of half his crop. and transport it to New-Orleans. When it has reached that point, England will be notified of its readiness for her shops; and will of course break up the blockade and take it. The remainder of the crop. will be moved subsequently, and with a similar result.

The new Senator of the United States, from California, Gen. JAMES A. McDOUGALL, arrived yesterday in the Ariel, en route for Washington. He is an independent Union Democrat, and as such was elected by a combination of Douglas men and Republicans in the California Legislature last May. It is understood that he will support earnestly the policy of the Administration in asserting the power of the Federal Government over all the States of the Union.

No movement of importance among the Federal troops, aside from the ordinary arrivals and departures, appears to have taken place in the vicinity of Washington yesterday. Our lines are being strengthened daily whenever such a proceeding seems necessary, and will doubtless soon be, if they are not already, in a condition to withstand the onset of the fifty thousand rebel troops which are reported to be ready to attempt the capture of the Capital.

A horrible disaster occured at Wyandotte, Kansas, yesterday, by the falling in of the walls of two buildings and part of a third, burying all the inmates, some forty persons. The buildings were four stories high and situated on the levee. They had previously been used as the head-quarters of the First Regiment of Kansas Volunteers.

By the Karnak we have Nassau papers to the 6th inst. A slave brig was wrecked on Anquilla Key early in June, supposed to be an American vessel. A Spanish schooner took off the negroes and sailed for Cuba. The slaver was 35 days from Congo River.

The steamship Illinois, P.E. TERRY, Commander, engaged in the transportation of munitions of war to Fort Pickens, has arrived here. She left Fort Pickens June 20, and arrived at Tortugas June 30, having discharged her guns, shell, , at Tortugas, (they not being required at Fort Pickens,) she left July 4 and arrived at Key West the same day. The following was received, July 13, from Beverly, Va.:

Death has been playing sad havoc lately with men in high position. First, Count CAVOUR, then Senator DOUGLAS, then Lord CAMPBELL, and now the Sultan, have paid the debt of nature. The late ABDUL MEDJID, a mild and intelligent Prince, gave himself up to intemperance and the pleasures of the seraglio, and thus has died from exhaustion at the early age of thirty-eight.

Capt. SMITH, from Springfield, Thursday, reached here to-night, reports that a messenger arrived there that morning with intelligence that Gen. LYONS' command would reach there that day. The entire National force, comprising the commands under Gen. SWEENEY, Cols. SIEGEL, SOLOMON, BROWN, and four wounded Home Guards, under JOHN S. PHELPS, are concentrated at Springfield.

Our city was thrown into a state of feverish excitement to-day, by the news of a great battle which was reported to have been fought in the vicinity of Carthage, between the United States forces, under Col. SIEGEL, and the rebel troops, under Gens, PRICE and RAINS.

The House of Representatives to-day decided, by an almost strictly party vote, that certain gentlemen occupying seats have not forfeited them by accepting military appointments in the States which they represent. I observed that Mr. ROSCOE CONKLING voted with the Opposition against laying the resolution for the exclusion of the military members on the table.

Recruiting for the past week for the Army shows a still further improvement. For the old regiments 25 men were enlisted; and the offices for the Twelfth (new) received about as many more. Detachments from the provincial rendezvous have arrived, as usual, and been added to the force on Governor's Island, where there are now 694 men. Buffalo is doing well, of late, Mr. SHERIDAN having forwarded more than the average.

The following dispatch has just been received by the War Department:

Judge P.B. MUIR, of our Circuit Court, in a case before him, involving the question of the legality of the Government's blockade of our railroad to Nashville, has this morning decided the blockade to be legal. His decision, if carried to the Court of Appeals, will probably be confirmed. The President, JAMES GUTHRIE, and the Union Directors of the road, will submit to it, and Kentuckians generally will.

One of the most exciting matches of the season took place yesterday at the Union Course, Long Island, between Ethan Allen and mate, S. McLOUGHLIN, and Flora Temple, J.D. McMANN, for $1,000, mile heats, best 3 in 5. Flora was the favorite, previous to starting, at the rate of $100 to $70.

The steamer Hibernian, from Liverpool, June 4, via Londonderry, 5th, reached this point at 9 o'clock this evening. She has 46 cabin and 122 steerage passengers. She reports numerous icebergs, and was detained 24 hours in a fog.

Ma. Gen. JOHN C. FREMONT was waited upon yesterday at the Astor House, by a committee of officers of the Fremont Regiment, U.S.V., now in progress of formation. The deputation was introduced by Dr. JUSTUS ADELBERG, of California, the well-known geologist. Gen. FREMONT expressed himself much satisfied with the intent and purposes of the regiment, and promised his active support in procuring a speedy acceptance of the same by the authorities in Washington.

DEATH OF THE PPOPRIETOR OF TAMMANY HOTEL. Mr. CHARLES BROWN, who for a number of years was proprietor of Tammany Hotal, in this City, died suddenly, on Monday night, at his residence, No. 114 East Eighteenth-street, of disease of the heart. Mr. BROWN was born in Bradford, England, where he lived until his eleventh year, at which time he came, with his parents, to this City.

The First Regiment of the Excelsior Brigade took their departure from Staten Island yesterday of ternoon. They received orders to march on Monday, and gave vent to their joy by exultant cheers. An individual's griefs or wrongs may be of little account to others, but when the gravest public interests are imperiled, through personal attacks and the coarsest imputations of base motives, the assailed, however humble, owes duties to others which cannot be disregarded. FIRE IN A FURNISHING GOODS STORE. A fire broke out, about 12 o'clock, on Sunday night, in the ladies furnishing goods store, No. 740 Broadway, owned by Mr. CHARLES H. BAKER. The flames spread rapidly, and the fire was not subdued until after the entire stock had been destroyed.

The prize brig Falcon, Lieut. GEORGE W. YOUNG, from Congo River in 43 days, arrived here yesterday. The Falcon was boarded and captured by the U.S. ship Surnter, off Red Point, June 14, when Lieut. YOUNG was placed on board with a prize crew of ten men.

Since the disastrous affair at Bull Run, we are again on the defensive. Our Army is back to its old position on the Potomac, strengthening itself against apprehended attack from the enemy, as it was three months ago.

"Beverly valley shall flow with blood!" is the threat which the citizens of Beverly believe to have been uttered by JEFFERSON DAVIS. Why this doom is pronounced especially upon the lovely valley of Bev- erly I am unable to state; I only know that he is popularly credited with the sentiment and the wish.

Col. FERRY'S regiment, the Fifth, of Connecticut, left Hartford on Monday at 2 o'clock, and proceeded to New-Haven. In the City of Elins the greatest enthusiasm was manifested, and the march through the city was a continued ovation. Leaving New-Haven at about 7 o'clock, Monday evening, in the steamer Elm City, the regiment proceeded to Elizabethport, N.J., where it arrived a little after noon yesterday.

He is a young man, apparently not more than twenty-five years of age, and, withal, is very intelligent.

The report of the State Treasurer, in accordance with the instructions of the Convention, was made this morning. The amount of money in the Treasury on the 24th of July was a little over $57,000. The disbursements since the adjournment of the last session of the Legislature have been over $600,000.

A week to-day the Army of the Union marched on Manassas with the joy as battle-cry of "On to Richmond," and a week to-night this same Army marched back with the wild cry of "Retreat on Washington." The venerable Mr. STOCKTON, the Chaplain of the House, took occa- sion this morning to administer a rebuke to the Government, and he did it manfully and unhesitatingly.

The Duquesne depot of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company accidentally took fire about 3 o'clock this afternoon, which was entirely consumed with all the contents. The fire is supposed to have originated in the basement, where about 3,000 bbls. of Petroluem Oil was deposited.

The reception of the Fifth Massachusetts Regi- ment, which arrived in this city about 1 o'clock, to- day, was a demonstration long to be remembered.

The Commander-in-Chief of the Army has ordered all the available batteries of United States Artillery now at Harrisburgh. Penn., and elsewhere in that State to the line of the Potomac. Several batteries left yesterday and the day before for that destination. Capt. CAMPBELL, now at Harrisburgh, has been deputed to get ambulance for the conveyance of ordnance and men.

Mr. OLIN, of New-York, from the Military Committee, reported a bill adding to the West Point Cadets a number equal to that of Senators and Representatives, to be selected from the States on the recommendation of Members of Congress, as prescribed by the former law.

Last Saturday, 1,200 men were detailed under Gen. SWEENEY, to break up a secession camp, located at Forsythe a point about fifty miles south of this, and situated at or near the foot of the Ozark Mountains. Monday at starting, we were thirty miles from Forsythe, having only made twenty miles in the two days previous, owing to heavy rains and the consequent almost impassable character of the mountain roads.

When Col. BALLIER'S Twenty-first Regiment of Pennsylvania Volunteers arrived in Philadelphia on Monday night, they marched to the residence of Gen. I hear a great outery through the Press about rebels in Washington, You will have some trouble in convincing people that there is much meaning or sincerity in this, so long as there are newspapers in New-York in the pay of the enemies of the Government, and openly, boldly and defiantly advocating their cause. Not only so, but even paid by our City Government for doing so.

Brig.-Gen. POPE has issued a special order, assigning Brig.-Gen. HURLBURT to the command of the United States forces along the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad. Col. GRANT will command at Mexico, on the North Missouri Road. Col. Ross will occupy Mounton, and Col. PALMER will post his regiment at Renick and Sturgeon, making his headquarters at Renick.

The Enquirer collects these incidents of the engagement. It says: "The dispatch of President DAVIS says that the severest fighting of the battle of the 21st was on our left flank. Those who gave attention to our description of the localities, in Monday's issue, will recognize thoe "Stone Bridge" as the scene of this terrible collision. That point, where the turnpike road crosses Bull Run, was on the extreme left of our line.

The arrival of Prince NAPOLEON at New-York has been promptly recognized by the Administration. Hon. F.W. SEWARD, Assistant Secretary of State, proceeded at once to New-York, and on behalf of the President, tendered to the Prince the courtesy of an official recognition, the hospitalities of the White House, and such facilities as the Government might have it in its power to afford him during his visit.

Capt. KILPATRICK, formerly of Col. DURYEE'S Regiment, arrived here this morning, from NewYork, with a company of 100 mounted riflemen. Cavalry has been greatly needed in this vicinity, and it is to be hoped that this branch of the service will be strengthened.

The Convention to-day declored vacant the offices of Governor, Lieutenant-Governor and Secretary of State, by a vote of 56 to 25.

The Sanitary Commission, through its Secretary, Mr. OLMSTED, has made its first Report; and a very direct, explicit document it is, even if not vert encouraging. The Commission wastes no words on generalties or medical and philosophical theories, but go straight to the practical matters of food and drink, night soil and drainage, clothing and cleanliness, and the other very plain conditions of a soldier's health.

The Twelfth New-York Regiment, Col. BUTTERFIELD, left here at 7 P.M., en route for home. They remained with Gen. BANKS, until his column was sufficiently reinforced. Their appearance is rough, from long marches and heavy duty as pickets and outposts, but all are well. Many will reenlist.

It is curious to observe the different light in which the old question out of which of the national pockets the money is to come presents itself to different nations. The English theory is that, apart from class interests, the method of indirect taxation is most convenient for ordinary purposes, and that an Income-tax is peculiarly available, if it should not be absolutely reserved, for such emergencies as war.

HALL to be Lieutenant-Governor, and MORDECAI OLIVER to be Secretary of State.

An extract from a letter dated July 25th, from on board the United States ship Savannah, off Cape Hatteras, says:

CORONER'S INQUEST IN THE CASE OF MRS. SELLERS. The Coroner's Jury, in the case of Mrs. SELLERS, who was killed on Thursday night by a fireengine, rendered their verdict yesterday afternoon, in accordance with the facts heretofore stated. The jury censure the firemen for their carelessness in this case, and recommend some salutary punishment as an example for the future. Mrs. SELLERS was a highly respected lady and mother of a large family.

Not a little error and confusion has been created by writers in the newspapers, especially since the recent battle before Manassas Junction, by confounding the names of two meritorious officers in the Army. There are two Col. SHERMANS in the Army: Col. WILLIAM T. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and Co. THOMAS W. SHERMAN, of Rhode Island. The former is the only one of the two who was engaged in the battle at Bull Run.

DESPERATE FIGHT AND STABBING AFFRAY. Early yesterday morning several young men, who had been drinking freely on Saturday night, paid a visit to the house of HENRY BUTHMAN, No. 220 Centrestreet, which has a notoriously bad reputation, and there engaged in a bloody fight. How the affray originated is not known, but it was generally participated in, and knives, decanters and clubs were used.

Earl RUSSELL has bade farewell to his old constituents of the City of London, and the benches of that body, in which the best part of his forty-seven years of public life have been passed. It is easy to see that the Democratic leaders in this State have made up their minds to bring forward fresh compromises as a means of saving the Union. This is the real motive of their declining to join the Republicans in sustaining the war. They expect to create a Peace Party, that is a party which will commission the South to dictate its own concessions and return to the Union upon its own terms.

The Breckinridge State Central Committee met at the Delavan House, in this City, to-day. Twelve members out of sixteen were present, one of the absentees being MATTHEW McMAHON, the Secretary, who now holds a Custom-house appointment under the Administration.

They say that PILLOW returned to New-Madrid on Sunday evening. These reports are corroborated by our scouts.

The General Assembly adjourned on Saturday after a session of three days. Considerable business was done on the last day of the session. A resolution pledging the support of the State to the General Government in its efforts to support the Union, was adopted.

It will be generally recollected that shortly after the election in 1856, the Tennessee papers gave accounts of a threatened insurrection among the slaves of a portion of the State, and that the insurrection was induced by the supposition, prevalent among the blacks, that FREMONT was coming up the river, backed by a large Army, for the purpose of liberating all the slaves.

The fleet of ten steamers, which have been laid up fifteen miles below here for some time past, were brought to the city to-day, by order of Gen. FREMONT, to prevent the possibility of their being taken by Secessionists.

The Banks of New-York, Boston and Philadelphia yesterday completed their negotiation of one hundred and fifty million Government Loan, and Mr. CHASE, the Secretary of the Treasury, left for Washington at 6 o'clock in the afternoon. The Stock Market closed steady on the Railways and State Stocks, and about 1 cent. higher on Treasury Notes.

C.J. JACK, Esq., applied to the County Court and obtained a writ of habeas corpus, upon application of United States soldiers at Fort Hamilton for their release, on the ground that they are illegally detained. One hundred and fifty soldiers are now in Fort Hamilton, who were liberated on their parole in Texas, having been surrendered to the Confederate authorities by their officers in Texas, and they now demand their discharge.

The correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat furnishes a detailed account of the battle of Wilson's Creek. But all the main facts concerning the engagement have already been telegraphed. The enemy's camp extended along Wilson's Creek about three miles, inclosed by high ground on each side, upon which the greater part of the engagement was fought.

Lieut, FRANK E. BROWNELL, the avenger of the death Of ELLSWORTH, has received a splendid present from some of his friends in this city. It is a dagger, with an ivory head carved with greatingenuity and skill by WILLIAM LAUTZ, of this city. At the top of the handle is represented the American eagle in the act of killing a rattlesnake, the symbol of the so-called Southern Confederacy.

MILES, charged with unofficer-like conduct on the Centreville Heights on the day of the battle Bull Run, is still progressing, the Court being held in the City Council Chamber. MILES, REVERDY JOHNSON, of Baltimore.

This colony is fully realizing the evil which I predicted in one of my previous letters to arise from the civil war in America. Jamaica is almost entirely dependent upon the United States for the breadstuffs and provisions which she consumes, and it is quite evident that anything which leads to a stoppage of supplies must occasion us very great suffering.

Christian patriots are solicitous that the existing war may be so conducted as to secure the right of our citizen soldiers to their wonted day of rest and worship, and so as to avoid all needless invasion of public morals. If there is any rule of warfare which is of instinctive and universal acceptance among men, whether civilized or savage, it is to strike an enemy where he is weakest. The reason is manifest: you strike thus with least danger to yourself, and with most damage to the foe. But it seems to us that the United States Government has wholly failed to profit by the wisdom of ages.

Y.S.M.: SIR: I beg leave to submit the following report: When our forces retreated after the action of 21st July, several Surgeons, myself among the number, deemed it our duty to remain with the wounded, of whom there were about 300, in and about Sudley Church, the place assigned us for a hospital.
The loss of the North Carolina Sixth Regiment in the battle of Bull Run, according to the offical return, was as follows: Killed, 15; wounded, 53; missing, 1.

Night before last a little Army of fifty-two hundred men moved in two columns on a march of twelve or fifteed miles to attack a body of rebels twenty-two thousand strong. In a military point of view the move was one of doubtful propriety, not to say absolute rashness. The larger force were, with the exception of three thousand men, well armed and equipped, and they had a very large body of cavalry.

By this time, about every person in the city is aware that martial law has been declared and established therein by Maj-Gen. FREMONT, commanding the Military Department of the West. The legal status also embraces the entire county of St. Louis.

A heavy seizure of goods destined for the rebels was made near Annapolis Junction to-day. The goods were bought by parties in Baltimore for Richmond dealers. A draft for $4,975 was sent to pay for them. With the goods were also seized the teams and wagons by which they were being conveyed, and a number of letters to officers in the rebel Army.

E.TULLIS, Esq., who last year shipped one of the first bales of cotton, had picked on his plantation, on Tuesday, the 30th of July, over five thousand pounds of clean cotton. In about another week, picking throughout the parish will be general.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I write to applaud the course you pursue in relation to the action of those regiments which have dishonored themselves upon the field of battle. It is time that we ceased lavishing indiscriminate praise.

The activity at our Navy-yard is now immense. The new war steamer Tuscarora literally presents the appearance of achive of bees 300 men now swarming about her, presenting a scene of energy and activity rarely witnessed. MEAGMER, of the Sixty-ninth New-York Regiment, written in reply to a note addressed to him by a gentleman in this city inquiring whether he (MEAGHER) had authorized any person to enlist men in this city for a New York Brigade "to be commanded by him." To the Merchants, Bankers and others of the Confederate States of America: There are two great objects which we desire as the result of the momentous struggle which is now pending. One is political, the other is commercial and financial.

A span of horses, drawing a somewhat dilapidated looking wagon covered with cotton cloth, made its appearance in the streets yesterday. The singular appearance of the vehicle attracted the attention of the passers and when the driver drew rein and halted on Jefferson-avenue, a crowd quickly gathered around.

While Hon. JEFFERSON DAVIS was Secretary of War under President PIERCE it will be remembered that the Territory of Kansas was the theatre of grave political controversies, finally degenerating into civil feud. The contest arose among the adherents of two Legislatures respectively assuming to represent the people of that Territory.

The rebels and destroyers of the Union are at work in the Middle States. During the last fortnight agents of the Southern Confederacy have been visiting various sections of New-Jersey, inaugurating movements for systematic peace meetings throughout the State.

A detachment of U.S. troops from Cape Girar dean seized fifty-eight thousand dollars belonging to the bank at St. Genevieve yesterday, by order of Gen FREMONT, and brought it to this city to-day. It is understood this money was being used or would be used for the benefit of the secession cause in that section.

SIR: The legislation of the Government of the Untied States, so far as it relates to mailable matter and the rates of postage, and the mode of transmitting mail matter, has been substituted by the legislalion of the Confederate States, and is thereby repealed.

Col. Franklin, Commanding First Brigade Colonel Heintzelman's Division, N.E. Virginia: SIR I have the honor to communicate, as Colonel of the First Minnesota Regiment of Volunteers, the events connected with the movements of my command, comprising a part of your brigade.
LORENZO D. PATRICK, Esq., arrived in this city on Monday last, from Pike County, Miss., whither he was driven on account of his devotion to the Union.

The Mobile Advertiser says that, on Saturday night, the 3d-inst., one of the harbor police boats Was chased by five ship's launches of the enemy, who, it is thought, came from the dry-dock, now anchored midway between Santa Rosa Island and the Navyyard. The steamer Niagara or Wabash, which arrived at the anchorage a day or two previous, sailed Monday evening to the southwest, probably for the Mississippi station.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The refusal of the Democratic State Com mittee to accede to the liberal and patriotic pro posal of the Republicans, looking to the nomination of a State Union ticket, will prove to be un wise, and will, in our judgment, effectually accomplish that dismemberment of the Democracy against which it is the alleged purpose of the refusal to guard.

The usual quiet of the city has been somewhat disturbed to-day by the mutinous conduct of the Seventy-ninth Regiment. It appears that an order was sent to them last night to strike their tents early this morning, and march to some other locality to join SICKLES' Brigade, as was generally understood.

Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, under the authority of Confederate legislation, of course, has issued a proclamation ordering all residents in the seceded States, who do not recognize the Confederacy, to depart within forty days, under pain of being "condemned as aliens and enemies."

COTTON The market opened unsettled and excited under the Canada's advices from America, and prices advanced 1/8d. Sales of the three days, 38,000 bales, including 17,000 bales to speculators and exporters. The market closes quiet but steady.

The rigors of military law are now being brought to bear upon mutinous and malcon tent soldiers. Gen. BUTLER has promptly quelled the revolts in the Second, Ninth and Tenth Regiments at Fortress Monroe, by bringing his loaded batteries to bear upon the mutineers, while he secured the ringleaders and transported them to the Rip Raps to be speedily tried by Court-martial.

It is known that brisk fighting is expected yet in Western Virginia, before the present campaign shall close. The people expect it; the soldiers expect it; it is shrewdly surmised that Gen. ROSECRANS expects and is preparing for it. On what is this expectation based?

The whole nation will remember this regiment with gratitude and pride. Their presence and bearing on the bloody battle-field where the gallant LYON fell, demonstrated their courage, and saved the brave little Army from being overwhelmed by the hosts which opposed them. Their names will go down to posterity as a bright illustration of sublime patriotism.
A flag of truce conveyed to-day to Craney Island a number of ladies wishing to go South.

We do not feel that we are sanguinary or bloodthirsty in our disposition, yet we confess that, day by day, we are gradually becoming more inclined to a terrible severity towards our enemies of Yankee States. Their war upon us is so unnatural, so revolting, so subversive of all the rights which we and they too have always held sacred, that its enormity grows upon us as we think of it.
Already the new order of the War Department, directing regular soldiers to be enlisted like volunteers, for three years, has exercised a marked influence on recruiting here.

The Sixteenth Regiment of Massachusetts enlisted for the war, arrived in this City yesterday vid the Fall River roule. The regiment has been for some time encampted at North Cambridge, near Boston, and during its march through the latter city on Saturday morning, was most enthusiastically greeted.

We stated a few days since the position taken by our Government in regard to exchanging prisoners with the authorities of the Southern Confederacy. It is generally understood that the President declines to make such exchange, on the ground that it would be virtually a recognition of the rebels as belligerents.

The Soldiers' Fair, inaugurated by the ladies of Katonah, and the town of Bedford, passed off pleasantly, and proved a complete success, supplying an ample fund for the prosecution of their labors.

The change in the command of this department so long expected, and by many desired, is about to take place. Gen. Wool is expected to arrive by the next boat. Nothing is yet known as to the future movements of Gen. BUTLER.

The futile attempt of the Committee on Federal Relations to manufacture sympathy in behalf of the Commissioners of Police, imparts renewed interest to the scenes of the 19th of April last, in which these gentlemen bore a conspicuous part.

Some time last year THOMAS C. BATES, of Brighton, made a contract for furnishing the rails for the Memphis, El Paso and Pacific Railroads, to the amount of several hundred thousand dollars. Mr. BATES made an arrangement with Eastern parties for the iron; and he had shipped a large quantity prior to the breaking out of the rebellion.
According to German mining law, the State owns all metals which may be discovered in the earth, and possesses the exclusive right of granting permission to obtain them.

A dispatch from Washington states that "since the affair at Mathias Point, the steamer Freeborn went down and shelled the woods from whence the rebels fired, clearing them up and rendering them untenable for the time being at least."

Gov. BUCKINGHAM, of Connecticut, has issued the following proclamation: For the purpose of sustaining the supremacy of the Federal Government, and suppressing the rebellion now raging against its authority, I, WILLIAM A. BUCKINGHAM, Governor of the State of Connecticut, do hereby call upon the loyal and patriotic citizens of this State, to organize in companies, for four regiments of infantry, and offer their services for three years or during the war.

The Secretary of War has left Richmond for a few days to take his family to the Springs. Professor (or Colonel) BLEDSOE, the Chief Clerk, is Acting Secretary during his absence.

CONCERT IN CENTRAL PARK. Notwithstanding the exceedingly threatening state of the weather, and the cold cheer that car drivers gave to inquiries concerning the musical prospects in Central Park, there was a concert there on Saturday. If the sun had been a little brighter the attendance would unquestionably have been much greater, and the comfort of those who were present perhaps relatively less.

News of the battle of Bull Run was received on Sunday, 4th. It caused a profound sensation. Northern Americans were much depressed, and the Southerners correspondingly elated. There was almost a collision in the Liverpool Newsroom.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: So soon as it became evident that war would be waged between the United States and the insurgents of the South, men who have experience in war asked, "What can we and ought we to do with the prisoners we may make?"

MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP certainly does, as the name implies, "soothe" the little sufferer into a quiet, natural sleep, from which it awakes invigorated and refreshed. And for the cure of diseases incident to the period of teething, such as Dysentery, Diarrhoea, Wind Colic, , c., we have never seen its equal.

The Times has an article, bitterly sarcastic, on the battle at Bull Run. It says there must rise a gathering doubt that the Southern nut is too hard to crack, and that the military line, as a matter of business, does not answer.
The steamship Bohemian, from Liverpool Thursday, 8th, via Londonderry 9th, arrived off this point at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

Hon. Caleb B. Smith, Secretary of the Interior, from Washington; Hon. Philip, Dorsheimer, State Station, of Stonington; Rev. Mr. Ellis, of Louder, and Lawrence Grinell, of New-Bedford, are at the Astor House.

There are now thirty-one skeleton regiments in this city, composed, on an average, of three companies each. The latest Army order will doubtless have the effect of merging them, and Philadelphia will soon be able to send an army of nine or ten thousand men.
The number of letters received at the Washington Post-office average about 30,000 daily, and of this number, it is estimated that at least two-thirds are for the Army.

On Saturday, we mentioned in our local columns that the schooner Henry Nutt, owned in this city, had been captured by a privateer off Hatteras Inlet, and that her Captain and crew were subsequently liberated, and brought to Baltimore by the schooner Priscilla, a vessel owned in Baltimore, from which city they arrived here on Friday night.
Fresh outrages are daily committed by rebel Tennesseans against loyal Tennesseans, the Government of the United States, and Kentucky as a member of the United States. ...
The steamship Bremen, from Southampton on the 7th inst., arrived at this port last evening.

Upon all sides there seems to be a lull of the battle-storm, which lately swept so fiercely by upon every breeze. What does this betoken? What fresh preparations upon either side are being made for a more desperate struggle? We are in no mood to find fault with our rulers, for we believe them to be wise and fully adequate for all the emergencies of the times. ...

The Schooner Hannibal, of Bangor, Capt. WENTWORTH, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Guadaloupe, W.I., which place she left on the 2d of August, brings intelligence that news was received at St. Thomas on the 3d inst., by a steamer direct from Curacoa, that the rebel privateer Sumter had been captured by one of our men-of-war, name not understood.

Public feeling in Kentucky is tending rapidly to a crisis. Any day the fire of civil war may light up "the dark and bloody ground." The attitude of the State of Tennessee is extremely menacing. That State has three important military camps close on the border of Kentucky; and numerous smaller bodies of troops, established at other points along the State line, apparently watching the Unionists of Kentucky. ...

In an article which we copy this morning from the New-York Ledger, Hon. EDWARD EVERETT sets forth, in clear and strong terms, the duty of suppressing all attempts, through the Press or by speech, to aid the cause of the rebellion. He remarks upon the extraordinary spectacle of toleration exhibited by our Government in this respect. ...
At 3 o'clock on Saturday afternoon last thirty-four of the prisoners taken from the Petrel were brought to the United States Marshal's office for a hearing. ...
The schooner Windward, Capt. PARTRIDGE, from Turks Island, Aug. 1, arrived at Holmes' Hole on the l7th inst. The Windward was captured by the Jeff. Davis on the 4th inst., in lat. 28, Ion. 67.
Gen. WOOL assumed command at Old Point this morning. Lieut. C.C. CHURCH is acting as AdjutantGeneral. The presence of Gen. WOOL is already having a good effect upon the troops.

New-York advices thoroughly depressed FLOUR, and Friday's advance was lost; Extra sold at $3.75; market dall and unsettled. WHEAT 5c, lower, and unsettled. WHISKY steady, at 13 c. PROVISIONS dull and unsettled; Mess Pork, $14; Lard, 8 c. Exchange on New-York, c.

Yesterday was emphatically a blue Monday in the City. The sudden demand of the Secretary of War for the immediate dispatch to Washington of all the men who had been accepted for the public service, whether organized or not, was held to indicate apprehensions of an immediate attack, either upon Washington, or upon Baltimore, in its rear.

After I had closed my letter to-day, the real nature of McDOWELL'S position was communicated to me. He advanced his left somewhat, with the view of turning the enemy's right if possible; but a careful reconnoissance convinced him that BEAUREGARD had fortified himself so strongly in a position which nature had made sufficiently formidable, that he could not persist in his design of attacking him on that point with any chance of success. ...

In calling to Washington the incomplete regiments of the Eastern and Middle States, the Government either confesses its fears as to the safety of the Capital, or proposes to introduce a new system into the muster and organization of its Armies. If we are to receive the latter interpretation of the measure, we may accept it as one of the very highest promise: ...

It is an old proverb that the laws are silent amidst arms. The laws are, for the most part, made for a state of peace, a excepting those which expressly refer to war, and the manner of conducting it. ...

We hear much said at the present day by these same equivocal "peace-makers" in deprecation of "invasion," but it is instructive to remark that by this term they mean only the southward march of the National, Army in support of the National authority. ...
SUTHERLAND, J. John Lund vs. The Seaman's Bank for Savings. Judgment for plaintiff on demurrer, with costs, with leave to defendants to answer in ten days, with payment of costs.
The following letter was read, on Thursday last, in the Virginia Convention, now in session at wheeling, by Mr. RITCHIE, of Marion County:

I make no apology for criticising Democrats, since I am myself a Democrat. Nay, almost can I say, "If any other man thinketh that he hath whereof he might trust in" Democracy, "I more." For I have spent much of my life in inculcating it. ...
In the skirmish yesterday at Pohick Church, Capt. BOYD'S Company of Philadelphia Cavalry behaved most nobly, charging after the Confederate cavalry for three miles.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have been a reader of your paper for the last six months, during which time I have noticed that it is filled with nothing but venom and animosity against the South and everything Southern. Its perusal has given me ample food for reflection, and suggested a few questions to my mind which I hope you will answer with freedom and candor.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of produce, since our last, have been: 68 bbls. Ashes, 20,119 bbls, Flour, 100 bbls. and 674 bags Corn Meal, 120,104 bushels Wheat, 230,967 bushels Corn, 283 bushels Rye, 21,113 bushels Oats, 302 pkgs. Provisions, and 328 bbls. Whisky.

Strange things happen in these latter days, but longest which has come within out ken for some time, is the presence in Canada of an active sympathizer with Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, a gentleman who did service to the Southern cause as a newspaper writer in Washington, seeking through the Ministerial press of this country to stir up strife between the Northern States and Great Britain. ...

Gen. WOOL is assigned to the command of Fortress Monroe. So far, so good. The nation was deeply dissatisfied, not to say indignant, at the fact that one of the bravest, as well as one of the most skillful and experienced of American Generals, was persistently kept in quiet retreat at Troy, N.Y., while political Brigadiers were fretting away the spirit of the Army by awkward blunderings upon masked batteries.

DEAR BROTHER: I have written two letters home since my arrest, giving a brief account of how and when I was taken prisoner, which I think must have reached you, as the officers of the Confederate Army who have charge of us here assured us that they should be forwarded without delay per Adams' Express. ...

Under the apprehension that the general order emanating from the War Department, published yesterday, indicated a belief on the part of the authorities at Washington that the Capital was insufficiently secured against threatened attack, the responses from the various Governors of States to whom the order was addressed have been of the most prompt, enthusiastic and patriotic character. ...

A dispatch to the Courier states that the steamer Hannibal City, with National troops from St. Louis, bound southward, was fired into by the Confederates at Commerce, Mo., and sunk; 300 Nationals were taken prisoners.
Information has reached here that Warsaw, Bolivar and Ocalo, points in the Southwest, have been occupied by portions of the army of Gen. PRICE.

The August Term of the United States District Court commenced yesterday, SAMUEL R. FISHER was appointed foreman of the Grand Jury. Judge CADWALLADER, in addressing the jury, referred to his charge to the former Grand Jury, as embodying all that was required to guide them in their deliberations. It was explained to them that business pertaining to the Circuit Court, as well as the United States, would come before them during the term.

The arrest of BUTLER, READ and others, in Philadelphia, is only the first manifestation of a purpose which the Government has long entertained, but which has been delayed with a view of obtaining accumulative evidence. For some time past the Government has been satisfied that the rebels were receiving aid, comfort and advice from prominent men at the North, who all the while professed to be warmly in sympathy with the United States.

The Central, cars yesterday brought down from the camps near Manassas 350 of our sick soldiers, most of whom are suffering with the measles, while some few are sick with bilious and other affections. Such a large addition to our sick list urgently requires another good hospital, which we hope will be selected and fitted up without the least delay.
A letter to ELWOOD WALTER, Esq., Secretary of the Board of Underwriters, dated at St. Thomas, Aug. 1, says:

A battle took place last night at 12 o'clock at Charleston, between the National forces, about 250 strong, consisting of the Twenty-second Illinois Regiment, under command of Col. DOUGHERTY, accompanied by Lieut.-Col. RANSON, of the Eleventh Illinois Regiment. The rebel force was estimated at 600 to 700 men, and commanded by Col. HUNTER, of JEFF THOMPSON'S army.
The Second and Fourth Battalions of Boston have voted unanimously to offer their services to the Government for three months.

The American bark Joseph Maxwell, which was brought to Cienfuegos by the prize crew of the Sumter, was ordered by the Governor of the town to leave the port within 24 hours, which they did, and were wrecked on the coast soon after having left Cienfuegos. The crew were all saved and brought into our port by one of our coasting steamers.

Yesterday morning a dispatch was received from Secretary CAMERON, ordering the arrest of Mr. PIERCE BUTLER, one of the most noted men of the country, formerly a resident of this city, but recently a resident of the South, and an alleged extensive slave owner. The order to arrest was accompanied with a description of the probable locality in which Mr. BUTLER would be found.
The Moniteur confirms a report current, but not credited, that the French Government has sent dispatches to Rome, asking satisfaction within twenty-four hours.

Rock River Bank vs. Hoffman Gelpcke. The defendants were Bankers at Chicago. It is alleged they collected large sums of money in behalf of the plaintiff, which they refused to deliver. A suit was commenced in this Court against the firm, and an attachment issued, by which the Sheriff attached $8,500 for the Bank and $3,300 for the plaintiff, Naylor.

The Democrats of Maine met in Convention at Augusta a few days ago to organize for the Fall campaign. Resolutions of a decidedly lukewarm character, so far as the Government is concerned, were offered and discussed with much spirit. Propositions were made to qualify them by a resolution supporting the war so far as it is waged to suppress rebellion and sustain the Constitution and the laws, which were promptly voted down.

All is military parade and bustle here at present. Two Illinois regiments the Fourteenth, under, Col. PALMER, and the Fifteenth, under Col. TURNER, arrived yesterday afternoon. They marched to-day for their camp, about four and a half miles west, to Pantsell's Spring, at the junction of the Little Piney and Big Beaver, where excellent water is found.
The St. Paul Pioneer publishes extracts from a letter written by a Lieutenant in the Regular Army, who was engaged in the battle of Bull Run. He says:

Hon. ALFRED ELY has addressed a long letter to his son JOSEPH, of which he this afternoon communicated to us the substance of all that possesses any public interest the most of it relating to business and family affairs.

In the Lower House of the Hungarian Diet, an Address from the Diet to the Emperor had been proposed by M. DINK, and unanimously and enthusiastically adopted. The demands made in this address do not differ from those in the first, which refutes the Imperial rescript, and declared that further negotiations are broken off.

There are many honest people who honestly believe that the North is responsible for the Slavery agitation; and that to Mr. SEWARD the country is indebted for the irrepressible conflict idea; and that the destruction of our Southern trade, and the perilous state of the country, is all owing to Northern fanatics; but our political history does not sustain these honest people in their views.

There are now over 1,700 mechanics and laborers on the roll at the Navy-yard, and at the last payday $45,000 was required to pay off the workmen. All were paid in specie.

The Jeffersonian newspaper office in Westchester was quietly visited by a crowd last night and "cleaned out." There was no disturbance. Most of the residents of the place were ignorant of what was going on until the work was effected.

JEROME BARBER was arrested in Marcellus on Friday last, by United States Deputy Marshal LOWELL, of Syracuse, charged with being "violent and turbulent in his denunciations of the Government of the United States, and ardent and fierce in the expression of his sympathy with the rebel cause." The Syracuse Journal says: "BARBER is about 26 or 28 years old. He is a native of the town of Onondaga, where he has relatives now residing.

Ex-Gov. Haile, of New-Hampshire; H.J. Hastings and family, of Albany; Robert Denniston, of Oswego County; Dr. A.R. Holmes, of Massachusetts; Willis Patten, of N.Y.; J.N. Sutcliff and lady, of Kentucky; Chas. Hall, of Boston; Alexander Harvey, of Buffalo, and Lieut. Southwick, of Washington, are at the Astor House.

Advices from New-Mexico indicate that the rebels are making desperate efforts to gain possession of the Territory. Two or three bodies of National troops had been surrendered by their leaders evidently through treachery and a fight of some consequence had taken place without decisive results.
By the arrival of the schooner Euphemia, Capt. BAYLEY, we have advices from Ponce, Porto Rico, to Aug. 6.
To J.M. Schofield, Acting Adjutant-General: DEAR SIR: I have the honor to submit the follow ing report of the part taken by the Iowa troops in the late hotly contested battle of "Wilson Creek".

Gen. SERRANO has not yet returned from his expedition to St. Domingo, but we have news of his arrival there, of his having been most splendidly received at Jamaica, and that extraordinary preparations were being made at the Capital to welcome his arrival. The Diario of this city, speaking about the passage from here to St. Domingo, says that it was a very gay one, and that the General was in excellent spirits.

The preliminary examination of ALBERT S. BIGELOW and A.H. POTTER, both of New-Bedford, charged with fitting out the whaleship Brutus, for a slaver, took place to-day before United States Commissioner, GUILD. The evidence failed to implicate POTTER, who was discharged. BIGELOW was held for trial.

A new face is put on the affairs of the Union by the financial success of Mr. CHASE. The unanimity with which the Northern capitalists come to the rescue of the Government in its present critical position affords an assurance that the Governmant is to be sustained. Capital becoming so far hazarded in the war cannot, after this, hold back from its prosecution.

We publish this morning a very important letter from our correspondent in the City of Mexico. It announces that England, France and Spain have simultaneously closed their relations with the Mexican Government, and withdrawn their Ministers, on the ground which may or may not be more than a pretext that the Government has, in its financial extremity, suspended for two years payment of its public debt.

Having mixed somewhat extensively with the merchants and tradespeople of England during the past four or five weeks, and discussed in many circles our American troubles, I am able to form a correct opinion as to the feeling of sympathy amongst that particular class. It is almost universally with the North, but at the same time there is an almost universal doubt as to the ability of the North to accomplish what that they undertaken.

There is still something wanting to the Northern side in this struggle with the rebels. These men fight with desperation, for they believe they strike for the chastity of wives, the safety of children and homes. Their war-cry is "Death, rather than subjection!" The Bank of England on the 15th reduced their rate of discount from 5 to 4 cent. The event was not altogether anticipated. The remarkable success that has attended the first effort of the Government to assail the rebel States on their exposed sea-coast, will doubtless inspire our military leaders to a perseverance in the policy. The country hails the achievement as the most sensible and significant of all our war movements. If this mode of attack had been begun earlier, very few privateers would now be scourging our commerce, and emboldening the Confederates by their successes.

The subjoined letter from McCULLOCH'S Headquarters, Camp Stephens, July 28, addressed to the Military Board, Little Rock, Ark., is published in the Gazette:

In the London Money market the Funds were quite buoyant on the 21st of August, and an advance in Consols was firmly established. In the Discount market there was increased ease, and good bills were scarce and taken at 4 cent. Evidences of stagnation in trade are increasing. Applications at the Bank continued limited.

I presume that most of the particulars of the brilliant success of the Naval expedition to Hatteras Inlet will reach you in advance of this letter. Nevertheless I send you some desultory particulars, which you may not possibly receive from any other source.

McCLELLAN with speedy reforms. He says that the Southerners believe they will be safe if they hold out until October,and that at the end of the year the Northerners will be further from their aim than ever.

Considerable excitement was created yesterday by the publication of a brief dispatch, stating that heavy cannonading was going on across the Potomae, and that the belief was Prevalent in Washington that an attack was being made by the rebels on the National lines.

The patriotic people of Yorkville assembled last evening, to the number of over five thousand, in a grand Union Mass Meeting, at the junction of Eightysixth-street and Fourth-avenue. A large platform was erected, DODWORTH'S unrivaled band was engaged for the occasion, a 6-pounder cannon was brought out, and bonfires blazed at the corners of the streets.

Senator WILSON meets with great encouragement in raising his regiment. Over 30 companies have already rendered their services, of which 28 have been accepted, including 16 from the returned three months' regiments. The companies are accepted, with the understanding that their ranks will be recruited to the standard within a week. The recruiting officers are required to make daily returns.

The Democratic State Convention assembled at Wieting Hall, at 12 o'clock. The body of the hall was completely packed, the representation being quite full, and many outsiders having succeeded in obtaining tickets of admission to the floor. The galleries were crowded with spectators, and a lively interest was manifested in the proceedings. Mozart and Tammany both obtained tickets, and took seats on the floor.

As we stated yesterday, there was nothing improbable in the announcement of his death, as it first reached us. He is known to have been a long time in feeble health.

We published yesterday morning an order issued at Washington, providing that all the volun teers raised in New-York must be reported to the State military authorities. In pursuance of that order, the following has been issued from the State Headquarters:

Our news from Fort Hatteras is highly important and highly encouraging. It appears that hundreds of citizens of the old North State have a gone forth to meet the Union forces, to rejoice once more in the floating of the Stars and stripes over their heads, and to asseverate, in the solemn form of an oath, that they are true, and mean to be true to the old Constitution of their fathers.

This morning, at 11 o'clock, Gen. GRANT, with two regiments of infantry, one company of light artillery and two gunboats, took possession of Paducah, Ky. He found secession flags flying in different parts of the city, in expectation of greeting the arrival of the Southern Army, which was reported 3,800 strong, 16 miles distant. The loyal citizens tore down the secession flags on the arrival of our troops.
The Monticello and Harriet Lane arrived from Hatteras Inlet this morning. They report the most gratifying intelligence.

The news from Kentucky this morning is of the highest importance. I Yesterday forenoon Gen. GRANT, commanding the National forces at Cairo, with two regiments of infantry, one company of light artillery and two gunboats, took possession of Paducah, which has for some time been notorious as the rendezvous of Secessionists.

ABE HAGER, baggage-master on the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad, furnishes to the St. Louis Democrat the following account of a diabolical outrage on that road the day before yesterday:

Messrs. SARGENT and HILL, of Yarmouth, who were arrested by order of the Secretary of War, yesterday, were taken by the United States officers in a carriage westward to-day, with the intention of taking the cars at Saco, but were pursued with a writ of habeas corpus, and brought back to the city. They will have a hearing to-morrow before the United States Circuit Court, Judge CLIFFORD.

The Board met yesterday afternoon to hear the report of the Special Committee on the reduction of the tax levy, but in consequence of the absence of the Chairman, as explained in the following note, the matter was further postponed:

The steamers Harriet Lane and Monticello arrived this morning from Hatteras Inlet. All on board are well. The latter brings intelligence of the evacuation of Fort Morgan, at Ocracoke Inlet, twelve miles south of Hatteras, by the rebels, after they had spiked their guns and destroyed their munitions of war. It mounted six guns. The Susquehannah was to go down and take possession yesterday.

Islip, L.I., appears to be infected with a smal band of sympathisers with JEFF. DAVIS, who leave rendered themselves so obnoxious to the loyal citizens of the place that they have found it necessary to make a demonstration.

Intelligence from the Virginia shore is to the effect that, from opposite the White House Ford, near the mouth of the Seneca River, down to Arlington Heights, the rebels have heavy pickets, and are daily expecting reinforcements to enable them to extend to Conrad's Ferry. There are at least from 600 to 700 now along the line.

SLAVES. Some question has been raised as to the law of Congress under which Gen. FREMONT'S proclamation concerning the slaves of rebels, was issued. So far as we understand the matter, Gen. FREMONT'S declaration goes somewhat beyond the letter of any law which has been enacted on this subject.

While it is gratifying to all friends of the Union and Constitution to see the evidences of the popular faith in the Government, and its restoration which day adds unto day, it must be especially gratifying to the President to know how much this sanguine temper results from the energy recently displayed by his Administration.

Pursuant to adjournment, the Committee met on Thurday afternoon, at the office of the Clerk of the Board of supervisors, for the purpose of reporting by-laws for the permanent organization of the Convention and selecting officers. Messrs. PURDY SWEENY, WILLIAMSON, BLUNT AND STOUT, were present Mr. WHITE being absent from the City, Mr. PURDY in the chair.

The haste with which Congress closed its business and adjourned, is likely to beget several very embarrassing and, perhaps, injurious effects upon public interests. The contradictions between certain acts in the published pamphlet, the needless repetitions, the grammatical inaccuracies, which unfriendly criticism has pointed out, are of little essential importance, and may be cured at the approaching regular session.

The statement that the President disapproves of the proclamation issued by Gen. FREMONT, has no shadow of foundation. The President has carefully selected commanding officers, and he will in no instance interfere with their action so long as he continues them in the field.

Thirty thousand Minie rifles have been sent from San Francisco to Aspinwall in the steamer Sanora. Company H, Fourth Infantry, U.S.A., Capt. H.D. WALLEN, acted as escort, and then returned to California after the safe delivery of their valuable charge.
Mr. F.C. DUTNEUX, one of the crew of the Jeff. Davis, has furnished the Richmond Enquirer with a graphic account of the career of that pirate, from which we extract the following:

Nothing has occurred to-day over the river to disturb the general quiet not even a skirmish between pickets breaking the monotony of camp life. The rebels have receded on a line west from Ball's Cross Roads to Chain Bridge, and our pickets have advanced a mile west.

CLERKE, J. Ely Hoppock vs. C.D. Archibald. Reference ordered to A.D. Ditmars. Esq., to take the additional testimony as to the facts stated in the plaintiff's and defendant's affidavits, and report the same, with his opinion thereon, founded on the said affidavits and said additional testimony.

Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen: Whence this mighty gathering before me, and all around me? and for what purpose? Whence and why these spires pointing to Heaven, telling of refinement and religion? Whence these institutions of learning? Whence these beautiful abodes, these gathering places of affection around whose hearthstones a free and happy people cluster? Whence this beautiful valley spread out here, no less beautiful than this sky, so "darkly, deeply, beautifully blue?"

One of the events of the week with us has been the advent of prince NAPOLEON. He comes rom the North, attended by his suite, having been on a visit to Lake Superior, where he spent some time in "looking about" in the mineral regions. They arrived in this city on Monday evening, and, it is understood, left yesterday, via the Illinois Central, for St. Louis. Having visited the Eastern

The Coast Survey has hither to been known to the public as a mysterious scientific body, endowed with apparently unlimited power of swallowing appropriations. These, anuually renewed, at the rate of half a million or so dollars, have made tax-payers, non-appreciative of scientific undertakings, to groan bitterly in the inner man.

At last the first great step has been taken to show the world that we are in earnest in our attempts to crush the rebellion which has been threatening our national existence for now nearly a year! And JOHN C. FREMONT, the people's first leader against the great slaveholder's conspiracy, has been the first man to strike the first great blow against its bold outbreak.

A free Press is the cause of great good. Even a licentious Press is far better than a Press which is enslaved, because, in the former case both sides may be heard, but in the latter they cannot. A licentious Press may be an evil, but a fettered Press must be so.

SUICIDE A MELANCHOLY CASE. A young man named WILLIAM UNDERWOOD, about 28 years of age, native of Boston, but for the last five years a merchant in the city of Milwaukee, Wis., committed suicide yesterday morning about 9 o'clock, at the private boarding-house of Mrs. AYRES, No.57 Springstreet, by shooting himself in the head with a revolver.

The eight regiments assembled here (including that of Gen. HECKER) have received orders to march "to the South" at 3 o'clock to-day. A serious difficulty in the Hecker Regiment has just been arranged.

Everything was very quiet in the vicinity of Washington yesterday not even a skirmish between pickets occurring to break the monotony. The rebels have a made several movements recently, apparently with a view to congregating a larger force around Munson's Hill, though their force, as ascertained by a balloon observation yesterday, has not been increased.

Among the items of news brought by the Arago is one that will be hailed with pleasure by all friends of free thought in this country. It is that Protestants are to be permitted to open schools in France. Thus does the Emperor give anew the assurance that his policy is progress;" and France is made illustrious by the embodiment of the principle in her own social life.

We have already had a report by telegraph of a fight in Boone Country, Virginia, between a portion of the National troops and some rebels, in Boone County, in which the latter defeated and the town of Boone burned. Since my last communication, nothing has occurred worthy of mention in the TIMES besides the Tyler affair at Cross Lanes some fifty odd miles from this point. We had no particulars of that arrangement until to-day, and they contrast ridiculously with the electrical flourishes which were forwarded to the Associated Press from Gallipolis. I am not at liberty to report details even now. The substantial facts are as follows:

Ten days ago, Gen. PRENTISS, who commands the Union forces in Southern Illinois, finding himself in possession of an inconvenient number of prisoners, dispatched a flag of truce to Gen. PILLOW to propose an exchange. The flag was received with unexceptionable courtesy by the hero of the misplaced ditch; its bearer treated with frank hospitality, and sent back with a satisfactory answer.
Steamers Mars, Fenton, Philadelphia, J. N. Briggs Chesapeake, Crowell. Portland, H.B. Cromwell.

The proclamation of Gen. FREMONT brings us to a new chapter in the war of rebellion. It brings us where we ought to have been six months ago. It brings us to the consideration of great problems not only those connected with the war, but with the future condition of this country. Among these are the two great points of state Rights and Negro Slavery.

The Charleston Mercury of the 5th says that Capt. COXETTA, of the brig. Jeff. Davis, has arrived. He has been presented with a watch, The captain says that for fully two weeks he was cruising for the yacht Rebecca, Capt. J.G. BENNETT, Jr., but without success.
The Lowell (Mass.) Advertiser publishes the following letter from Major-Gen. BUTLER upon the condition of the country and the coming State election:

The regular Fall season at our theatres will commence to-night with the opening of the Winter Garden, the rentree of Mrs. JOHN WOOD, and the production of an expensively-got-up spectacular piece. A few weeks ago the prospects seemed blue enough, but since then they have greatly changed, and strange as it may sound, the indications are now in favor of a good Fall season.

It appears that the die is cast in Kentucky and that in spite of the earnest efforts of loyal Unionists to preserve the State from the horrors of the war that is now desolating Virginia and Missouri, the tramp of hostile armies is now felt on her soil.

FLOUR dull. WHEAT, but little doing; sales of car-loads red State, at $1.6 bag white Michigan at $1.27. RYE, in the street, at 65c.@66c. CORN dull, at 47c. for car-loads at East Albany, and 46c. for 3.70c. bushels Western mixed, afloats for cargoes afloat 45c. are offered, and some lots are going into store. OATS, 33c.@33 c. for State. WHISKY is held at 19c.

DEDICATION OF SAINT ANNE'S CHURCH. There was a large and appreciative audience present at the dedication of Saint Anne's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, yesterday forenoon. The church is located at the corner of Front and Gold streets, and is a most elegant, costly and tasteful structure, in every respect creditable to the taste of the architect, Mr. KEELY, of Brooklyn, and to the directing church authorities.

The country will be gratified by the order which has been issued by Gen. McCLELLAN, enjoining a more perfect respect for the Sabbath, on the part of his command, than it has heretofore received. The order is happily so specific that it cannot fail to secure the eminently proper object in view. The General says:

The remark of all foreign observers, that the American people is to the last degree variable, petulant and easily moved to extremes of elation or depression, is one under which we shall do well to sit meekly.
The testimony for the prosecution in the case of Rev. HENRY BUDGE, charged with the murder of his wife, was closed before Judge ALLEN, at Rome, yesterday.

The news from Washington this morning indicates the speedy opening of active hostilities. Gen. McCLELLAN on Saturday made a balloon assention with Prof. LOWE, and spent two hours in making reconnoisances of the enemy's positions.

GEN. BEAUREGARD, COMMANDER OF THE CONFEDERATE ARMY Dear Sir: With a grievous and torn heart, I address you. If it is in your power, will you give a word of comfort to a distressed spirit? I allude to the death of the gallant Col. CAMERON, of the National Army, on last Sunday, 21st July. We are all God's creatures, alike is his sight. It is a bereaved sister that petitions.

I do not know that I can give you much information of importance from this point. Here is not really the scene of operations in Missouri it is only the base of operations, and not the point at which occur those magnificent events which give a letter the character of a grand poem, or enable a letter-writer to rise above the mere stupid chronicler of dull events.

The Third Rhode Island Regiment Col. BLANNING, arrived in this City by the steamship Commodore yesterday afternoon. The arrival was quite unexpected, the United States Quartermaster not having been notified of the fact. The men landed at Pier No. 1, North River, but did not leave the dock; shortly afterward they reembarked and were carried to Fort Hamilton, where at present they are quartered.

Gen. McCLELLAN has wrought a marvelous change in the face of affairs in his military division, and has reduced to order the chaotic rubbish which he found here on taking the command; but no man can be ubiquitous or omnicient, and even yet it is my duty to call his attention to glaring abuses.

I presume you will have had the particulars of the little affair here, but you perhaps have not learned all that occurred. We attacked the batteries at this Inlet last Wednesday, and after shelling them two or three hours they (the rebels) hoisted an American flag, and we ceased firing.

FIRE, EXPLOSION AND LOSS OF LIFE. Between 7 and 8 o'clock, on Saturday night, a fire broke out on board the schooner Cornelia, of New-Bedford, which resulted in the destruction of a large amount of property, the death of one man and the serious injury of two others.

The controversy in the United States has already influenced this country. The first news of secession gave courage to Buenos Ayres to maintain also a kind of reserved State right. The determination of the United States Government to maintain its integrity has, on the other hand, given moral strength to the Confederation. The position of the Confederation and of the United States is nearly alike.

WEINSTEN Co., wholesale clothiers; on the second by T.S. WHEELER, as a wholesale button and general finding store for tailors' goods; the third floor by HECHT FRIEDLAND, shirt manufacturers, and the first floor by LOCKWOOD BROS. UUDERHILL, auctioneers.

Yesterday afternoon two or three rear cars of a train containing a detachment of the Ira Harris Cavalry, of New-York, under Col. KILPATRICK, was thrown from the track of the Northern Central Railroad, near Cockeysville, through the criminal carelessness of the engineer. Four soldiers were instantly killed and several wounded, three mortally.

In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFHAN, James Kelly, aged 18, and Thos. Burns, aged 26, were tried and convicted of highway robbery, and sentenced to the State Prison for ten years each. The robbery was committed in Chatham-square a week ago today, upon the person of Jas. W. McGuire.

There is no change of moment to note in the condition of affairs in the vicinity of Washington. Matters last night remained very much as on the night previous. An incidental skirmish or two between advanced pickets took place yesterday, but with no results of consequence.

Mr. HOLT indicated, the other day, a characteristic of the present war which the future historian will have occasion to record as the most remarkable metaphysical fact of the times. "I have nowhere in the North," said he, "found any feeling of exasperation against the people of the South." European journalists emphasize the same characteristic, and some even go so far as to assert that we will never conquer until we grow more "vindictive."

At the meeting of the Board last evening, Alder man BOOLE offered a resolution permitting Lewis S. Rice to erect a tent on the Battery for the purpose of exhibiting a whale, during the pleasure of the Common Council.

Two of the rebels were killed; and in another skirmish the same day ten more of the rebels were killed and thirty-two horses captured. The period has passed which I indicated as the limit of danger to the Capital, and though battle between the confronting hosts on the right bank of the Potomac may still be considered imminent, there is no apprehension left, in any loyal mind, that the National Army, when such conflict comes, will not he entirely successful. The heart of the troops is entirely restored.

In March last, a friend who knew the country well, and who was just returned from the Southwest, wrote to me, that "all the Slave States would secede, except Maryland and Missouri; war is inevitable." I well knew the South meant to secede, and that war was the inevitable consequence, but I wrote him that he was mistaken in one particular. Kentucky would not secede. I know the spirit of Kentucky very well.

In speaking of DANIEL S. DICKINSON, the Albany Atlas and Argus, true to its instincts of opposition to everybody whose loyalty to the Union rises above party fealty, says: "No man has done more to bring upon the country the disasters that surround it; and upon no one does the duty of repairing these disasters fall more directly and heavily."

The People's Convention, called by no one knows whom, has astonished its contrivers. For several days it has been apparent, from the number and character of the delegations announced from the various sections of the State, that an influential and highly respectable body of men would be in Syracuse to-day, in response to the volunteer call. Yesterday the town began rapidly to fill up, and before daylight this morning all the first-class hotels were overflowing.

The anticipated arrival of the Prince of JOINVILLE has prompted extraordinary displays of hospitality on the part of this Government. Escorts have been provided; instructions to Custom-house officers that unusual courtesies and facilities may be offered, have come from Washington; and the princeling, his son, is to have a place in the Naval Academy, which thousands of American sons have sought in vain.

A period of peace continued till a generation had passed away, and with it the embittered recollections growing out of an unprovoked, on our part, and cruel war, had apparently brought England and the United States into relations of amity and mutual esteem. The two seemed in a fair way to prove an exception to the law by which nations almost universally misinterpret the character and sentiments of each other.

ROCKVILLE, Tuesday, Sept. 10. On Saturday last a primary meeting was held here by the Secessionists to elect delegates to the Baltimore Convention to nominate State officers. About six delegates from Montgomery County were present. Their meeting was a secret one.

SYRACUSE, Wednesday, Sept. 11, 1861. Knowing that your telegraphic advices will give you all requisite information in relation to the organization of the Republican Convention, and touching the formal proceedings of both the patriotic bodies now in session here, long before any letter will reach you by the slower medium of the railroad, I look about for some matter of interest aside from what strictly belongs to the department of news.

THURSDAY, Sept.12--P.M. The popular subscription to the National Loan on 7.30 per cent. Treasury Bonds, at the SubTreasury office to-day, amounted to over one million dollars. The public interest in the Loan is rapidly on the increase, and the amount taken today, in advance of the ability of the Department at Washington to prepare and deliver the Bonds, is the heaviest daily subscription since the books were opened.

AT WORK.--Hon. MOSES F. ODELL, member of Congress from the Second Brooklyn District, has returned to Washington with a view to looking after the interests of the Brooklyn troops. Since the commencement of the war, Mr. ODELL has been assiduous in his efforts to benefit the condition of men who have gone to the seat of war from this city, and has in many instances rendered marked and valuable service.

The rebels commenced an advance on both pikes yesterday morning, towards Elk Water and Cheat Mountain Summit. They succeeded in surrounding the fort on the summit, and cut the telegraph wire. They continued to advance on Elk Water until within two miles of our troops, when a few shells from Loomis' Battery dispersed them. Skirmishing was kept up all night.

The Academy of Music will open for the season to-night, but not with opera. For the moment the musical prospect is somewhat clouded. This regiment, Col. EUGENE LE GAL, is progressing rapidly toward completion. At Factoryville, Staten Island, a new camp has been erected for the accommodation of the men; it covers sixty acres of ground, and is one of the most delightful places imaginable. Government this morning commenced throwing up intrenchments on Potter's Hill, an eminence in the eastern suburbs of the city, near the Philadelphia Turnpike. The ground was surveyed at the same time as that of Federal Hill, and the fortification to be built will be one of the most extensive and substantial in this country. The ground was broken by the Seventh Maine Regiment, encamped at Patterson's Park, near by.

The Seventh Regiment New-Jersey Volunteers left for Washington at 3 P.M. to-day. The regiment is well officered, having for its Colonel JOSEPH W. REEVE, of long service in the Navy, having been appointed Midshipman in 1828. During the Mexican war he was Captain of a company of mounted rifles, serving with distinction.

Two couriers just arrived from Lexington give the following intelligence, which is believed by the commanding officer here to be in the main reliable. Gen. PRICE commenced an attack on the intrenchments at Lexington, commanded by Col. MULLIGAN, on Monday. The fight lasted, all day, and was very severe. Gen. PRICE assaulted the works, and was repulsed with severe loss.

The General commanding desires to reassure the people of Western Virginia that it is the desire and intention of the United States Government to give to the citizens full and ample protection in all their civil and political rights, and that private property, of whatever character or description, shall be held inviolate.

Much more activity is now observable on Governor's Island than was the case a short time ago. The recruits for general service of whom there are two full companies are drilled three times a day in company drill. Hitherto they have been drilled twice a day only. This looks as though they will shortly be required elsewhere.

With a view to the health and comfort of the volunteer troops in and near to the City of St. Louis, a Sanitary Committee is hereby appointed, to consist of five gentlemen, who shall serve voluntarily, and be removable at pleasure. Its general object shall be to carry out, under the properly constituted military authorities, and in compliance with their orders, such sanitary regulations and reforms as the well-being of the soldiers demand.

The House bill passed, by a vote of 62 to 15, authorizing the Military Board to borrow $1,000,000 in addition to a million authorized May 24, on the State bonds, payable in ten years, and establishing a tax of 5 per cent on a hundred dollars, to pay the bonds and interest, the said sum to be appropriated for the defence of the State.
