The sales of COTTON to-day were 15,000 bales, of which 8,000 were to speculators and exporters. The market closed firmer at the rates reported yesterday.

The Meagher demonstration to-night attracted an immense audience. Music Hall was filled to its utmost capacity, and more than 2,000 were turned away unable to gain admittance. The audience, closely packed, numbered not less than 4,000. About $1,500 were realized.

It is thought by many persons here that JACK- SON went through the miserable farce of calling the Legislature together at Lexington yesterday, for the purpose of passing the ordinance of secession. In this Court, yesterday, Recorder HOFFMAN presiding, Julia Boland, 19 years, native of Ireland, pleaded guilty to defrauding the disbursers of the patriotic fund for the relief of the families of volunteers, out of $24.50, by representing that she had a husband in the army. Sentenced to the City Prison for seven days.

Some twenty prisoners who have been waiting here for several days to go to Norfolk by a flag of truce, will return to Baltimore to-night. Neither the General nor the Flag-Officer will allow any communication with the rebels for a number of days at least.

A special session of the Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows was convened last night at Odd Fellows Hall to take measures to express the feelings of the Lodge upon hearing of the death of P.G. Sire THOMAS WILDEY.

While it is certainly possible to attach too much importance to the occasional manifestations of Union sentiment in the seceded States, they are nevertheless entitled to very great weight in our judgment of the future.

We spoke yesterday of the probable change of rebel tactics in the West, which will lead the rebel generals to transfer again to Missouri their daring, aggressive enterprises. Their failure to get possession of Louisville, and the tremendous Union rally in that State, have put them on the defensive. They are blowing up the bridges between themselves and the Union armies in Kentucky, thus proving their fear of attack rather than their disposition to advance.

NO PROGRESS MADE. At twenty minutes past 4, the Charter Convention had a bare quorum, and the reading of the minutes of the last meeting was proceeded with. The various Standing Committees were called upon, but the unanimous response was "progress reported." The Committee on Absentees made a similar report.

The steamship North Briton, from Liverpool on the 10th of October, via Londonderry on the 11th, has reached Father Point. She brings 78 cabin and 222 steerage passengers.

On the evening of the 5th inst., Mr. S.W. LINDSAY, M.P. for Sunderland, delivered an address in the Mechanics' Institute, North Shields, the subject being "America and the Americans." The chair was occupied by the Mayor, who briefly introduced the lecturer.

The following dispatch was received here this morning, and forwarded to headquarters at St. Louis; In conjunction with Col. PLUMMER'S command we have routed the rebels of THOMPSON and LOWE, estimated at 5,000. Their loss was heavy. Our loss was small, and confined principally to the First Indiana cavalry. We captured four heavy guns. LOWE, the rebel leader, was killed.

The following is a special dispatch to the St. Louis Democrat: Parties direct from Warsaw say no news of importance had reached that point up to 2 o'clock yesterday. The pontoon bridge was finished, and the river was high.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mme. HERRMANN who has contributed so charmingly to the enjoyability of Mr. HERRMANN'S soirees will take her benefit here tonight. It is rightly made a special occasion by the management, and will, we hope, be remembered as such by the public.

The New-Orleans Picayune of the 12th, editorially contratulates its readers on the success of HOLLINS' flotilla on the Mississippi, and particularly the exploit of the Manassas. It urges the Southern people to be prepared to drive the Northern invaders from their ports and coasts at every sacrifice and exertion.

The Pacific Mutual Insurance Company vs. Wm. J. Ree et al. This action was brought upon certain promissory notes given some years since to the plaintiffs for insurance premiums due them from defendants.

The ruling caste in England give law and public opinion to that country. The newspaper press there is only its mouthpiece. This class and press have been constant in their assertions that the rebellion in this country could not be put down. In this way they have contributed more than all other causes to give courage and persistency to it.

The New-York Herald is actually bursting with anxiety to see our Government involved in a war with England. It has labored in this cause for months, and as the hope of success fades, it gets actually raving for a foreign fight. It is quite apparent to the Herald and the rest of the world, that the United States Government has its hands full trying to reestablish its authority over the seceded States.

The trial of the privateers of the Savannah is set down to commence to-day in the United States Circuit Court, before Judges NELSON and SHIPMAN.

A courier has arrived here from Camp Dick Robinson, and reports a fight yesterday between Gen. ZOLLICOFFER with 6,000 or 7,000 men, and Col. GARRARD with 1,200 men, at Camp Wild Cat. ZOLLICOFFER made three different attacks, each time being repulsed with considerable loss. The National loss amounted to four killed and twenty wounded.

A Cabinet meeting in reference to the case of Gen. FREMONT was held yesterday, at which, our correspondent assures us, it was decided not to interfere for the present with Gen. FREMONT in his command. Meantime, however, Judge DAVIS, of Illinois, has been commissioned to take testimony in reference to the contracts made in the Western Department, and it is understood that whatever bills he may pass will be paid.

There has been a considerable outcry in the North in reference to the means whereby several States have been what is called "forced out of the Union." But it is not to be expected that in the struggle for States between the Confederation and the United States some acts should not be committed by the latter which have very much the look of "forcing them not to go out of the Union."

The examination of the case of ERASTUS H BOOTH, charged with being captain of the slaver Buckeye, which landed a cargo of negroes in Cuba about a year ago, was resumed yesterday before Commissioner OSBORNE.

The Guardia-Murillo Convention, by which the State agrees to achnowledge Gen. MOSQUERA as the Executive of the National Government at Bogota was approved by the Legislative Assembly yesterday. It needs the approval of Gen. MOSQUERA, Provisional President, to become effective. The vote stood 15 to 5 seven of the opposition declining to vote.

It is full of bitterness against the Union and the people of the North, who are accused of everything that is bad, the accusations resting entirely upon the assertion of the Executive.

The probability of an early recognition of the Southern Confederacy by France is the leading topic in the latest batch of foreign news. The several Chambers of Commerce in the Empire are said to be busily petitioning the Government to that effect.

The movements of the Federal army in the Southwest are becoming interesting. The apparent quiet that has prevailed West of Jefferson City for several days past, has not been a silence of inactivity. The Federal forces have been in motion, and marching rapidly, ever since Tuesday. The army is now on the Osage at Warsaw, and a portion of SEIGEL'S Division has even crossed the river.

During that time many versions of the affair have been given, all more or loss incorrect, and the country has been balancing between the blame which certain correspendents insist should fall upon Gen. STONE and the unbounded praise which the same parties lavish upon the late Col. BAKER.

The great naval and military expedition, intended for operations on the Southern Coast, has at last left for its destination wherever that may be. The fleet sailed from Hampton Roads on Tuesday morning, in fine style, the weather being all that could be desired.
A meeting of the electors of the Sixth Senatorial District is to be held to-morrow evening at Irving Hall, to ratify the nomination of WASHINGTON SMITH for the State Senate.

Advices from Hayti extend to Oct. 19. According to the Opinion Nationale a partial change had occurred in the Cabinet of President GEFFRARD. The Portfolio of Justice had been intrusted to a former member of the Legislative body.

It is reported that the Italian question has been debated in Cabinet Council with considerable animation, owing chiefly to the decided tone taken by PERSIGNY in favor of the Italian side. No resolution was taken.

Francis Roeder vs. Dorman L. Ormsby and Leonard D. Ormsby. This is one of those actions brought under the statute of 1847-9, authorizing the personal representatives of a party whose death has been caused by the wrongful act of another, to bring an action for the recovery of civil damages, where, had the deceased party lived, he would have been entitled to such damages, or would have had cause of action.

At a regular meeting of this Board last evening. Alderman FREAR in the Chair, the petition of certain stage owners and carmen, asking for an ordinance prohibiting the sprinkling of Broadway, was granted.

A special dispatch to the St. Louis Republican says: "Gen. FERMONT and Staff arrived here yesterday, and the Benton Cadets, Col. CARR'S Cavalry, Maj. HOLMAN'S Sharpshooters, and Gen. SIEGEL'S command at different periods during the same day, finding no professed rebels in the place. Our troops were received with delight, the Stars and Stripes being displayed at numerous houses, and men, women and children waving handkerchiefs from almost every doorway."

The loss by the burning of CRAIG'S Mills is over a hundred thousand dollars, of which $25,000 is insured on the machinery, including $15,000 in the Etna Insurance Company of Hartford. The building contained two hundred and sixty-six looms, (belonging to various parties,) engaged on army flannels. Two hundred operatives were thrown out of employment.

Jane Malone vs. Simpson and Another. This was an appeal from a judgment rendered below in favor of the plaintiff, a married woman, who sued to recover certain funds derived from her separate estate, which had been deposited with the defendant.
The Santa Fe mail and Carson City Expres reached here on Saturday, in advance of schedule time.

The immense fleet, under Flag-officer DUPONT, sailed this morning. The Wabash, with the gunboats, leading the van; then the troopship and the rear, protected by the Mohican, Seminole, Augusta, Florida and Alabama. The retirement of the veteran patriot, Lieut.Gen. SCOTT, is announced this morning. On Thursday last, he sent to President LINCOLN a letter announcing his determination to avail himself of the provisions of the act for retiring officers, recently passed by Congress his physical infirmities rendering it absolutely necessary that he should seek repose.

An officer on board the ship Vandalia, till lately one of the squadron off Charleston, writes with reference to some of our strictures on the imperfections of the blockade at that point. He thinks the Navy Department, which did not send proper vessels, and more of them, is to blame, and not the force, which did the best it could.

It cannot be otherwise than that the retirement of Gen. SCOTT from the command of the army, will be noted as an era in the military history of the country. His career, indeed, embodies all there is of the National military life since the revolutionary period. His first services as a soldier were in the second war with Great Britain.

The schooner Susquehanna, DANIEL MYERS, (colored,) captain, and owned by him conjointly with Messrs. APPLEGATE SON, of Baltimore, reached this port on Tuesday, having succeeded in running the rebel blockade of the Potomac. Capt. MYERS is very well known among the merchants of this city, and especially among the flour shippers. He is about 69 years of age, and has been a ship-master, trading to and from Baltimore for the last 55 years.

Times of trouble and disaster are touchstones. They not only bring out hidden elements of strength or weakness in those upon whom the disaster falls, but they throw new lights upon all with whom life has brought them in connection.

The British Mail steamship Karnak, Capt. MESSURIER, from Havana, Oct. 26, and Nassau, Oct. 28, reached here yesterday morning. Nothing of interest had occurred at either port since previous advices. The health of Havana and Nassau is reported as good.

The march of Gen. FREMONT from St. Louis presents little more than that systematic attention to military detail, which constitutes the ordinary precursor to the conflict.

A few days since we published in the TIMES an account of a horrible murder, supposed to have been committed in New-Jersey. The murdered man, SIGISMUND FELLNER, was a German Jew, about 40 years of age, who arrived in this country, on the 19th of October, by the steamship Bavaria. His body was found floating in the water, near Applegate's Landing, NewJersey.

SIR: I have to report that the two schooners brought here by me were captured by us. The first, the Ezilda, was taken on the 30th ult., four or five miles from land, with the Timbalier light bearing W., S., about thirteen miles.

Yesterday was a day of excitement. A ship laden with French naval stores took fire in the bay. She was strongly anchored, and could not be towed out; so she blew up in the midst of the shipping.

Gen. SCOTT took his departure yesterday morning for New-York. Learning that the old veteran intended to take his leave in the morning, President FELTON, of the Philadelphia and Baltimore Railroad, sent forward his splendid private car for the use of himself and suite, and before daylight it was in readiness for him, at the Baltimore depot.

Our news from all parts of Central and South America is unusually meagre and uninteresting by the mails which centre here. There are slight ripples on the surface in Ecuador, Peru and Bolivia, but no great chance, apparently, that they will culminate into "mountain waves." Chili is quiet, happy, and even jubilant under the new millennium of conciliation and compromise inaugurated by her new President.

The heavy easterly storm which culminated on Saturday night, was one of the severest that has been experienced for twelve months on this part of the coast. The tide on Saturday evening and Sunday morning, in the East and North Rivers, rose higher than it has been known for over 20 years, several of the docks being completely submerged, while the streets fronting the river were kneedeep with water.

Our Washington correspondent telegraphs positively that the order transferring the command of the Western Military Department from Gen. FREMONT to Gen. HUNTER, has been sent to the former, and has probably reached him. The order is stated to be absolute and unconditional, and based upon a thorough conviction of FREMONT'S incapacity as a General, and of his profligacy in the expenditure of the public money.

The People have determined that this election shall not be controlled by partisan considerations. They desire that it should be simply a declaration of this City and State in favor of the Union and against rebellion. And they have put in nomination a State, County and Judiciary ticket, which represents their sentiments and embraces men of all political parties who agree on this one cardinal point.

This afternoon the Times has some particulars of the late fight at Gauley Bridge. The engagement was not a general battle, but a rather warm skirmish, in which the enemy were repulsed with great loss. The action was commenced by the rebels, who opened two batteries on our lines near Ganley Bridge, but, though the firing continued all day, little or no damage was done, not a man being killed.

An exhibition of a very interesting character is Capt. WILLIAMS' Panorama of a Whaling Voyage at Hope Chapel. In a graphic narrative, or, more properly speaking, yarn, the Captain tells us of his adventures in the South Seas, and explains with remarkable force the secret of taking whales.

Some branches of the Wool trade have shown great activity during the last few weeks, in consequence of the demand for Wool and Woolens suitable for blankets and army clothing adapted for export to the United States.

The death of Sir JAMES GRAHAM is reported by the last steamer as having occurred at Netherby, on the 25th of October. Sir JAMES is chiefly distinguished as having been the chosen lieutenant of PEEL, and of late the chief of the Peelites. If he was not a great statesman, he was certainly a powerful Minister, and his support was always considered of immense advantage to a Government.

The magnitude of the force either under arms or shortly to be raised is almost incredible. After all the abatements demanded by the exaggerations of the American journals, the residue of the probable truth, as computed by our special correspondent, is enough to astound us. None of the regular armies of Europe make any approach to the scale of these levies, all of which, be it observed, are for active and immediate service.

FIRE IN A GROCERY-STORE. About 2 o'clock, yesterday (Tuesday) morning, a fire broke out in a grocery-store, No 120 West Nineteenth-street, and before it could be extinguished extended to Nos. 118, 122 and 124, which, being frame-buildings, were entirely destroyed. The grocery where the fire originated was owned by Mr. WATERS, and was damaged about $800.

Our news from Kentucky is highly important. A telegram from Cairo states that an expedition left there on Thursday evening with the intention, as was supposed, of attacking Columbus. Heavy and continuous cannonading was heard in that direction yesterday, and the expedition was believed to be having a warm time.

GEORGE B. McCLELLAN is Commander-in-Chief of the Armies of the United States! This important step was taken, to-day, in Cabinet Council. The young General finds himself at the head of a force as numerous as that of Rome in her palmiest days, and not since equaled except by a monarch of the last century--LOUIS XIV.--until we descend to the wars of NAPOLEON. What changes have nine centuries introduced in the mode of warfare.

T.W. CONWAY and Rev. M.N. TAYLOR. The meeting was called to order by PELATIAH PERIT, Esq., who nominated as Chairman Hon. GEORGE BANCROFT. Upon taking the chair, Mr. BANCROFT said:

One of your correspondents has called attention to the propriety of abolishing in our army the distinction between volunteers and regulars. I see no good reason for maintaining this distinction. At the termination of the war there will be material enough out of which to form a standing army as large as would be required by the necessities of the country, or would receive the sanction of Congress.

GENTLEMEN: Your favor of the 7th is received to-day. Most gladly would I comply with the request of your Club if I could, but the professional engagement that has brought and will detain me here for some days, and others that I cannot without a breach of duty postpone, make it impossible.

We have no news whatever from the Naval Expedition in addition to what has already been published. It must be borne in mind that there are but two channels through which information concerning the fleet can come-- one is by returning vessels which would make Fortress Monroe their first stopping place, and the other is through rebel sources by the overland route. By the latter route we as yet hear nothing.

The Mayoralty Nominating Convention of the National Union Club met at Brown's Hotel, corner of Eighth-street and Astor-place, on Thursday evening, and organized by electing J.C. HAM, President, and O.S. HOLDEN, Secretary.

We are favored with a little excitement this week growing out of our local politics or rather out of the personal scramble for local offices. A "Union" Convention was held, composed of Democrats, Republicans, and all others who saw fit to unite. A ticket was nominated, which, however, failed to give satisfaction to the disappointed aspirants!

Paymasters are now busy in distributing two months' wages to the brigades of Gen. BANKS' Division. The time is very opportune, as the approaching cold weather notifies the soldiers that they are without many of the necessaries and luxurios of home.

The Germans, somewhat disappointed at many of the results of the late election, but gratified at others, are again in full activity, preparing for the approaching Mayoralty contest, in which they will exercise a most important control.

The telegraph brings an unsatisfactory report of an engagement which occurred on Thursday at Belmont, a spot on the right bank of the Mississippi, a short distance above Columbus. There was a rebel encampment at this place, where have been lodged some seven thousand men, under the command of Gen. CHEATEM, of Tennessee.

The remains of the late Col. BAKER arrived in Philadelphia on Thursday afternoon. When the train rolled into the depot, the City Guard were drawn up in line upon the platform. The Mayor of the city formally received the coffin containing the body, and then a squad of soldiers belonging to the California regiment received it in their turn, and bore it upon a bier to the hearse provided for it.

The new steamship Constitution, 3,500 tons register, is now on the great Balance Dock, for the purpose of being coppered.

Secretary CAMERON arrived in the City last evening from Springfield, whither he went to inspect the Arsenal. The leading object of his visit North has been to ascertain the exact number of arms at the command of the Government. He returns to Washington to-day.

The art of statesmanship consists in first knowing all the elements and condition of a nation, and then applying legislation or policy, so as to bring out the most beneficial results from those elements. Scandal-mon gers are busy with the motives which have taken THURLOW WEED, Archbishop HUGHES, and other distinguished gentlemen holding no official positions, abroad just at the present moment. Since I last wrote to you, everything has passed off quietly here until yesterday, although the secess have been in sight of us for the last four or five days, on the opposite side of the river.

The correspondent of the London Times, who was the historian of the war in the Crimea, and the reporter of the Indian campaign, has become to European ears the great chronicler of a mightier event the American Rebellion. As a popular historian, he is himself a public, if not a historic character.

FLOUR quiet. WHEAT dull, and c. lower, at 71 c. for No. 1; 66 c. for No. 2, in store. CORN quiet, at 22c. for Mixed, in store. OATS active. Receipts--7,300 bbls. Flour, 78,000 bushels Wheat, 59,000 bushels Corn. Shipments--7,800 bbls. Flour, 1,700 bushels Wheat, 23,000 bushels Corn. FREIGHTS--Firmer at 13c. on Corn, and 14c. on Wheat to Buffalo. Exchange unchanged.

MATHEW F. MAURY, whose arrest in Cleveland, Ohio, was noticed on Saturday, under the head of telegraphic news, arrived here yesterday morning in charge of a Government officer, and was at once sent to port Lafayette.
An erroneous but very general impression obtains that the current increase of the Public Debt of the United States is equal to at least a million dollars per day. But such is not the fact.

A flag of truce went to Norfolk to-day. Although the rebels maintained strict silence and declared they had no news, I am able to state that a dispatch was received in Norfolk that the Expedition had bombarded and taken two forts at the mouth of Port Royal.

After an absence, dating from 2 A.M. of the memorable 14th of August the hour at which our shattered army commenced its retreat from Springfield from this place, until yesterday, I find it but little changed externally, but much in other respects.

Our successes at "Wild Cat," Burkesville, West Liberty, Prestonburgh, Woodbury and Morgantown are encouraging, but they are by no means decisive. Our military lines are everywhere advancing, yet we may meet with future backsets and reverses in Kentucky, Missouri and Virginia.

The steamship City of Baltimore passed Cape Race, for Liverpool, at 6 P.M. of Thursday. She was boarded by the news-boat, and the latest dispatches and news from the United States placed in charge of the Purser.
Martin Waters vs. Josiah G. Clark. This was an action to recover rent for the use and occupation of the plaintiff's premises, No. 126 Charlton-street.

Notwithstanding the threatening aspect of European affairs, and the occupation of France in military preparations, the Emperor is prosecuting steadily and vigorously three of the greatest enterprises of modern times any one of which, successfully completed, will constitute an enduring monument of his statesmanship. These three undertakings are: the Submarine Telegraph between Europe and Africa, the cutting through of the Alps, and the opening of the Isthmus of Suez.

BUCKNER has left the south bank of the Green River and retired his forces towards Bowling Green, and STANTON has left Burksville, in Cumberland County, and returned into Tennessee with his marauding gang.

There is but one important change in theatrical announcements for to-night: this is at the Winter Garden, where Miss JULIA DALY who has recently achieved a very enviable success in England will make her rentree in the "Female American Cousin."

Passengers by the Old Point boat say that the Richmond Enquirer, of Friday, contains a dispatch from Charleston, dated Wednesday, simply announcing that the Federal troops had landed at two points, and were marching inland. It does not say at what points.

We have had stirring times here yesterday and today. Late on Saturday night, one of three messengers sent forward by Col. LEONARD SWETT, from St. Louis, succeeded in eluding the vigilance of the guards stationed to prevent access to Gen. FREMONT'S Headquarters, and served on the General personally the orders from Washington turning over the command of the Western Department to Maj.-Gen. DAVID HUNTER.

Gilder and John Freeborn, to the Third; Jacob Wilsey and Dennis Dowdican, to the Fourth; Henry C. Dubois, to the Fifth; Monroe B. Filley, to the Ninth, and Tycho E.C. Hartz, to the Twenty-ninth.
The condition of the contrabands in this State deserves some attention. Ever since the commencement of this war the moveable property of Missouri has been taking unto itself legs.
On what purports to be the official Drawings of the Delaware State Lotteries, under the management of JOHN A. MORRIS CO., I find my name is used as a Commissioner having superintended these drawings.

The full returns of the Maryland election show that but one rebel Senator and six Delegates are elected. The House stands 68 Union, and 6 rebels. The Seeate stands 13 Union, and 8 rebels. Seven of the latter are of the number who hold over, and six of them represent strong Union Counties.
COUNTRY. It seems that Gen. MIRAMON, the defeated leader of the reactionary party in Mexico, is taking active measures to aid the invasion and conquest of his country.

The immediate departure of the United States storeship Nightingale for the port of New-York gives us again an opportunity of transmitting letters to our friends at the North. It is quite unnecessary for me to assure you that it is eagerly embraced by all, as the facilities extended to us for communicating homeward have been of late extremely irregular and exceedingly limited.
The flag of truce to-day brings not a word of news concerning the Expedition.

We are still without direct and authentic tidings of the naval expedition. No dispatch vessel has yet been sent back, or none at least had arrived at the date of our latest advices. But we have instead a flood of rumors, all coming through rebel sources, and all agreeing on one point--that of reporting the substantial success of the expedition.

Gen. HUNTER arrived at Springfield last Monday, and took command of the army. There is no doubt that the army will accept their new commander cheerfully, many of the best officers in it even gladly; and that, in a few days, HUNTER' will have perfect control of the men, unless efforts should be made to give him trouble by persons whose fortunes are inseparably connected with those of the late Commanding General.

It is understood that the Commission authorized to report upon the Stevens Battery is now in session. The Stevens Battery is a shot-proof ship-of-war, of unusual power, size and weight of armament, designed for coast and harbor defence, upon which work was commenced in 1854, and stopped in 1856, when the vessel was more than half completed, for want of appropriations, after Mr. STEVENS had spent $200,000 upon it from his private purse.

The walls of the new theatre in this city are now up and ready for the skill of the carpenter. There are two clear months' interim before the usual annual festivities commence, and this space will doubtless be fully occupied in throwing on the roof of this temple of the drama, and in hasty temporary fitting up of the interior for the reception of the professors and admirers of the sock and buskin order.

We are still without news direct from the Great Expedition, though driblets continue to reach us through indirect channels enough to indicate that the success of the enterprise has been commensurate with the anticipations of the Government, and all that its friends could desire.
Mr. WM. R. TRACY and Capt. CROSS, of the Second East Tennessee Regiment, arrived at London, Ky., on the 3d inst.

Capt. DOWELL, of the Twentieth Indiana Regiment, which returned to Fortress Monroe from Hatteras, says that he found it almost impossible to remain longer on that narrow neck of land on account of the loss of camp equipage and stores. Although the men have suffered severe privations, the number on the sick-list is very small. All are now comfortably quartered near Fortress Monroe.

Having returned from the disastrous, yet glorious, expedition down the river at too late an hour to furnish you the full information for your paper of today, by the telegraph, I avail myself of one hour's leeway in which to write, to send by a train that is now making up to leave.

A large number of merchants, and others in favor of the passage of a National Bankrupt Law, met at the fifth-avenue Hotel last evening for the purpose of exchanging views on the subject, and adopting some measures by which the object in question could be attained. Mr. ROYAL PHELPS was called to the chair, and Mr. N. SULLIVAN acted as Secretary.

The ceremony of presenting the colors to the Ira Harris Cavalry, which had been postponed from Saturday, on account of the weather, took place yesterday afternoon, at Camp Scott, where the regiment is encamped, in the presence of some five hundred spectators, a considerable proportion of whom were ladies.

ALLEGED THEFT OF ARMY CLOTHING. Mr. MAHLON KINNEY, a detective in the employ of the Provost-Marshal at Washington, arrived in this City on Saturday in quest of a lot of army clothing which was sent to the Seventy-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., soon after the battle of Bull Run, but which they never received, and which, as now alleged, was taken by the sutler of the regiment, J.M. REYNOLDS

Will you permit me to say a word or two of English feeling about America? You read the English papers as well as I, but you know that the papers are not always an accurate reflection of public opinion. Allow me then to report the popular opinion as I find it expressed among the common people.

Business has led me more than once, this Autumn and the past Summer, into that part of Virginia through which the York River and its affluents flow. I went by way of Richmond, visiting West Point and Yorktown.

According to the announcement made in the TIMES, of Sunday, the last funeral honors were paid in this City, yesterday, to the remains of Col. BAKER, previous to their departure for San Francisco, where they are to be buried, near the grave of the late Senator BRODERICK.

The steamer Nova Scotian, from Liverpool, Thursday, the 31st. and Londondery the 1st, arrived here at 8 P.M. She brings five days later intelligence than that of the Persia.
Sales of four days, 27,000 bales; market dull at a decline of 1/8d. Since the departure of the Persia, but useful grades are firmer. Sales to speculators and exporters, 10,5000 bales.

The splendid success that has attended the naval expedition at Port Royal, and the tidings of which, still through rebel sources, we publish this morning, will carry the public mind to the climax of satisfaction. Stricken vs. Wakeman. This was a motion to discharge a levy, and set aside an execution, appeal having been taken from the judgment pursuant to which the execution was issued, proper security being given.

A meeting of citizens was held, last evening, at the Girard House, Mr. JAMES KENNEDY in the Chair, for the purpose of taking into consideration the propriety of nominating SAMUEL HOTALING for Mayor. After some discussion, Mr. HOTALING was unanimously nominated as candidate for the Mayoralty. There is no intelligence as yet from the great fleet. A flag of truce brought down to-day the crew of the French corvette Pronna, wrecked last Tuesday night near Ocracoke Inlet, N.C. She had no pilot and went ashore during heavy weather. The crew, 100 in number, were all saved and reached Norforlk via Charleston. They also bring the report of two rebel batteries having been taken by our troops, but nothing more.

It appears that the accounts of the wreck of the French war-steamer were not correctly stated yesterday. Her name was the Pomona. She was a sixgun steamer. Her crew, about one hundred in number, were not permitted to hold any communication with the people whatever, though the officers were allowed to mingle with them to some extent.

The success which has attended the arms of Gen. NELSON, in Eastern Kentucky, will class with the few really brilliant events of the war. A FATAL ACCIDENT IN BROOKLYN. A sad calamity occurred in the family of Dr. LUCIUS HYDE, who resides at the corner of Clark and Henry streets, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, in the sudden death of his interesting little neice, a child of seven years of age, who met her death from falling from the upper floor of the stable attached to the residence, in which she was playing with a young brother.

The arrest of Messrs. GWIN, BENHAM and BRENT, by order of Gen. SUMNER, is one of those incidents which is striking and startling, simply because all the facts of the present anomalous period in the national career are so necessarily. Of the immediate reasons which prompted the action of Gen. SUMNER, we are of course not advised. We took this fort, mounting twenty-one guns, after a four-hours' fight. It was nobly done. The Wabash, which led, was carried along the shore by the soundings as close as possible. The soundings were given regularly, as upon an ordinary occasion; signals were made continually without a single mistake, while the rain of fire from this ship (the Wabash) fell upon the fort with all the cold precision of target practice.

Advices received by the Government from Great Britain, represent that though much sourness of feeling is evident toward the United States, yet there was a manifest feelings averse to a war, and that the sentiment in favor of maintaining a strict neutrality was daily strengthening. BLAIR preached the sermon and presided. Rev. D. PATTERSON addressed the Pastor, and Rev. Mr. BRUSH the people. The exercises were very interesting and appropriate. The attendance was large. The work on the Mormon Temple, according to resolutions passed at the Conference last month, has been recommenced. Not that the foundations thereof have been exhumed they still lie "cached," buried, as they have since the Fall of '57. But other signs are visible. The rock is being hauied from the quarry and the masons are busy with the chisel and mallet.

Recruiting has improved, though not to a very great extent. The enlistments in, New-York for the regular army, during the week ending Oct. 23, amount to twelve men and twelve boys. Several applicants were rejected upon being examined by the Doctor.

This morning I paid a visit to Carondelet, and other points where the gun and tugboats are being constructed. The greatest activity prevails, and it is promised on the part of the builders that the fleet will be ready for service in three weeks.

An intellient deserter from the Tenth Georgia Regiment reached Newport News on the morning of Friday last and was taken to headquarters at Fortress Monroe, where upon being interrogated, he made known the location of a number of important rebel camps on the right bank of the James River.

BEEVES--The receipts of Beeves are comparatively light, but the demand is moderate, there being only a few heavy buyers up from New-York, while the Eastern men are not taking quite so many as usual. There is a falling off in quality as compared with last week. Prices are about the same, and taking quality into consideration, the market is to that extent more favorable for sellers.

United States Marshal MURRAY, who boarded the San Jacinto as she was coming into this port, with dispatches from Washington directing her to proceed to Boston harbor, and deposit the prisoners SLIDELL and MASON in Fort Warren, and who accompanied the captives on the voyage, returned yesterday morning and reports the following incidents of the voyage:

After a long and stormy passage from NewYork, which port she left on Monday night last, the steam sloop-of-war San Jacinto, having on board the famous prisoners of war, Messrs. MASON and SLIDELL, has arrived in our harbor.

The rebel Congress, according to a report forwarded from Baltimore, has authorized the seat of the insurgent government to be transferred to Nashville. The Congress, it is added, will presently adjourn to reassemble there. This legislation is the slow fulfillment of an old promise.

The amount taken was $1.50, and the prisoner was sentenced to the Penitentiary for six months and lined $100.

The train on the Platte Company Railroad was seized yesterday, on its arrival at Weston, by the guerrillas under GORDON, and the United States Express Company's freight appropriated. All the money in charge of the Express was saved. The mail matter was not taken. GORDON had previously robbed the stores of several union men of Weston.

PRICE, with 5,000 men, commanded the centre, and was near Montebello, Vernon County.

My last letter was dated at Pleasant Hill, Cass County. Col. ANTHONY'S command left that place on Thursday morning. With the WEEKLY TIMES of this morning we publish a SUPPLEMENT containing a FULL PAGE MAP OF THE NATIONAL LINES BEFORE WASHINGTON, exhibiting faithfully the defences of the National Capital, and positions of the several Divisions of the Grand Union Army. By the City of Baltimore we receive the text of the treaty recently arranged between Great Britain, France and Spain, in reference to Mexican affairs. The treaty does not determine the strength of the combined force to be employed for the purpose of obtaining satisfaction from the Mexican authorities, but the contracting parties engage that "the total shall be sufficient to seize and occupy the several fortresses and military positions" on the coast.

The 29th of November is an ever-memorable day in the history of liberal Poland. Thirty-one years ago on that day, at 7 P.M., the students of Warsaw gave the signal of revolt, and drove fifteen thousand Russians from the city. For about a year the war for independence raged with fury, until discord among the leaders extinguished Poland's political existence.

The Consul of the United States at Paris, Mr. BIGELOW, has received the following commucation:

DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, June 17, 1861. SIR: Every instruction which this Government has given to its representative abroad, since the recent change of Administration took place, has expressed our profound anxiety lest the disloyal citizens who are engaged in an attempt to overthrow the Union should obtain aid and assistance from foreign nations, either in the form of a recognition of their pretended sovereignty, or in some other and more qualified or guarded manner.

Farmerel al. vs. Bank of Fox Lake.--This action was brought to take up a draft given by the defendants in payment of a former one. On the trial below, the case resulted in favor of the plaintiffs, the defendants setting up as a defence first, that the check was obtained by fraud; and, secondly, that the giving of the check, in any event, was a payment.

he Union Defence Committee held a meeting yesterday, Hon. EDWARDS PIERREPONT in the Chair. The following members were present: Abiel A. Low, Wm. M. Evarts, Samuel Sloan, Wm. E. Dodge, Isaac Bell, Jr., Moses H. Grinnell, R.A. Witthaus, A.C. Richards, P.M. Wetmore, his Honor Mayor Wood, A.T. Stewart, Hon. R.T. Haws, Comptroller; R.H. McCurdy. The subjoined preamble and resolutions, submitted by Mr. SLOAN and seconded by Mr. GRINNELL, were unanimously adopted:

SIR: You receive the President's instructions for the discharge of your very important mission at a moment when a domestic crisis, long apprehended with deep solicitude, is actually reached. For the first time since the foundations of this Federal Republic were laid, with such pious care and consummate wisdom, an insurrection has developed itself, and assumed the organization and attitude of a separate political power.

The Nashville Banner of Nov. 20 is reliably informed that a few evenings ago the family of ANDREW JOHNSON felt so assured that he would make his appearance in Greenville at the head of a Lincoln force, that they made preparations for giving the distinguished traitor a splendid supper upon his arrival. What a delusion?
Messrs. FESSENDEN, of Maine, (Rep.,) and SUMNER, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) presented petitions for he emancipation of slaves under the war power.
The Sante Fe and Callon City mail arrived last night with dates to the 24th ult.
SIR: Your dispatch No. 11, dated on the-- day of June ult., has been received.
A letter, dated New-Orleans, Oct. 23, published in the Paris Constitutionnel, the organ of secession at Paris, says:

Capt. Wilkes, U.S.N., commanding San Jacinto: SIR: We desire to communicate to you, by this memorandum, the facts attending our arrest yesterday, on board the British mail steamer Trent, by your order, and our transfer to this ship.

Jane Smith vs. William Smith.--The plaintiff moved for allmony, pending the result of the action, which is for divorce. She alleges that she was married to the defendant in England, in 1829, and that she lived with him until 1848, when he abandoned her, and came to this country, and that since that date he had been guilty of adultery.

SIR: Your dispatch of May 22 (No. 5) has been received. Your safe arrival at your post of duty in this crisis, when our relations to foreign countries, and especially to France, have assumed a degree of interest and importance never known before since the Constitution was established, is a source of sincere satisfaction.
Henry Duffy, aged 18, born in New-York, was tried and convicted of highway robbery in the first degree, committed upon Cornelius Sullivan, on the 18th ult. Remanded for sentence.

Very little business of public importance was done by Congress yesterday, the day being principally devoted to eulogies of a dead Senator. In the Senate, petitions for the emancipation of slaves under the war power were presented by Messrs. FESSENDEN, of Maine, and SUMNER, of Massachusetts. A resolution for the expulsion of WALDO P. JOHNSON, member of the Senate, from Missouri, was presented by Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, and laid over.
The Richmond correspondent of the Nashville Union and American affords the following insight into the state of affairs at Richmond:

Although we have nothing as yet direct from the Stone squadron, the "sixteen vessels looking like whalers," descried by the Savannah journals, inside the bar, answer so nearly to the description, that they may fairly be put down as the moiety of the famous rat-hole fleet, the other score having gone to pay their attentions to Charleston har- bor.

Mr. GOODRICH, special bearer of important dispatches from our Ministers in Europe, arrived here this morning, and laid the documents before the Secretary of State. Mr. GOODRICH has been travelling for some time in Europe, and has had frequent interviews with the leading men throughout that country. The sympathy is almost universal with the Federal Government, and against the rebels.
Ocean Bank vs. American Exchange Bank et al.--Judgment for plaintiff on demurrer, with leave to defendant to answer on payment of costs.

Rev. Dr. STORRS last evening delivered a lecture at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, choosing for his subject the war in which the nation is now engaged, and the results likely to accrue from it to the people of this generation and their posterity. The lecturer having been introduced to a large and highly respectable audience, commenced his address with a general reference to history. He said that history is the biography of nations.
Steamships United Kingdom, (Br.,) Craig, Glasgow, F. McDonald; Karnak, Le Messurier, Nassau and Havana, E. Cunard.
SIR: You will have the second and third cutters of this ship fully manned and armed, and be, in all respects, prepared to board the steamer Trent, now hove to under our guns.

Mr. ROSCOE CONKLING, of New-York, (Rep.,) offered a resolution, which was adopted, requesting the Attorney-General to report his views as to the means of obtaining a retrocession of that part of Virginia formerly belonging to the District of Columbia.

Yesterday the last of the National gunboats, the Benton, Commodore FOOTE'S flagship, departed for Cairo, none too early, as to-day the river is full of ice Capt. W.D. PORTER left for the same destination on Monday with his gunboat.

The vessels to compose the second stone-fleet, which have been fitted at this port, and are to be used for the purpose of blockading the harbor of Charleston, in connection with ships fitting at Boston, NewLondon and New-York, took their departure this morning.

SIR: Mr. SANFORD, who was requested by me to look to our interests in Paris in the interval which might elapse between the withdrawal of Mr. FAULKNER and your own arrival, has transmitted to me (in his dispatch No. 2) an account of a very interesting conversation which he has recently held with Mr. THOUVENEL on our internal affairs.

The delay which we have experienced in receiving reliable reports of the recent National victory at Fort Pickens,--for the rebels themselves virtually acknowledge that this was the result of the engagement,--furnishes another proof of the positive necessity of organizing some more regular and frequent system of communication with the ports held by our forces on the Southern coast.
SIR: Your dispatch of June 28 has been received.
SIR: Nations, like individuals, have three prominent wants; first, freedom; secondly, prosperity; thirdly, friends.
Application of Frederica Neidlinger.--This case was stated in the TIMES a year or so since, under the above hearing.

A flag of truce went to Norfolk this morning, carrying thiry-two prisoners, discharged by the United States on parole. A rebel flag of truce met our boat and transferred thereto some ladies coming from Richmond.

The Sub-Committees appointed at the meetings of the German Republican Clubs, in all the Wards of this City, on Monday night last, assembled yesterday evening, in compliance with a published call, at the Steuben House, the Republican Headquarters on the Bowery.

SIR: In my dispatch by Commander TAYLOR, I confined myself to the reports of the movements of this ship and the facts connected with the capture of Messrs. MASON, SLIDELL, EUSTIS and MACFARLAND, as I intended to write you particularly relative to the reasons which induced my action in making these prisoners.

Our missionary, Rev. L.C. LOCKWOOD, writes from Fortress Monroe that, notwithstanding the contributions of clothing, , already made in the Free States, for the "contrabands," or freed men, at the Fort and the vicinity, he has scarcely "begun to supply the people with clothing and bedding."

The Twenty-fourth Massachusetts Regiment Col. THOMAS G. STEVENSON, which has been encamped at Readville for some time past, left Boston on Monday evening for this city, on its way to Annapolis, at which place it will be attached to Gen. BURNSIDE'S Division. The regiment numbers 1,020 men, all of whom are thoroughly uniformed and equipped, and armed with the Enfield rifle. On landing at Twentythird-street the men were marched down Broadway to the Park Barracks.

It is reported that several regi ments on the Potomac are putting up commodious cabins for holding meetings for intellectual improvement and discussion during the Winter evenings. We don't remember that history records any spectacle exactly like that --a huge army coolly resolving itself into a debating society in front of the enemy.

On Thanksgiving Day--the 28th ult.--a large party of the workmen engaged in constructing the Pacific Telegraph from the western borders to Salt Lake City, under the direction of Mr. CREIGHTON, arrived at Omaha on their return. Among them was SAMUEL P. STARR, of this city, who reached home on Thursday last.

With the WEEKLY TIMES, issued THIS MORNING, we furnish two large and admirably executed maps, drawn with sedulous regard to topographical accuracy, and representing that entire region of Virginia known as "The Old Dominion," stretching form Harper's Ferry to Norfolk, Hostile armies, numbering in the aggregate a half million of men, are encamped, or intrenched, or enwalled in these limits.

"The sentence of the court is," said the judge to a very hardened criminal, "that you be tied to the cart's tail, and whipped from one end of this town to the other."

SIR: I have to acknowledge the reception of your dispatches No. 10, dated the 21st May, and No. 11, dated on the 24th, with a copy of a letter from Mr. O. VANDENBURGH, and also a printed circular from the Department of the 20th of May, relating to purchases made here of articles contraband of war.

My DEAR SIR: The mails for New-York by one of the transports closed to-day, and I write to inform you that I send no correspondence. I have been three days ashore, and my time has been mainly occupied in finding decent accommodations. Being easily satisfied, I am happy to say that I am moderately comfortable.

The object of the expedition to the eastern shore of Virginia having been successfully accomplished, most of the troops sent thither by Gen. Dix have returned to Baltimore, leaving the Maryland and Delaware contingents, under the command of Gen. Lockwood, to winter on the Peninsula.

The intelligence which we publish to-day from Hilton Head warrants an outlook for coming business in South Carolina. Gen. SHERMAN has at length determined to occupy Beaufort; and at the Sailing of the latest steamer had dispatched an advance guard of one thousand men to hold that point. Addi

Mary Johnson vs. Susan Dixion. In this case the plaintiff hired a stall in the defendant's stable, at $2.50 per month, in which to keep a horse. Under the floor of the stall was an excavation, as appeared from the evidence, some ten feet deep, which was not known to the plaintiff at the time she rented it.
By the arrival of the Columbia we have later intelligence from Mexico.

In the Senate, the Committee on Military Affairs was instructed to inquire and report what reduction may be made in the expenses of the Army. An inquiry was also directed as to the possibility of furnishing greater facilities to soldiers for sending home their pay. Resolutions...

The Delta of the 24th thus alludes to the military display at New-Orleans on the 23d: "The general muster of the First Division of Louisiana Militia was the grandest military display ever made on this continent. Those who have witnessed the great reviews of the armies in Europe declare that the demonstration fully equaled some of the largest parades in the European capitals of the great military Powers.

Mr. McKNIGHT, of Pennsylvania, (Rep.,) from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, reported a resolution, which was adopted, that all memorials, resolutions and documents which may be presented for the recognition of the independence of Hayti and Liberia be referred to that Committee.

A small Spanish steamboat, N'tra Senora de Regla, has just been detained in this port for attempting to carry contraband matter. She put into Georgetown, S.C., under stress of weather, a few days ago, and was allowed by the vessels of the blockading squadron off that harbor, to enter and water. While there papers of an important nature were intrusted by prominent rebels to some of her officers.
A letter received yesterday afternoon, by Messrs. MAITLAND, PHELPS Co., dated St. Thomas, Nov. 23, states:

I have to-day the opportunity of announcing perhaps the most important news that has been sent to the North from South Carolina since the fall of Sumter. I am not sure that even the capture of Port Royal was more of an event than the orders now issued to Col. NOBLES, late of the New-York Seventyninth (Highlanders) Regiment.
Union men from Lafayette County report that 700 rebel recruits left Lexington yesterday morning to join Gen. PRICE'S army.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 14 bbls. Ashes 25,878 bbls: Flour, 591 bbls, and 40 sacks Corn Meal, 11,183 bushels Wheat, 30,175 bushels Corn, 3,351 bushels Rye, 500 bushels barley 47,357 bushels Oats, 1,503 packages Provisions, 927 bbls. The few words of intelligence which reach us from Port Pickens through a channel not entirely under rebel control, shows that Gen. BRAGG, in his recent interchange of countrsits with Col. BROWN, earne by the worse. His batteries were silenced, and he only escaped a more thorough drubbing because the National commander was yet lacking the necessary force to render a landing safe or practicable. The fort was, therefore, not breached
In the Legislature to-day, Mr. CARKSADON, of Hampshire, introduced a resolution to prohibit any person engaged in the rebellion from ever holding office in the State.
Mr. SUMNER presented a petition for the emancipation of the slaves, those of the rebels without compensation, and those of Union men to be paid for.

Carl Ehmer vs. Henry Bull. This was an action for the recovery of the net proceeds of merchandise consigned by the plaintiff a merchant residing in Hamburg, to the defendant, who does business in New-York.

Col. NOBLE, of the Seventy-ninth New-York Highlanders, has resigned his position, and has been appointed by Gen. SHERMAN to collect all the cotton possible about here, picked and unpicked, ginned and unginned, and store, preparatory to a shipment of it to Col. TOMPKINS, of your City.
The Kentucky Provisional Government have passed an act taxing brokers $25 per week, who charge a discount on Tennessee and Southern money.

The Columbia, from Havana, arrived yesterday, brought a mail from Fort Pickens. Letters from that post state that in the recent fight Col. HARVEY BROWN silenced the rebel guns, but had not force enough to land and drive off BRAGG'S army.
The weekly return of the banks for Saturday last was completed this morning. The changes for the week are:

The affair of the rebel steamer Nashville, that put in at Southampton for repairs, had caused the greatest excitement and was the subject of a diplomatic note from our Minister to Lord JOHN RUSSELL. Mr. ADAMS, on the part of our Government.

Saturday was devoted to the War elements, and though the streets in general were crowded to excess, the flags of Carondelet were deserted by the habitues. Counting-houses, offices, and warehouses were all closed. The telegraph wires brought nothing important from distant parts, and the day was devoted to the grand future of the country, and even yesterday there was very little else talked of than the grand review on Saturday.

A lady has just arrived in Brooklyn from Savannah, Ga., which place she left on the 24th of last month. The Brooklyn Times narrates her experiences, and adds, from a long acquaintance with the lady, we can assure our readers that her statements may be relied upon.
The steam transport City of New-York, Capt. NYE, from Port Royal on Dec. 6, arrived yesterday. The transport Atlantic, hence, arrived at Port Royal on the 2d inst.
The following is a list of the dead since leaving Annapolis out of this Division Gen. SHERMAN'S: THIRD NEW-HAMPSHIRE VOLUNTEERS. Amasa Nile, private, Co. G, Nov. 9, congestive fever.

The undersigned, her Majesty's Principal Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, has had the honor to receive the note, of the 23d instant, of Mr. ADAMS, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States.

Notwithstanding numberless newspaper reports to the contrary, it is evident no forward movement of importance will take place from here for a couple of weeks, at least. The Union commanders are not ready to commence successful offensive movements and of magnitude sufficient to gain, should they be successful, any really important result.
A late Scottish paper, the Edinburgh Daily Review, contains a letter, apparently genuine, from Secessia, the revelations of which may be important in the present crisis.

Important reconnoissances were yesterday made along our lines of the Potomac, to ascertain the positions and strength of the rebels. One, made in a balloon by Prof. LA MOUNTAIN, establishes the facts that the rebel force at Fairfax Courthouse is very light; that between that point and Vienna there is an increase of strength, and that all along the line very considerable additions have been made to the scouts of cavalry and infantry.

The Herald prints an advertisement of THE TRIBUNE copied from our columns, for which it pretends that we pay it half-price. The pretence is utterly false; we never employed, nor authorized, nor in any manner solicited, the insertion of our advertisement by the Herald, any more than we ever entreated its forbearance, or did any other of a thousand discreditable acts which that mendacious journal has from time to time attributed to us.

The steamship Columbia arrived at this port yesterday, from Havana, which port she left on the 6th inst. Nothing of importance had occurred at Havana since the date of previous advices. Two rebel vessels had arrived, having run the blockade, with cotton and naval stores. Among the passengers by the Columbia is Mr.CHARLES ANDERSON, brother of Gen. ANDERSON, who recently succeeded in escaping from the rebels in Texas.

The impression is forcing itself into a conviction that neither Gen. McCLELLAN nor any other General will convert the mass of men under arms about here into a well-disciplined army according to the European standard or the notions of the most easily satisfied military critics.

The Lord Mayor, towards the close of the business of the day, said: I should be glad if the gentlemen connected with the Press would be good enough to rectify a statement which appears in a communication from Southampton in the Times of this morning, relative to an application to the magistrates there yesterday.
The exhibition and sale for the advancement of this truly merciful cause, is now progressing at Dodworth's Rooms, on Broadway, just above Eighth-street.

At last the destination of the Federal fleet is known. On the 7th of the present month it entered Port Royal harbor, in South Carolina, engaged the forts, and, after a fight which lasted four hour, forced the enemy to abandon them. The next day the troop's, to the number of 15,000, were landed at Beaufort' which, we are told, they found totally destroyed, together with the neighboring plantations.

The accident which occurred on the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad near Gray's Ferry Bridge, on Friday night, resulted in the destruction of several cars, injury to locomotives, and some narrow escapes.

Mr. BLAIR, of Missouri, (Rep.,) rising to a question of privilege, caused to be road the following extract as further explanatory of the remarks which he made yesterday on Mr. LOVEJOY'S resolution, having in view the revocation of a part of Gen. HALLECK'S general order relative to fugitive slaves. The resolution, it has already been stated, was laid on the table.
The screw-steamship Hansa, Capt. VON SANTEN from Bremen, calling at Southampton on the 27th ult., and remaining at that port until the following day, arrived here yesterday morning.
Public curiosity still remains unsatisfied as to the future of this ship, or the intention of the British Government in relation to the question.
Mr. R. N ULL, of Illinois, (Rep.,) presented a petition to repeal the law which prevents Jewish divines officiating as chaplains in the army.

Letters from Gonaives to November 13, state that an insurrection there against the Government had been suppressed. All other parts of the Island are quiet. An unusually large portion of the coffee crop was going to Europe. From St. Domingo we learn that the inhabitants remained quiet under the Spanish rule.

At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen yesterday, the usual reference was had of numerous petitions and resolutions. The Engineers of the steam fire engines, petitioned for the establishment of depot for wood for their use, in case of fires in the lower part of the City, and stating that at the late fire in Murray-street, they had to break up packing-boxes to keep steam up. The Louisville Journal has rendered the Union cause most noble service by sustaining the Administration in its efforts to suppress rebellion. It seems likely now to do it serious injury by a captions and utterly unreasonable denunciation of the President, on account of what he does not say in his Message concerning Slavery.

The news of the aggression upon the Royal Mail Company's steamer Trent by the United States ship-of-war San Jacinto produced an indescribable effect in the city this morning. It transpired about the middle of the day, up to which time the English funds and shown great buoyancy, and, after a few moments, during which it was deemed almost incredible the result on the funds was a fall of 1 per cent.

Col. MORGAN, in command of the troops at Weston, has issued a proclamation to the citizens of Platte County, in which he calls upon them to aid in protecting the railroad, and calls on all absentees to return, assuring them protection to persons and property, if loyal. No negroes will be allowed within the camp, or to leave the State without a pass. All marauding parties and armed men will be shot.

GOVERNMENT DISPATCHES FROM FORT PICKENS. The Government has received dispatches from Fort Pickens, stating that Gen. BROWN had silenced Fort McRae, destroyed the Navy-yard, and burned the town of Warrenton, and that the bombardment was a complete success. Our loss in the engagement was one man killed and five wounded.
GEN. PRENTISS' command was to move from Platte City to Richfield on the 11th.

In this Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, Geo. R. Cowee, 28 years of age, native of Troy, was tried for stealing goods valued at $200, from Robbins Royce Hard, in whose employ he served as clerk.' The case occupied the entire day, and resulted in a verdict of acquittal.

In the Senate, after the usual presentation of petitions and memorials, Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, offered a resolution, which was agreed to, that the Naval Committee be instructed to inquire into the expediency of appointing pupils in the Naval Academy, according to merit. A bill, introduced by Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, authorizing the President to fill up the corps of Cadets at West Point, was referred to the Military Committee.
The following vessels, comprising a portion of the second Rat-Hole Expedition, are now at anchor in the roads, and awaiting a fair wind to sail South:

By virtue of a written order from Superintendent KENNEDY, Sergeants WILSON and WADE, of the Eighth Precinct Police, made a descent upon a gambling house, on Wednesday night. The establishment is situated on the northeast corner of Spring and Mercer streets, and was kept by a man named WILLIAM ALLEN, but more generally known by the name of "Butt Allen."

The Nineteenth Massachuseets, of Gen. STONE'S Division, have been sent to Muddy Branch to picket the Potomac, in lieu of Gen. BANKS' Division. Their Post-office is Darnestown. Gen. STONE'S command will thus keep river guard from near the Great Falls to Nolan's Ferry, above the mouth of the Monocacy.

We have at last got the truth about the affair which opened at Fort Pickens three weeks ago to-day, concerning which the rebels in the meantime, have so awfully bamboozled us.

It will be remembered that, in the early part of last April, Fort Pickens was suddenly discovered to be in imminent danger of capture at the hands of BRAXTON BRAGG and his new army of Confederate warriors.

By the screw-steamer Hansa, which arrived here yesterday morning, we have the first report of British opinion on the MASON and SLIDELL capture. The first news of the affair received in England was by the British West India mail steamer La Plata; and the account seems to have been tolerably fair, excepting a few exaggerated details thrown in for effect.

The reports yesterday that three National brigades had crossed to the south side of the Green River is authoritatively denied.

By way of Washington, we have a important information from Tybee Island and vicinity which has not been furnished by any direct arrival at this port. On the 5th inst., before daylight, Commander RODGERS left Tybee Roads with three gunboats, and proceeded to Warsaw Island, the fort upon which was found to be entirely deserted.

The brig Thomas W. Rowland, Capt. ROWLAND, from Rio Janeiro vid St. Thomas, Nov. 27, arrived at this port on Thursday night.

At anchor off Pass a POntre, recovering from the effect of our late affair with HOLLINS at the head of the passes, the United States steamer Mississippi found us on the evening of the 18th, at 6 P.M. At 8 o'clock we were under weigh, with a full head of steam, bound for Fort Pickens.

The Board of City Canvassers, yesterday, completed their labors, with the exception of making some minor corrections and formally announcing the result. OPDYKE's majority over GUNTHER, according to the official figures, is 613, and over WOOD, 1,213.

The German Republican Central Committee met last evening at its headquarters, the Steubon House, the president, Mr. ANDREAS WILLMANN, in the Chair, and Messrs. H. RICHARD and STEINHEIMER, the regular Secretaries, officiating.

The Bowling Green Courier publishes what purports to be a message from GEORGE W. JOHNSON, who signs himself "Provisional Governor," addressed to "Mr. President and Gentlemon of the Legislative Council." The so-called "Provisional Council" has been organized as follows:
The Frankfort (Ky.) Gazette has a dispatch, which says that when the stage left Somerset, at 11 o'clock, on Wednesday, there had been no fighting.

The Commercial says; "We had, yesterday, a very interesting interview with two Union refugees from Louisiana, who succeeded in making their way from New-Orleans to Nashville, through the rebel lines, to the Ohio River. They confirm the report of the utter stugnation of business in New-Orleans, and constant apprehensions of attack, and scarcity of all the necessaries of life. All men between the ages of eighteen and forty five were being impressed into service.

A flag of truce left here this morning for Norfolk, in charge of Capt. MILWARD, with a large quantity of letters and express matter for the South. The boat returned with passengers from Richmond, who are British subjects, and two from Norfolk.
A letter from Somerset, dated the, 7th inst., confirms the capture by the rebels of Major HELVETI and Capt. PRINCE.

We copied yesterday from the Halifox Reporter an extravagant statement of an insult said to have been offered to the British flag, in the case of the British gunboat Landrail. It was stated that she was stopped by an American corvette firing a shot across her bows.

In this Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, Samuel Murray, a colored seaman, 31 years of age, born in Pennsylvania, was tried and convicted of an assault with intent to kill his paramour, Julia Wilson, of No. 58 Leonard-street. State Prison 5 years.

We received this note from the telegraphic operator here, at 12 o'clock to-day. We give the intelligence for what it is worth, having no other means of verifying its accuracy.?Eds. New-Orleans Picayune.

Our "cold season" has broken up, and for the past five days we have had mild, genial weather, accompanied by Spring-like showers. To-day fires are unnecessary. The ice has gone out of the, river, and a few vessels are moving for short voyages.
Nothing in public has been done in Congress to-day.

The Examiner of this morning says that Congress, while in session, passed a bill admitting Kentucky into the Southern Confederacy. The admission is complete, as Commissioners were appointed at Russellville, and empowered to act in behalf of Kentucky.

We publish this morning most important news from Charleston, coupled with rumors of the most startling character. Nearly the whole of that pestilent city has been destroyed by an incendiary fire, the torch being applied by a negro a free negro, the dispatches state.

One cry impulsively leaped to the lips of Englishmen as the news was told of the search of the Trent a cry for the vindication of the "honor of the British flag." The act, seen through the distorted medium of the partisan reports first carried over, seemed to them a wanton wound to English honor.

The difficulty with regard to the supply of cotton, to meet the probability of a future American deficiency, seems likely to arise rather from the multitude than from the scarcity of new sources. From every quarter of the globe we have evidences of capability for the growth of this staple; and, as each country asserts its own claims to be superior to those of its competitors, attention is distracted...

Yesterday, about 10 o'clock A.M., an Exchange Broker, named BERNARD LEVY, one of the firm of L. B. LEVY SON, of No. 146 Canal-street, under the Citizens' Bank, was found in his own office with his throat cut in a most horrible manner. Life was extinct when he was discovered, though the body was still warm.

The British Gov ernment has pointed out numberless evidences of its amicable feeling toward this country, as an offset to as many outrages it has suffered at our hands. Its catalogue will receive an appropriate addition by inserting the case of the Nashville.

The first report of the Commissioner appointed by the Anglo-Indian Government to inquire into the cotton-growing capacity of the great Oriental Peninsula, and the progress of cotton cultivation therein, has been recently published. It is a most able and valuable document; and though it relates only to the region...

By a gentleman who left Sedalia yesterday, we learn that PRICE had moved from Osccola to a point five miles distant, with a portion of his force, and made that place his headquarters. RAINS remained at Osceola, and was in command of that place. On Monday last a train of fifty wagons passed from Lexington, between Warrensburgh and Sedalia, to PRICE'S army. They were laden with supplies, and encountered no molestation.

Feverish excitement about the nigger pervades the popular mind just now. What shall be done with the nigger? What can be done? What ought to be done? Or, shall anything be done? Can we, or can we not, somehow, keep the nigger from distracting and dividing the Union sentiment and cause?
The following communication is from Capt. T. L. BRIGGS, of the brig Joseph Park, recently captured by the privateer Sumter:

MAKING CHEESE. The process of making cheese in Hermiker County, New-York, is admirable for its simplicity and dispatch, as compared with that practiced in Cheshire and other districts in England. The night's milk is placed in the cheese-vat, and kept as cool as possible. After the morning's milk is added, the whole is raised to the proper temperature either by heating...

Mr. KNOEDLER, succesor to GOUPIL CO., announces that he has received two landscapes by CASILEAR, and two grape pieees by G. H. HALL, which will be added to the fine collection now to be seen at his charming gallery, corner of Ninth-street.

The desk of the Secretary of the Treasury is covered with applications from patriots who desire to serve the country as commercial agents at Southern ports. As but one port it now open, they are permitted to wait.
Outside reports say that the fire at Charleston originated in the mill on Broad-street; also that the Mills House and the Roman Catholic Cathedral were destroyed.

A telegraphic dispatch to the Norfolk Day Book of this date, received by a flag of truce which was sent from here to-day, announces the burning of Charleston. Whether it was caused by the whites or blacks I am unable as yet to say.

There is evidently much confusion of ideas in Congress, and in the country, on the subjects of confiscation and emancipation. The power to confiscate the property of rebels as a punishment of treason, and the power to destroy their property as a means of putting down rebellion and reducing them to obedience to the laws, are wholly different in kind, and stand on different bases.

To-morrow morning the Fourth and Fifth Regiments of the brigade will arrive in this City from their quarters at Fort Schuyler, and proceed via the New-Jersey Railroad to Washington, and thence immediately to encamp beside the other regiments of the organization in the division of Gen. SUMNER, in Virginia.
The firing at Poolesville on Tuesday proves to have been nothing but artillery practice by Gen. STONE'S batteries.

It must be conceded to the English newspaper Press, that the territorial acquisitions of Gen. SHERMAN are not important as a question of acres; but there is no doubt the capture of Port Royal has exerted a prodigious moral effect within the bounds of rebeldom, and done more than seemed possible...

During the past four days, the heaviest rainstorm that has been experienced for years has prevailed in California, causing severe freshets in the valleys, and great destruction of property.

COTTON--Sales, yesterday and to-day, 18,000 bales, including 7,000 to speculators and exporters. The market is firmer, but quotations are unchanged.

At the close, there was a rally of about per cent.
