Great excitement was created in Washington yesterday on the reception of the news from Europe, which was forwarded in advance of its publication in this City. It was discussed universally in the streets and hotels, and the universal sentiment, according to our correspondent, appeared to be one of defiance. There was a disposition, however, to doubt the reliability of the news.

The export of saltpetre and warlike stores was formally prohibited. It was stated that one ship with a cargo of saltpetre for America has been stopped, and that the relanding of warlike stores, already shipped, had been required.

All excitement and confusion here. The military wagons have been passing for the last two hours. Our troops are on the road, and will be here before to-day. No aid has reached us, although we hear they are on the road. Nobody can tell where they are. From what I can learn, there will be no resistance made at Fishing Creek.

The Brokers' Circular reports: "The sales of Cotton, for the week, foot up 22,000 bales. The market is downward, with a decline of d., the market closing dull and inactive at the decline. The sales to speculators were 4,500 bales, and to exporters, 4,250 bales. The sales on Friday were restricted to 1,500 bales, the market closing with a downward tendency at the following quotations:

--To remind us of certain dues which fall about Christmas time, JAMES MILLER publishes in royal quarto form a sumptuous volume--Lyra Germanica--a selection of hymns from Chevalier BUNSEN'S comprehensive collection, Versuch eines Allgemeinen Gesang and Gebetbuchs, translated from the original by CATHARINE WINKWORTH. The German language, in its wealth of sacred poetry, is rivaled by no other.
The Old Point boat brings the report of the discovery and prompt suppression by the military authorities of a negro insurrection at Charleston.

--We but pay the Atlantic for January a deserved compliment when we rank it as the best number that has appeared in the history of the magazine. It is always the custom of magazine proprietors to make the initial number of the year an extraordinarily good one.

Dispatches from California, published yesterday, gave an account of a great flood which has occurred in that State, owing to a heavy rain storm. The City of Sacramento was almost submerged, the water in the houses standing from two to twelve feet deep. The losses in that city alone will probably amount to half a million of dollars. At last accounts the weather had become more settled, and the waters were slowly subsiding.
The Thirty-fifth Anniversary of the New-York City Tract Society, (and the twenty-ninth of the female branch,) was held last evening at the Church of Rev. Dr. ADAMS, on Madison-square.

The Democrat learns from a gentlemen just from Lexington that Gen. RAINS and SHEIN, with 6,000 rebels were in possession of that town on Friday last, and that another large body of troops were expected to reach there yesterday.

The map mania continues without showing any visible signs of abatement. Perhaps we should have said map passion, as it is scarcely fair to characterize as disease that which is only a natural demand, stimulated by the exciting events of the day. The term was as badly chosen as though we should say "war-fever," when alluding to the present natural throbbing of the patriotic pulse of our people.

The Enquirer's Louisville correspondent, under date of the 14th, says that Gen. JOHNSON, with 15,000 Federal troops, is on the northern bank of Green River, and Gen. ROUSSUAU seven miles distant, preparing to join him. Another brigade, under ...

The reports that have thus far reached us concerning the escape of the privateer Sumter from the United States steamer Iroquois, involved the very severest censure of Capt. PALMER, whose failure to seize her certainly stands in need of explanation. Simple justice, however, demands that he should no be condemned unheard.

It is not to be denied that, during the past six months, many of Mr. SEWARD'S most devoted friends and warmest admirers have felt that there was something lacking in his public career. With, perhaps, a too ready distrust, they have listened to the little expressions circulating in society, quoted often incorrectly from his conversation, which indicated a want of proper appreciation of the dangers before the country.

THE NEWS FROM EUROPE. The dispatches relative to the action of the British Government, which will appear in the New-York journals of Monday, were received by the Government this afternoon. Notwithstanding the belligerent attitude assumed, there is no disposition on the part of any member ofthe Cabinetto alter the plans or policy of the Government assumed in the arrest of MASON and SLIDELL.
Our dispatches concerning the Charleston conflagration, first reported here on Saturday, are as yet very meagre and confused. We gather them together, and give them as connectedly as possible.

The ship Lady Franklin, from London, for NewYork, put into Plymouth on the 3d inst., and took fire the same night. She was scuttled. There were Southerners among the crew, who were suspected of firing her.

The bark Mary C. Kimball, brig Remmington, and schooners Davis, Hopkins, Stampede and Highlander, vessels belonging to Gen. BUNRSIDE'S Expedition, left this port last evening for Annapolis. They will be supplied at that place with ordnance, ammunition and provisions, and will proceed on their mission as soon as the other vessels of the fleet are put in a condition to join them.

The Richmond Examiner, of Nov. 30, learns that the Government has determined not to give arms to volunteers for twelve months, as long as it has troops offered for the war to a number greater than can now be armed. Where volunteers are enlisted for the war the Government will supply them with arms in proportion to the several States tendering such volunteers.
CORONERS' INQUESTS.--At 6 o'clock yesterday morning, the body of MATTHEW KING, a native of Ireland, 40 years of age, was found on the sidewalk in First-avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth streets.

It is without a single rising of vindictive joy that a rightminded man will learn the tragic tidings of what has befallen Charleston. At the same time, if the catastrophe be one of the outworkings of the train of consequences which the inhabitants of that rebellious city instituted in spurning the beneficent protection of the Government of their fathers,--what can be said other than that it is just?
Scouts bring in the news of a proposed meetting of rebel recruiting officers and a formation of arebel camp in the Timbers.

The seizure of MASON and SLIDELL monopolizes the columns of the Press, which continues to denounce the act as an insult in the strongest terms. Nearly all the London weekly papers treat the question in the same energetic spirit as the daily papers. Agitation increases.
The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool 4th, via Queenstown 5th, passed Cape Race at 11 o'clock yesterday (Sunday) morning, and was boarded by the news yacht of the Associated Press.

The Convention has disposed of the boundary question. They include unconditionally an addition to the thirty-nine counties included by the ordinance of the August Convention, viz: the Counties of Pocahontas, Greenbrier, Monroe, Merces, and ...

The sales of Cotton on Monday and Tuesday reached 7,000 bales. The market opened at a recovery of d. under the advices per Persia, but it was not sustained, and it closed unsettled, with a downward tendency.
The French journals look at the Trent affair in the interest of England.

The dispatches that reach us concerning the great Charleston conflagration, are very unsatisfactory; and as the fire was still raging, at the latest advices we have yet got up to Thursday, midnight, through the steamer from Port Royal, it is useless to attempt to define its limits or mark out its direction.
The steamship Champion, WILSON, from Aspinwall, Dec. 7, with mails, passengers and specie from California, arrived last night.
The Speaker presented the memorial of the Legislative Assembly of Colorado asking for the establishment of a branch Mint in that Territory. Referred to the Committee of Ways and Means.

SIR: The subject of a more effective and rapid mode of communication between Washington and New-York is becoming so prominent before Congress and the people, and the great necessity for such an improvement is being felt to such an extent by the Government, and more particularly by that department over which you preside, that I will venture to submit for your consideration some views which I have long entertained in relation to the matter.

Before Justice White. J. Barlklie vs. Mitchell Pott, and Otis D. Swan, their Assignee. It appeared, on the hearing of this case, that the defendants, Mitchell Pott, of this City, were the factors and commission agents of the plaintiffs, who are linen manufacturers in Larne, Ireland.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 13 bbls. Ashes, 31,025 bbls. Flour, 643 bbls. and 205 bags Corn Meal, 1,983 bushels Wheat, 6,614 bushels Corn, 2,434 bushels Rye, 543 bushels Barley, 9,868 bushels Oats, 334 bushels Malt, 3,815 packages Provisions, 2,380 bbls. Whisky.

Forty of Gen. PRENTISS' command returned here last night, most of them sick with the measles. They report that the Nationals had several skirmishes with the rebels on their march, killing a few of them.
The Sanitary Commission has just issued a circular, stating the general objects and results of its organization, and appealing for additional contributions for their prosecution.

ASPINWALL, Saturday, Dec. 7 12 M. The victory of Gen. MITRE, of Buenos Ayres, over URQUIZA, of the Argentine Confederation, was complete. MITRE occupies Rosario. He took 2,500 prisoners, who have joined his forces; 28 cannon, 5,000 horses, The dates from Mendoza are to Nov. 2. From Chili the dates are to Nov, 18. The Republic was tranquil. Business improving.
The Commissioners of Excise vs. Purdy et al Motions granted with $10 costs, to be included in one order only.

We shall have the Europa's mails to-morrow, and then, perhaps, we can test a little more accurately the precise import and value of the news which yesterday threw Wallstreet into such a paroxysm of alarm, and created so much excitement in the City at large.
Several citizens of Arkansas have reached here during the past week, and onlisted in the Arkansas company, under Capt. WABE, late member of the Legistature from that State.

The United States steamer transport Constitution, Capt. A.T. FLETCHER, arrived at Fortress Monroe on Sunday afternoon, where she called for orders, on her return from Ship Island, Mississippi Sound, having safely landed at the latter...
David Colden Murray vs.; Cornelius Vanderbilt This case has been on several occasions stated in the TIMES.

A dispatch from Phillippa says that our force at the battle of Alleghaney Camp numbered one thousand eight hundred. They came in sight of the enemy, drawn up in line of battle in front of their intrenchments, charged upon them, and drove them back. A hot fire was kept up during the afternoon on both sides, and several brilliant charges were made by our men.

Before Justice Leouard. The Excise Commissioners vs. R.H. Purdy and 65 others. The Liquor Dealers' Association, by their counsel, moved to dismiss the complaints in these cases, on the ground that they had been commenced by the opposing counsel without the authority of the Board. No notice had been given to the Board of Excise, nor proofs offered to show the violation charged.
Mr. KING, of New-York, (Rep.,) presented a petition from the New-York Chamber of Commerce, asking that the New-York Assay Office have the privege of coining. Referred to the Finance Committee.

The latest news from England has occasioned no marked excitement among public men, the indignation of the British Press having been anticipated.

Our new Military Department has scarcely got into working order. Major-Gen. DAVID HUNTER arrived here last Monday, and assumed command next day. At present the post does not present a very lively appearance, there being but a small body of troops stationed there.

The steamship Champion, from Aspinwall, with specie from California to the amount of $979,000, arrived here yesterday. She reports that when in lat. 31 30, Ion. 76 , she was chased for an hour by a propeller, supposed to be a privateer, which finally hoisted the English, colors; but the propeller did not succeed in overtaking the treasureship.

The recent caucuses of Republican members of Congress, and the result of their deliberations, have a far more important bearing upon public affairs than appears from the very incomplete reports published in relation thereto.

In the Senate, a number of petitions tonching upon the Slavery question were presented. Mr, TEN EYCK, of New-York, offered a resolution against radicalism in any sense, which was laid over. The Committee on Military Affairs, on motion of Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, was in structed to inquire into the expediency of providing a uniform manner in which to deal with the slaves of rebels.

U.S. steamer Dacotah, Commander J.P. McKinstry from Hong Kong, via St. Thomas 3d inst. Has had strong northerly gales since leaving St. Thomas. 14th inst., at 8 A.M., lat. 32.42, lon. 76.1, spoke steamer John Hart, hence for Key West, 3ds. out.

The steamship Europa did not reach Boston until late last evening, and her mails were not forwarded by the express train. They will reach this City this morning. The British sloop-of-war Rinaldo, which was in Boston harbor, started half an hour after the Europa's arrival, to deliver a message to the British Admiral at Bermuda, and special messengers from the Queen and from Mr. ADAMS, our Minister, started for Washington by the Shore Line road.

The U.S. steamship Connecticut, Commander MAXWELL WOODHULL, from Galveston, Nov. 29; Southwest Pass, Dec. 1; Ship Island, Dec. 2; Mobile Bar and Fort Pickens, Dec. 3; Key West, Dec. 10; Savannah, Dec. 12, and Fortress Monroe, Dec. 16, arrived at this port yesterday. The crews of the blockading squadrons and the troops are all in good health. Left at Key West the U.S. steamer Richmond, coaling and repairing.
That WILLIAM WALSH, by the greatest number of votes, was duly elected as Alderman of the Second Aldermanic District.
A bill was received from the House to authorize the raising of a volunteer force for the defence of Kentucky.

-We rehearsed, a few days since, certain circumstances of the Canal-street homicide, which in our judgment utterly negatived the idea that the deceased committed suicide. The Coroner's jury returned a verdict of suicide, and the Police apparently concurred in its justice. The fact that no robbery appeared to have been committed, was held to constitute a very strong pesumption against the idea that he had been murdered.
A sheet of paper, containing the following statement, was found tacked to a tree at Key West. It was copied by one of the officers of the Connecticut:
That JAMES WOODS, by the greatest number of votes, was duly elected as School Commissioner for the First Ward.

The midnight line from New-York last night brought on a number of companies attached to Gen. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER'S Brigade. While at the Treaton depot a number of the privates got out to fil their canteens. In the meantime the train started, and there was a rush to get on-board the cars again.

A very interesting and successful reconnoissance was made on the 11th inst., at Ossabaw Sound, by a squadron of gunboats, consisting of the Ottawa, Seneca, Pembina and Henry Andrew, under the command of Capt. C.R.P. RODGERS, of the Wabash.

In addition to the large map of Ship Island and its surroundings, which we published yesterday, we give herewith another diagram, exhibiting the depth of water in the vicinity of the Island, and between the Island and the mainland showing what an admirable water-way for inland navigation the rebels here possessed, and how admirably we close it up by the possession of this narrow strip of land.

An article has recently appeared in a daily paper of this City, extracted from the San Francisco Bulletin, which states that the American merchants in Japan have requested the recall of Mr. TOWNSEND HARRIS, our Minister resident in that country, on the ground that he unnecessarily restrains American citizens from visiting Yeddo, the capital city of the Empire.

At the regular meeting of the Board of Supervisors, yesterday, Mr. BLUNT offered a resolution directing the Committee on Printing, , to audit the bills of all the newspapers now before them, at the rate of ten cents per line for the first insertion, and five cents for every other insertion.

During the past year very extensive improvements have been completed in Central Park. Considering the fact that the number of laborers employed has been much less, and the expenses only about one-half those of last year, it is believed that the management has been good, and the money judiciously expended.

As the details of the conflagration at Charleston begin to reach us, we are able to form some idea of how complete is the ruin that has fallen on that rebellious city. Five hundred and seventy-six buildings, representing a property of seven million dollars, are reported as having been destroyed on Wednesday alone.

The Herald wants to know what motive it can possibly have for stirring up public passion and plunging this country into war with England. It is not for us to judge its motives, it is sufficient to point out the inevitable consequences of its conduct. But the Herald has over and over again boasted that it prospered most in the midst of public calamities.

Mr. BINGHAM, of Ohio, (Rep.,) from the Judiciary Committee, reported back the Joint resolution directing and requiring the Provost Court at Alexandria, Virginia, to retain and safely keep in its custody any property taken as that of persons engaged in on aiding the rebellion against the United States, until the further action of Congress touching the same. The resolution was passed.

By the Constitution, which touched at Havana en route to Boston, we receive our files of Havana papers and highly important corrrespondence from Mexico. The news from Havana is destitute of importance. From Mexico we learn that the ulti

The news brought by the Connecticut from Tybee Island and Port Royal is highly interesting, but from prudential reasons is withheld from publication at the present time. It is confidently asserted that Savannah and Charleston (what little remains of it) will soon be in possession of the Union forces.

The London Times regrets that the Administration of Mr. LINCOLN will hardly be able to release itself sufficiently from popular influences to take a manly and proper course in regard to the Trent. There is too much reason to believe that a remark of the same kind applies to the position assumed by the British Government.

The Connecticut combines with her capacity as a transport ship strength and staunchness enough to make her quite formidable as a vessel of war. She is pierced for six guns, and is, therefore, fully able to relieve the monotony of her peaceful carrying avocation with occasional dashes after prizes, or a brush now and then with a rebel privateer.

There are signs in what we hear from the rebellious States that they are beginning to realize their situation in some measure, and that, as a consequence, alarm is seizing them. It is not surprising that it should be so. Let us reverse the situation of things, in our imaginations, and strive to picture to ourselves how such prospects would seem to us.

The spacious new structure in the "domestic Gothic" style of architecture, built upon the ground once known as "Potter's Field," has been taken possession of by its intended occupants before the finishing touches have been made, for the reason that the two houses recently serving as a home on West Thirty-ninth-street became perfectly inadequate to the growing demand of growing children, for space wherein to live, and move, and play.

The Washington correspondent of the Tribune says that "Surgeon-Gen. FINLAY is working hard to defeat bill reorganizing the Medical Department of the army. He has presented a report against it to the Secretary of War."

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 75 bbls, Ashes, 14,095 bbls. Flour, 54 bbls, and 1,531 bags Corn Meal, 2,930 bushels Wheat, 2,943 bushels Corn, 728 bushels Rye, 150 bushels Barley, 5,009 bushels Oats. 2.525 bushels Malt, 5.968 packages Provisions, 1,309 bbls. Whisky.
We have dates from Bogota by the monthly British steamer, which reached Aspinwall last evening from Cartagena, to the 17th November.
The Santa Fe and Canin City mail, with dates to 2d, arrived Sunday morning.
The Charleston Mercury, of the 30th ult., contains the following belligerent paragraphs:

Returning here after a three weeks' absence, I am surprised at the wonderful change which has been effected in the appearance of the place. Evidences of indomitable Yankee energy are abundant. A single rickety plantation residence, with its halfdozen straggling outhouses, and a frame hut near the fort, erected by the rebels as a make-shift barrack, were the only buildings on Hilton Head when our army took possession.

Henry Dexter vs. Richard J. Clark. This was an action commenced in the Marine Court, to recover $50 for one quarter's rent of a house belonging to the plaintiff, and occupied by the defendant; also to recover $68.75, upon a claim for prior rent of the same house, due from the defendant to Messrs. Weeks De Forest, and by them assigned to the plaintiff. The complaint was dismissed by Judge THOMPSON.
The Europa arrived at 4 o'clock this afternoon. She encountered head winds the entire passage, and was 40 hours from Halifax to Boston.

That it appears on such estimate and canvass, that the whole number of votes given for the office of Councilmen of the Fourth Senatorial District, was one hundred and five thousand two hundred and seventy-three.

Four companies of Col. WILLICK's German Indiana regiment were attacked this afternoon, on the south side of Green River, opposite Mumfordsville, by Col. TERRY'S regiment of Texan Rangers, two regiments of infantry and six pieces of artillery. Col. WILLICK, on being reinforced, drove the rebels back, with a loss of 33 killed, including Col. TERRY, and 50 wounded. The National loss was 8 privates and 1 Lieutenant killed, and 16 wounded.

In the Senate, the House bill authorizing the raising of a volunteer force in Kentucky was referred to the Military Committee. A bill to increase the number of cadets at West Point was reported from the same Committee by Mr. WILSON.
A correspondent of a Nashville paper, writing from Bowling Green on the 2d, gives the following account of JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE'S recent exploits:

One evening last Summer, soon after the warspirit had been touched to a more vivid flame by the disaster at Manassas, I was standing near the office of the Congressional Globe, in that magnificent Pennsylvania-avenue which is one of the features of Washington. The sharp rattle of forty drums stirred the still-summer air with martial ardor, as a New-York regiment went marching by on its way from the railroad depot to quarters.

FISH is now in the hands of the rebels at Charleston, and it will be a matter of interest to know how our soldiers are faring in that section, while it shows the necessity of providing for an exchange of prisoners:

I have received a copy of to-day's Norfolk Day Book, by a flag of truce. It contains the followimportant intelligence:
This brilliantly arranged affair, which promises to be the nine days' wonder of New-York society before the holidays, was in full tide of successful operation on Saturday night last.

The Board of Commissioners of Excise for the City and County of New-york vs. Robert R. Purdy. LEONARD J. Motions are made in this and several other similar actions for an order dismissing them with costs, to be paid by the plaintiffs' attorneys, on the ground that they are commenced without any authority or lawful right so to do.
That THOMAS SALMON, by the greatest number of votes, was duly elected as School Inspector for the First Ward.

A correspondent of the Memphis Appeal, writing from Feliciana, Graves County, Ky., says: "Yesterday a lady from Padueah was arrested near our camp, and upon her person was found a large package of letters written to our boys at home. They had been intercepted somewhere in transit, and had, no Joubt, either been or were intended to be taken to Padneah. This fact plainly shows that LINCOLN has emissaries fingering our mail."

A reconnoissance was made to-day by a squadron of the First New-Jersey Cavalry, belonging to Gen. HEINTZLEMAN'S Division, under command of CaptSHELLNISU. A portion of the squadron commanded by Lieut, JANEVILLE, of Company L, of Jersey City, was ordered to proceed to the Bone Mills, to the left of Springfield station, on the Orange and Alexandria Railroad, about seven miles from the headquarters of Gen. HEINTZLEMAN.
That JAMES FITZSIMMONS and JOHN CASEY, by the greatest number of votes, were duly elected as School Trustees for the First Ward, full term.

The United States steamer Mercedita, Capt. STELLWAGEN, Will sail to-day for Key West, Fort Jefferson and Fort Pickens, Florida, The mail for these posts, Ship Island and the blockading squadron at the different points in the Gulf, will be sent by her, and will close at 2P.M.

The Eleventh Regiment of Connecticut Volunteers, which has been quartered for several weeks past at Camp Lincoln, near West Hartford, in that State, arrived in this City yesterday morning by the steamer City of Hartford. As the troops landed, their officers were met by a Committee of the Sons of Connecticut, and formally notified of the hospitalities awaiting them.

Gov. CURTIN is about to issue a proclamation, calling upon the citizens to form military organizations for State defence. He has had all the State arms collected, which are being repaired at Lancaster at the rate of 1,260 per week. He will shortly visit Washington to confer with the National authorities for the defence of Delaware River and Lake Erie.

Sacramento is now mostly out of water. Influential parties of that city have advocated that the money already appropriated to pay the interest on the an embankment, to prevent another inundation. The proposition was defeated through the action of a pub-...

The steamship Constitution, Captain A.V. FLETCHER, sailed for Boston at midnight last night. It is supposed that she will there take on board three more regiments for some point on the Southern coast.

The excitement could hardly have been greater at New-York, when the news of the capture of Messrs. SLIDELL and MASON arrived there, than it was at Paris, yesterday, when the same news arrived here. The Unionists shouted with joy at the bold stroke, while the Secessionists swore loud and long, and predicted an immediate war with England.

Mr. DAWES, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) from the Committee on Elections, reported that CHARLES HENRY FOSTER is not emitted to a seat in this Congress, either from the First or Second Congressional District of North Carolina.
Mr. TEN EYCK, of New-Jersey, (Rep.) presented a petition for the establishment of an armory on Burlington Island, New-Jersey.
The speculations from France in regard to the English-American difficulty are contradictory.

That fresh sensation, the want of which becomes in our community a necessity almost as imperious as that for daily bread, has been furnished again in the forminable danger that seems to threaten us from England; and this time the interest it excites is neither fictitious nor feeble. All seem instinctively to recognize the actual presence of a great peril, and are disposed at once to grapple with the question at close quarters.

The following is a copy of a letter which has been addressed by the seamen at drill to the commanding officer of the Naval Reserve training ship in London. The few hours' additional intelligence brought by the Jura shows a rapid subsidence of the popular excitement in England. The tone of the Press is less recklessly defiant, and such organs of the Liberal party as the London Daily News, the London Star, and the Mannchester Examiner, take a generous and conciliatory view of the cause of agitation. The News in its earlier article was unconditionally for war.

It is said that immediately on the receipt of the intelligence of the American outrage, orders were forwarded by telegraph to all the military posts to fit out with the utmost dispatch all the ships in ordinary or in reserve.

WINTER GARDEN, This evening will be presented the new piece of "Lakes of Killarney, or Brides of Glengariff," which has been for some time in preparation, and which will be produced with new scenery, Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAMS have leading parts in the piece.

The London Times, in its latest article on the Trent affair, goes the length to assert that "that sort of irregularity has often formed the occasion of war." Probably this is only meant as a sounding piece of British bluster, for, as a historical statement, it...

The recent Mumfordsville engagement, considering the disproportion of numbers, proves the most brilliant National victory yet achieved. Four companies, of about 350 men, of Col. WALLACH'S regiment, led by the Lieutenant-Colonel, drove back over 3,000 rebel cavalry, artillery and infantry. They were first attacked by a regiment of Texas cavalry, whom they repulsed and followed, when they were drawn into ambush, and fired at from all sides by rebel infantry.

The annoucement that the Law Officers of the Crown have given an opinion that the proceedings of the Captain of the American frigate San Jacinto were illegal, caused Consols to open this morning at a further fall of per cent. Subsequently the heaviness increased, until transactions took place at 1 per cent, below the last price of yesterday, and 2 per cent.

The mails by the Europa reached this City yesterday morning. A very ample summary of her news was telgraphed from Halifax, but our London and Paris correspondence on the excitement produced by the Mason and Slidell affair, and the extracts which we give from London and Paris journals, will be read with great interest.
Gen. BUELL has telegraphed to headquarters the following:

The New-York Belling and Packing Company vs. The Metropolitan Fire Insurance Company The plaintiffs brought their action upon a policy of insurance issued by the defendants upon the plaintiffs' establishment for the manufacture of India-rubber goods, at Newtown, in Fairfield County, Conn.
A Cabinet meeting was held to-day, at which the English question was discussed of course informally, as the nature of the dispatches brought by the Royal messenger have not been divulged.
We have the Norfolk Day Book, of Tuesday, which contains extracts from the Charleston Courier and Mercury, relative to the fire, but there is little additional to what has already been telegraphed.
The Royal Mail steamship Jura, Captain AITON, from Liverpool, on the afternoon of the 5th, and Londonderry on the 6th instant, arrived here this morning.

The report of Col. HARVEY BROWN, representing the comparative uselessness of his smooth-bore guns as against the rifled guns of the rebels, in the late action at Fort Pickens, will, of course, receive the attention which it demands of the Ordnance Department. It was not necessary, however, to await the result of a battle in order to reach Col. BROWN'S conclusions.

The Mayor of one of the cities of Canada West writes that the people of that region are highly excited about the "indignity to the British flag," and military organizations are rapidly forming to resent it.

By the Jura, which arrived at Portland yesterterday, we receive two days later European news. The excitement in regard to the Trent affair continues unabated throughout England. Large military and naval preparations are going on, and the exportation of arms and munitions of war to the United States has been prohibited. In the midst of the popular clamor, Messrs. BRIGHT and COBDEN

Gentlemen who left Henry County Sunday say that Clinton, the county seat in that county was in possession of from six to eight thousand rebels, most of whom were from Gon. PRICE'S camp at Osceola, and the balance recruits from the northwestern counties. They were persecuting Union men and plundering private property.
A regular meeting of the Board was held yesterday, the President, G.C. VERPLANCK, in the chair.

Gen. Miramon and Staff, consisting of Manuel Gaul, Miquel Gaul, Francisco Bueno, David Vallaltel and Manuel Garcia, together with Senoritas Anita and Lola Scholtaus, from Mexico; Col. Sibley, Capt. Larned, Capt. Howard, J.G. Rodgers and F. Harwood, of the United States Army, are at the Metropolitan Hotel.

In the Senate, after the presentations of petitions amoug which were the usual number relating to the question of Slavery Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, offered a resolution, which was laid over, asking by what authority Gen. PHELPS' proclamation to the people of the Southwest was issued. A bill for the collection of direct taxes in the rebellious States was introduced by Mr. DOOLITTLE of Wisconsin.
A gentlemen who arrived from Williamsport, late last night, reports that JACKSON'S brigade has been largely increased, and is supposed to amount to 9,000 men at Falling Waters.

A Cabinet meeting was held yesterday, at which the whole matter was discussed, though informally, as neither the Queen's Messenger nor the one from Minister ADAMS had arrived at the time the meeting was held. Contrary to expectation, GARIBALDI had arrived at Turin and appeared in the Chamber of Deputies, where the Roman and Neapolitan question continued under discussion.
An Admiralty notice was issued yesterday, requiring all men on leave of absence to return immediately to their respective ships.
Not one of the least remarkable events in our great contest with the rebellion was the accident of the seizure of Messrs. SLIDELL

Capt. DOWLING, of the Sixth Precinct, yesterday afternoon, arrested a man named GEORGE HUMEL, upon suspicion of being connected with the mystery which still envelops the sudden and terrible death of BERNARD LEVY, the Canal-street Broker.

A Union refugee from Arkansas says Gov. RECTOR has issued a proclamation, requiring all persons between the ages of 16 and 45 to join the army, was relentless, and they were being arrested and imprisoned.
From our English files by the Jura, which extend to the 5th of December, inclusive, we obtain some additional and highly interesting details of news.
The steamer S.R. Paulding has arrived from Port Royal, bringing news of the safe and successful occupation of Beaufort by our troops. The health of the men was good, and the weather fine.

At 11 , seventeen vessels, whalers from NewLondon, are inside the bar. These were purchased by the Government for the purpose of being sunk in the channels of various rivers in the South. Thirty have been sent and are now on their mission.

The Havre journals publish the following report from Captain (master) GUICHON, commanding the French brig Jules et Marie, (174 tons, a crew of nine men, and one passenger,) from Liverpool to the Havannah, with a cargo of coals:

Taking Hilton Head for the base of operations, the army and navy are conjointly making a series of strategic moves which must, sooner or later, bring South Carolina and Georgia to their fealty. So soon as the foothold here was made secure Tybee Island was seized and held, and now other operations are in progress for a flank advance upon Savannah. Charleston, too, is receiving a share of attention.

The New-Orleans Picayune, of Nov. 23, has the official report of the assessed valuation of the city, the total reaching $129,255,000. The real estate of non-residents is of the value of $11,000,000. The amount of money at interest is $17,277,000. Number of slaves owned in the city, 11,329.

Judge HOLLINGSWORTH, a well-known and prominent citizen of Todd County, arrived here yesterday, having succeeded, after considerable difficulty, in getting through the rebel lines. Todd County is southwest of Bowling Green, and on the railroad from that place to Memphis. The Judge has been there ever since the rebel forces entered Kentucky, and has had every opportunity for ascertaining the true state of affairs in that entire region.
H.B.M. gunboat Racer, Commander Lyons, Port Royal Dec. 19, via Charleston Bar Dec. 13, 15th inst., off Cape Hatteras, spoke U.S. ships Jamestown and Orlando, cruising.

The names of about 300 rebels have been enrolled at the Provost-Marshall-General's Office, upon whom contributions are to be levied under Gen. HALLECK'S General Order No. 24, for the benefit of the Southwest refugees. About sixty of the most prominent of these are to be called upon to-morrow for the sums set opposite their names, varying from $100 to $100, and the balance are to be notified as the exigencies require.
Richmond and Norfolk papers, of yesterday, have been received here.
HEALTH OF THE MAYOR. There was another unfavorable turn yesterday in the disease by which Mayor KALBRLEISCH is prostrated upon a bed of sickness, and it is feared that he will not recover.
THE ALLOTMENT SYSTEM, AS PASSED BY THE ALDERMEN, CONCURRED IN A.V. STOUT, TREASURER $3,000 TO BE PAID FOR A COMPILATION OF LAWS RELATIVE TO THE CITY.

The following vessels comprise the British naval reserve at Portsmouth, and which, in the event of war with the United States, could be dispatched across the Atlantic at a week's notice to reinforce the squadrons already in American waters. The British fleet already on our coast includes some 44 ships mounting 837 guns, and manned by 8,509 sailors:
By a flag of trace to-day we have a Richmond paper of this morning. We extract from it the following news:
The trial proceeded at 10 o'clock this morning, District-Attorney WATERBURY examining witnesses for the prosecution.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been; 72 bbls. Ashes, 13,318 bbls. Flour, 662 bbls. Corn Meal, 4,580 bushels Corn, 730 bushels Rye, 640 bushels Barley, 4,648 bushels Oats, 5,720 packages Provisions, 874 bbls. Whisky.

A number of private letters' however, had been received from England, which were generally similar in tone to the English Press.

At every step of our naval operations, we get new demonstration of the immense utility of that great National undertaking, the United States Coast Survey. In the latest expedition, that to Ship Island, the only guides the commander had in the dangerous navigation off the Florida reefs, were the "day-marks" of beakons left by the of ficers of the Survey.
News from Williamsport last night shows that considerable disquiet exists along the river line. Shots are continually being exchanged between the enemy and Col. LEONARD'S men.

At 10 o'clock this morning, a rebel battery of three guns, flanked with about two hundred infantry, suddenly commenced shelling the encampment of Col. GEARY'S Pennsylvania Regiment. About twenty shells, well aimed, fell amidst the encampment, the first within a few feet of Lieut.-Col. DE KORPONAY, commanding. The six companies in camp were well deployed and intrenched.

The steamship S.R. Spaulding, Capt. S. HOWES, which left Port Royal last Sunday, arrived here at an early hour this morning.

The screw steamer City of Washington, Capt. BROOKS, which left Liverpool at noon on the 4th, and Queenstown on the 5th inst., arrived on the 4th, last night. Her advices are anticipated by the Jura, full extracts from whose mails we give elsewhere.

It is just a year ago to-day since the first State Ordinance of Secession was passed, and South Carolina declared the National Union forever dissolved. The day is to be commemorated in that State, and probably in other parts of the South, and it is hoped to make the 20th of December in the new Republic what the 4th of July has been in the old Republic Independence Day.

Charles B. Hoffman et al. vs. Daniel Miller et al. This was an action to recover upon a draft for $1,100, of which Allen, Hay Co., a firm doing businees in this City, were the acceptors, and the defendants, a Baltimore firm, payees and indorsers. The draft was dated Sept. 22, 1860, and accepted on the 5th of October following.

At a regular meeting of this Board Wednesday the School official of the Nineteenth Ward were authorized to purchase three lots of ground on the south side of Forty-second-street, 130 feet east of Thirdavenue, at a cost not exceeding $7,500, for the erection of a school-house.

Dispatches received at Headquarters from Gen. POPE state that after a forced march yesterday he got between the enemy, encamped six miles from Chilbowee, Johnson County, and a body, 2,200 strong, in Clinton and Henry Counties, but as soon as they heard of his approach, they beat a rapid retreat toward Rose Hill, Johnson County, leaving all their baggage, arms, munitions, , in our possession.

The Herald says that the TIMES "has fallen to puffing prodigiously, philosophically and piously those well-known institutions, the Broadway concert saloons." As a mere matter of fact, this statement is, of course, exactly the reverse of the truth.

Peter Lynch vs. Henry Bischoof.--The plaintiff brought his action to compel the defendant to deliver to him, plaintiff, a deed to the premises known as No. 46 Elm-street, in this City, pursuant to a contract, as alleged, made between the parties for the purchase thereof by the plaintiff.
CAIRO, Friday, Dec. 13, 1861. We begin to have stirring times among both land and naval forces, which indicate that something will shortly transpire which will strike terror to the rebels below here.

CAIRO, Friday, Nov. 20. Scouts from Kentucky report that a large con traband trade is carried on with the rebels, from Illinois via Cave-in-the-Rock, on the Ohio River; also, that rifled cannon have been placed on the Tennessee River for the purpose of sinking the gunboat Coneste- ga, which makes occasional trips up the river.
Wills Admitted.--The wills of the following parties were now admitted to probate, none of them containing anything of public interest.

William Jarvis vs. The Steamboat State of Maine.--This case came up on exceptions to the Commissioner's report. The action was for a collision in Hellgate, between the steamboat and a schooner, and the Court, on a hearing, held both parties in fault, and directed an apportionment of the damages, for which purpose the case was referred to a Commissioner, to whose report both parties excepted.
SEDALIA, Mo., Friday, Dec. 20. Col. PALMER'S Brigade arrived here last night, and Gen. POPE is expected to-day.

CHARLESTON JAIL, S.C., Tuesday, Nov. 19, 1861. MY EVER DEAR FRIEND: After all the privation and insults to which we have been subjected since prisoners of war, and when the worst passions ought to be satisfied, we find that we have yet another and the worst ordeal to pass through.

THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER was presented with a handsome and valuable horse, completely caparisoned, by a few of his personal friends. The horse and its accoutrements cost upwards of $500.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 20. Mr. TRUMBULL, of Illinois, (Rep.,) presented a petition for the emancipation of the slaves of rebels if necessary to save the Union.

LOUISVILLE, Friday, Dec. 20. Gen. JOHNSON'S Brigade made a reconnoissence in force, to day six miles south of Green River, without finding a trace of the enemy. No official account of the Munfordsville fight has yet been received at ...
CHICAGO, Friday, Dec. 20. The Memphis Appeal, of the 18th inst., has the following:

WILLIAMSPORT, Md., Friday, Dec. 20. Affairs in and around this vicinity are quiet, ex cept an exchange of shots with the enemy at Dam No. 5, and Falling Waters. JACKSON'S Battery, at the former place, including a twelve-pounder rifled gun, has been at work endeavoring to destroy the dam, which now seems to be the principal object of his demonstration. His fire is responded to by two Parrott guns of KNAPP'S Pennsylvania Battery.
The Court opened shortly after 10 o'clock, Mr. Wm. T. Walton, brother of the deceased, resuming the stand.

HILTON HEAD, S.C., Monday, Dec. 16, 1861. A few days since I wrote that the expedition which has been so long in contemplation from this place to some other port in Secessia, would leave early this week.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 20. The Navy Department has received dispatches from Port Royal, including one from Commander DRAYTON, dated Dec. 9. He gives the particulars of his recent cruise in the Pawnee, with the Unadilla, Isaac Smith, and Vixen, and the exploration of the Ashepoo River.

PADUCAH, Ky., Monday, Dec. 16, 1861. LOUISVILLE, Monday, Dec. 16, 1861. Our city ladies' sixth and seventh week report of work and contributions for our Union soldiers, sums up 2,370 articles of clothing, l,630 articles of bedding, 95 army bags, 62 bottles of wine, and an almost countless amount of divers and sundry other things. Even women of fourscore, and little girls, not six years old, are volunteer workers for their State's and country's defenders.

The testimony in the Walton-Mathews murder, yesterday, was highly interesting. The crossexamination of WM. WALTON was completed, and Officer MOORE, who was employed to make JEFFERDS acquaintance and elicit confessions from him, was examined at length. His history of JEFFERDS' confessions comprised a series of most remarkable admissions by the prisoner. He was subjected to a rigid cross-examination by Mr. BRADY.
FORTRESS MONROE, Thursday, Dec. 19, Via BALTIMORE, Friday, Dec. 20. The steamer Illinois left for New-York early this morning.

LEAVENWORTH, Thursday, Dec. 12, 1861. Nothing more interesting than some drunken shooting scrapes, among disorderly soldiers, two or three rumors of a fight in Platte County, and the close of a trial for murder, resulting in the conviction and condemnation of the accused parties, have occurred to break the monotonous stir of life here for the last week, until yesterday, when orders were issued placing most of the organized corps under marching orders.

AL BURTIS, a circular recently issued by him, discussing the financial questions now before the country, and giving his views upon the policy necessary to raise the large sums needed to carry on the Government, and meet the heavy expenditures incidental to a war of the magnitude in which the country is now engaged. ST. LOUIS, Mo., Friday, Dec. 13, 1861. Returning to this city after an absence of sev eral weeks spent at the East, it is curious to observe how thorough has been the revolution effected under Gen. HALLECK'S management within that time. It is as if we had taken the wrong train, and were really in another city, while thinking ourselves in the commercial metropolis of Missouri.

They state that our prisoners at Richmond, numbering about 1,500, are suffering greatly for the want of clothing. Many are in rags, and some half naked. Saturday was an interesting day here, as there was a general review of the troops at this place. The weather was beautiful, as in fact it has been for several days, very much resembling Indian Summer. The sun rose bright and beautiful and the balmy air from the still waters of the Chesapeake Bay, catching the music from a dozen bands, made the morning one of pleasure and mingled sublimity.

The Paris papers assert that the dispatches sent by the British Government to Lord LYONS, although couched in moderate language, are, nevertheless, inflexible in their conclusion, which is, "The restitution of the Commissioners." If this is refused, Lord LYONS is to leave Washington with all the members of the British Legation.

On Sunday night, Dec. 15, Mrs. HARRIET STROCKEY shot and killed one WILLIAM CONWAY. The woman had been CONWAY'S mistress, but they had separated. On Sunday night he went to her house, and as she refused to admit him, he broke in the door and entered, whereupon she shot him with a pistol.

The first session of the Conference of the "Independent Methodist Churches in the United States was held in the St. John's Methodist Church, in this City, (Prof. MATTISON'S,) on Wednesday and Thursday last. About twenty delegates, lay and clerical, were in attendance, representing various Independent Methodist Churches in different parts of the country. Rev, M. STAPLE, of Brooklyn, was chosen President, Rev. H. MATTISON, of New-York, Secretary; and JAMES M. COBURN, Esq., of New-York, Treasurer.

We were grossly deceived here as to the number of the enemy. The facts of the case are these: There are only several hundred of them, and no fear need be entertained of their doing much harm in this immediate section.

HENRY SCLTHER has been appointed Surveyor General of the State, to fill the vacancy caused by the and confirmed Brigadier-General.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: Since my communication of Nov. 30, I have seen several able arguments on the question I have again written about one in the Boston Courier, of Dec. 12, and especially one which occurs in an able and eloquent appeal on behalf of Constitutional Law against the "higher law," from the pen of Judge NICHOLAS, of Kentucky, in the Louisville Journal of the 11th December.

Col. KIMBALL, of the Fourteenth Indiana Regiment, arrived in this City on Tuesday night, on his way home from Western Virginia. He left Phillippi, the headquarters of Gen. REYNOLDS and of his own regiment, on Sunday, and brings the first full and authentic account of the late battle between our troops under MILROY, and the rebels under JOHNSON, that has reached us.

The steamship Edinburgh, from Liverpool, Wednesday, via Queenstown, the afternoon of Thursday, 12th inst., arrived off this point this evening. She was boarded by the news yacht, and her, dispatches obtained. Her advices are but one day later, having sailed on the afternoon of the same day as the Arago.

The great interest which, up to the time of the National retreat from Springfield, clung around operations in Western Missouri, has returned in consid erable strength although probably nor for a lengthened stay, But, before touching upon the details connected with the demonstration upon the rebels, let me give you some of the circumstances which have lately transpired here, having reference to affairs in general.

At 3 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the five-story brick building No. 161 Broadway, which resulted in the total destruction of the building and contents. The lower part was occupied by HEGEMAN Co., as a wholesale and retail drugstore. They are the greatest sufferers, although there are several other parties who have sustained damage to a large amount.
A bright light was seen from this place last night, in the direction of Norfolk. It was probably caued by a conflagration in that city.

The number of recruits enlisted in this City last week, for the regular army, was not more then ten or twelve. Considering that there are eight recruiting offices open, in different parts of the City, this return is not at all satisfactory.

SOUTH FERRY ATLANTIC-STREET RAILROAD. The entrances to the Atlantic-street Tunnel, at the South Ferry, have been closed, and the street, being one hundred and twenty feet wide, has been restored to its original grade. The consummation of this change makes a great improvement in the street, for which the owners of property can well afford to pay the assessment levied therefor.
U.S. steam transport Star of the South, Commander Kearney, Port Royal 18th inst., in ballast.

Passengers from below report that everything is quiet there. They confirm the recent rumor of the rebels tearing up the railway tracks between Green River and Bowling Green.

The information I gave you about the troops of Ohio and Indiana has proved more than true. This week no less than six regiments from Ohio and ten from Indiana, comprising sixteen thousand men, go into Kentucky.

The steamship Persia, having British troops on board for Canada, Passed Cape Race yesterday afternoon, having left England on the 15th. The advices are three days later than those by the Edinburgh. The all-important feature of the news is the announcement of the death of the consolt of Queen VICTORIA, Prince ALBERT. He expired at noon of Sunday, the 15th, his disease being gastric fever.

By the Persia we have tidings of the death of His Royal Highness Prince ALBERT, confort of Queen VICTORIA, Duke of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, The event took place in London, on the 15th inst., after a brief illness, which was not considered dangerous until two days before it resulted in death.

The last two mails have brought us a sad batch of news from home, embracing the battle at Bull Run and that at Springfield, Mo. It has had a depressing effect upon Americans abroad, but we hope that these reverses may serve as training for better things.

Gen. Sir FENWICK W. WILLIAMS, of Kars, the commander of the forces in Canada, has been here again all day, in consultation with the military authorities. He came down from Montreal by special train, to hold a council of war. What warthereat determined, of course I cannot tell. But this I know, that heavy guns and shot and shell are daily going west, and that the Imperial Commissariat are preparing to receive more British troops.
Gen. HUNTER'S Department, as recently organized, embraces the State of Kansas and the four vast Territories to its north, south and west Dakota, Nebraska, Colorado, and the Indian domain.

The whole country is watching with intense interest the movement of the National armies in the field. But a subject not one whit less in importance, is the movement of the National finances. Secretary CHASE is bearing as great a burden as Gen. McCAELLAN, for without the success of the Minister of finance, the best of Generals and the best of causes must fail.

The destruction of the North Missouri Railroad is complete, as was at first stated. At short distances all the way from here to Hudson the track is torn up, ties burned, rails broken or bent so as to be useless. Wellsburgh Station was burnt with all its contents.

Among the veracious reports on the health of our troops, with which it is the ambition of some of our cotemporaries to enrich their columns, one of the most original has recently appeared in the Tribune. The Santa Fe mail, with dates to the 9th inst., has arrived. The Territorial Legislature met on the 2d, and on the 4th Gov. CONNOLLY read his annual Message to the joint session of both Houses. The Governor recommends all Indian tribes to be placed on reservation on very strict regulations, as the only way to prevent the constant recurrence of troubles with them.

" On earth, peace, good will to men," is the sentiment of the day. Alas! it is to us an aspiration; not an actuality.

Yesterday and to-day the rebel batteries on the Potomac have been wonderfully employed in wasting powder and ball. Probably $1,000 would not replace the ammunition consumed in their pyrotechnic displays of the past forty-eight hours. Not a vessel has been disabled out of the sixty which have run their blockade within the above time, not a soldier victimized or injured.

The chances are against the probability of a war between England and North America. On Tuesday we stated, on authority that excluded doubt' that in diplomatic circles it was understood that a reference would be made to LOUIS NAPOLEON, and yesterday the telegram confirmed our statement. The Emperor of the French has already offered his services as mediator, and they are pretty sure to be accepted.

At a special meeting of the Board last evening, the message of the Mayor vetoing the resolution making the World a Corporation paper, and recommending that the whole system of advertising patronage be revised, and the advertising be given to three or four papers having the largest circulation, was taken from the table, and Alderman SMITH moved that the resolution be passed over the veto.

Within a few years no event has so exclusively occupied the attention of the public and the press in France, as what is here called the Anglo-American conflict. It is the one sole subject of conversation in financial and commercial circles, and the columns of the Press are one-half given up to it.

It is perfectly evident, from the whole tenor of our foreign advices, that the English people were at the latest dates in a perfect paroxysm of rage and indignation. Every pretence of listening to the dictates of common sense had been abandoned. War with the United States was the popular and paramount passion.

The Legislature of Maryland formed a quorum on Thursday, when the annual message of Gov. HICKS was received and read. It is an excellent business document, and presents to the consideration of the Legislature a plain statement of the several matters requiring their attention, which have come under his observation. The message is of very moderate length, and should be read by every one interested in the affairs of the State.

The partial strike at the Brooklyn Navy-yard has been considerably exaggerated, but may now be looked upon as settled altogether. A great number of the artisans did not go to work until one o'clock yesterday, but at that time they were all present, with the exception of about fifty of the extremists, who, after mature deliberation, came to the wise conclusion of resuming work this morning.

I came over from London last night, leaving the station near London Bridge at 8 P.M., and reaching Paris at 7 this morning. In crossing the Channel, the weather being clear, I remained on the deck of the steamer all the way from Dover to Calais, watching the lessening lights of the Cliffs of Dover as we progressed, until, long before we were half across, the Calais lights appeared.

A single week of comedies at Mr. WALLACK'S handsome up-town establishment, has wrought so complete a change in the strength and character of the audiences there, that the manager will scarcely need to be urged to continue a style of performance so eminently successful with the classes to whom he looks for support.

SMITH, late Colonel of the Fourteenth Regiment, and present Senator representing the Second District, to the command thereof.

My last letter was sent from Independence about fifty miles north from our present encampment. We left that town on Thursday morning, the 19th inst. Our train was considerably swelled by the addition of one hundred and fifty mules and horses, taken from the hiding places eight miles below the town, and also by some ten wagons containing commissary and other stores, taken from the warehouses of men now in the rebel army.
To-day Gen Banks and Staff, accompanied by their ladies, took a special train hence, and joined the Vice-President and family at the junction. They proceeded thence to Sandy Hook.

Yesterday we started in the steamer George Washington for an expedition up to James River under a flag of truce. The object was to receive the exchanged prisoners who were to be sent down from Richmond.
A deserter from Columbus on Sunday, who arrived here this morning, reports that Gen. PILLOW resigned on Friday.

THOMAS and his daughter, who were asserted to have been arrested and imprisoned. Our correspondent telegraphs, however, that these rumors and assertions are malicious and untrue.

His Honor GEORGE OPDYKE, our new Mayor, regularly assumed the cares of office yesterday at City Hall.

The arrival yesterday from Port Royal brings us news of how our boys down in Palmettodom spent New-Year's; and it is pleasant to learn that they have not forgotten the good Yankee traditions of the day.
By the steamship Bohemian, which arrived at Halifax yesterday, we recive advices from Europe four days later. She left Liverpool on the 26th, and Londonderry on the 27th ult.

We learn from Albany that the members of the Legislature, elected on the Republican and People's tickets, met yesterday in joint caucus, and nominated candidates for officers of the Assembly.

Advices from Hancock, Md., state that Gen. LANDER had arrived there; also that Gen. JACKSON, with a large force, one 24 and two 12-pounders, had appeared opposite Hancock, and threatened to shell out our troops unless they evacuated the town.
Coroner WILDEY yesterday concluded the inquest upon the body of ANDREW J. FOWLER, who was murdered, on New-Year's morning, at the house of ill-fame No. 80 West Houston-street.

The passage of the Treasury Note bill is to be followed, we learn, by a comprehensive system of taxation to provide not only for the payment of the notes issued, but an adequate system of finance to meet what must be the enormously increased expenditures of Government for some time to come, at least, on a peace footing.

In the presence of events so momentous as those now surrounding us, we can but realize that man's strength is weakness, his wisdom foolishness, and human forecast a mockery. The Government, as foreshadowed in our previous Circular, proposes to make an immediate issue of Treasury Notes to the amount of $100,000,000, to be receivable in the payment of Government dues; to be legal tender between individuals, and convertible into 6 per cent bonds. The same provisions are to extend to the $50,000,000 which the Treasury has already the authority to issue.

In consequence of disproportionate assessments having been made on rebels in this city, Gen. HALLECK has appointed a new Board of Assessors to revise the old list and make such changes as they deem proper.
Massrs. POMEROY, of Kansas, (Rep.,) and CRANDLER, of Micoigan, (Rep.,) presented petitions for the emancipation of the slaves.
The Committee of Ways and Means have concluded to provide by taxation for a hundred and fifty millions during the current year.

The first meeting of the Republican General Committee for 1862, was held last evening, at the rooms of the Committee, No. 9 Court-street. A temporary organization was effected, by the election of WM. COIT, Esq. as Chairman, and S. ALPHEUS SMITH as Secretary.

The Ohio Legislature organized to-day. The Governor's Message is congratulatory on the prospect of a favourable termination of the present war, and on the general prosperity of the State for the past year. He recites briefly the history of the State since 1802, when the Constitution was adopted, showing an immense increase in wealth and population.

In the Senate, petitions for the emancipation of slaves and for the exchange of prisoners were presented. The bill in regard to the appointment of sutlers was reported back from the Military Committee, with amendments, and ordered to be printed.

An Italian, named PETER BONAVENTURA, appeared before Justice CONNOLLY yesterday at the lower Police Court, and made a complaint against CESAR E. POGLIANA, a lawyer of this City, residing at No. 378 Fourth-sreet.
Brevity is not the most conspicuous merit of the Message which Gov. MORGAN yesterday laid before the Legislature, and to which we devote this morning so large a share of our space.

An immense audience assembled, last evening in the Academy of Music, to hear the distinguished and venerable orator and statesman of Massachuselts deliver his already celebrated address upon. "The Origin and Character of the Present War."

The annual sale of pews at auction in Plymouth Church for the year was held last evening. As usual, there was a very large attendance of people, and the buying was quite as spirited as ever, though the premiums offered were not so large.

Senator DAVIS, of Kentucky, has introduced into the Senate a bill, of which we have already given an abstract, in relation to the rebels and their property. In the main purpose of the bill, viz., the forfeiting all the property of those who shall be engaged in the rebellion, we heartily concur.

William Brown et al. vs. David Austen et al. This was an action by the creditors of David Austen to obtain a decree in equity, declaring certain deeds made by the defendant to his three daughters, of a house each, void for alleged fraud.

An express messenger from Col. NUGENT'S regiment, stationed at West Point, Bates County, arrived here yesterday evening, on his way to St. Louis, with important dispatches to Gov. GAMBLE. He left Bates County on Friday, and reports that Col. JENNISON had burned Austin, In Cass County, instead of Rose Hill.

Hon. EDWARD EVERETT delivered his address "On the Character and Origin of the Present War," before an audience of 3,000 persons, last evening, at the Academy of Music. His portraiture of the evils of secession and the secret history of its progress was received with continued and enthusiastic acclamation.

In this Court yesterday, Judge McCUSS presiding, Daniel Sullivan pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the fourth degree, in causing the death of John Cunningham on the 26th of October last. Remanded for sentence.

LEUTZE is busy at work upon his great picture for the western staircase of the House gallery. It is to be entitled. "Westward the Star of Empire takes its way." The sketch in color is finished, and is in many respects the finest of Mr. LEUTEE'S works. The completion of the painting (the main picture, with the arabesques and smaller designs) will require a twelvemonth's work at least.
The latest intelligence received from Hancock last night states that Gen. JACKSON had retired, leaving only a battery and an infantry guard in sight.
A message was received from the President, communicating the papers in the Trent affair heretofore published.

The Ninety-first New-York Volunteers are preparing to leave Governor's Island, and expected to get away yesterday, but as the steam transport Ericsson, which will convey them to their destination, was taking in stores and provisions during the day, it is probable that they will not leave until this afternoon. The men have received all the pay due to them since their enlistment.
On Thursday last an increase in the number of vessels off this hartor was noticed. On Friday morning not less than twenty-three sail, of all classes, were in sight.

Two more important successes in Western Virginia are recorded this morning. Gen. MILROY has followed up his victory at Huntersville with another one in Tucker County, north of his position at Huttonsville, in which three hundred of the Thirty-second Ohio Regiment, under Capt. LACEY, dispersed four hundred rebels, and captured a Commissary, with a large amount of his stores, besides killing and wounding several.

The Republican Central Committee met last evening for the purpose of reorganizing for the year 1862.

The Legislature effected its organization, this morning, in the choice of the Union nominees by nearly a two-thirds vote. At no time has there been any contest between the Unionists and Democrats as such; but between individual members of the Union Party as to its course of action.

ANOTHER GAMBLING-HOUSE BROKEN UP. On Tuesday night, at a late hour, Capt. WILLIAMSON, of the Fouateenth Precinct Police, made a descent upon a gambling-house, situated at the corner of Hesterstreet and the Bowery.
The new Board met for the first time, last evening, at the Halls of the Board of Education, and was called to order by the Clerk, Mr. BOESE. All the members were present.

The Mass Union Convention assembled at 10 o'clock this morning. The attendance was much smaller than was expected. Hon. JAS. T. PRATT presided. The doings were participated in by Union Democrats and Republicans, representing each county in the State.

A letter from the Twelfth Indiana, at Sharps burgh, states that a portion of the political prisoners recently sent from Williamsport to Washington, were captured at Shepardstown by a detachment from that regiment.

The non-commissioned officers of the regular army are much gratified with the provision in Senator WILSON'S bill, now before Congress, to increase their pay $2 per month. The act of last Congress, increasing the pay of privates to $13, made a private equal to a Corporal in point of pay, and led to a good deal of dissatisfaction and grumbling.

SOLDIERS OF THE ARMY OF THE KANAWHA: The campaign in the western portion of this State is now, as far as you are concerned, ended. At its close you can review it with pride and satisfaction. You first encountered the enemy five months since on his unobstructed march into the intorior of the State. From that time until recalled from the field, you were engaged in perpetual warfare with him.

THE PENSACOLA SAFELY DOWN THE POTOMAC. The steamship Pensacola which left her anchorage off Alexandria yesterday morning, proceeded to Indian Head, about twenty-seven miles from Washington, where she remained until between 5 and 6 o'clock this morning, and then proceeded to run the blockade, which she did with safety.

Our citizens were shocked, this morning, to hear of the death of Col. SAMUEL COLT. Though the event was not wholly unexpected, the Colonel having been very sick for two or three days, yet the many flying rumors of his critical condition, and even of his death, had partially given way to more encouraging reports during the last twelve hours before the final event.

Nothing but the most consummate skill and wisdom can keep the troops here from utter demoralization. This is true, especially in the case of the New-York Ninth. This body of men have had a hard campaign here during a very sickly Summer season, and now are kept here contrary to the advice and protest of their medical staff, who have urged their removal on purely sanitary grounds.

About 11 o'clock last evening a fire broke out at Nos. 22 and 24 Frankfort-street, owned and occupied in part by JENEINS BROTHER, printers and bookbinders. The fire was first discovered on the fourth floor. It was a seven-story brick building, and was tenanted by quite a number of different parties, who conducted therein all the various branches of bookmaking. The building was totally destroyed.

A special to the Tribune from Cairo states that two more columns will be moved into Kentucky to- morrow. All the transports here have been chartered for that purpose. I am assured from the best authority, that troops are on the way here from St. Louis, and will arrive to-night or to-morrow.

The bill providing for a Solicitor of Customs in this port received the attention of the Chamber of Commerce in a recent meeting, at which the bill was discussed with a good deal of energy on both sides. It deserves consideration.

Sheehan vs. Clark. This action was brought to recover compensation for the services of the plaintiff. It appeared on the trial that both parties were in the battle of Bull Run the plaintiff as a private, and the defendant as a captain.

The losses by the fire in Frankfort-street on Sunday night were more extensive than was at first reported. At 2 o'clock yesterday morning nothing remained of the two buildings Nos. 22 and 24, except a small portion of the walls and the smouldering ruins.
The North Missouri Railroad trains now leave here regularly, but do not make time, owing to the difficulty of getting water for their engines.

A report was brought up yesterday morning that a large propeller was ashore a few miles below Cape Henry. The Spaulding was sent to her assistance, but could find nothing of her, and consequently repaired here early last evening.
The bomb-boats Geo. Manghan and Hugel were towed down the Delaware from the navy-yard, on Saturday. The destination of these boats is not known except to those in charge of them.

Moore et al. vs. Willett, Sheriff. Judgment for plaintiffs on the verdict. Opinion by Ingraham, J.

Washington was never more astounded than it was to-day, by the announcement that Secretary CAMERON had retired from the War Department. The thing was wholly unexpected, and no man was more surprised than Mr. CAMERON himself.

A meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, Ald. FRANKS in the Chair. A large number of petitions were presented and referred to appropriate committees. Ald. LYNCH offered a resolution, which was adopted, in favor of a petition to the Legislature, asking the passage of an act to prohibit "Shysters" from practicing in the Police Courts.

Yesterday, the Twenty-eighth Massachusetts Regiment, Col. WILLIAM MONTEITH, arrived at Governor's Island from West Cambridge, where it has been encamped since the beginning of last October. The regiment members nearly a thousand mer, all of whom are Irish, from the Colonel downward. Enfield rifles the men are armed with.

Green River, now the theatre of such vast warlike operations at different points of its course, is a deep, rapid stream, greenish in appearance, and most excellent to the taste.

Cooper Institute was about half filled last evening on the occasion of WM. LLOYD GARRISON'S lecture on "The Abolitionists and their Relations to the War."
Both Houses met pursuant to adjournment last evening, and held short sessions. Mr. ROBERTSON introduced his bill, of which I have made previous mention, in regard to concert saloons.

All eyes are turned southward, scanning the coast and exploring the interior, in the endeavor to conjecture upon what point the insurgents will next be made to feel the power which is now gradually and steadily brought to bear upon them.

The steam ship Champion, Capt. WILSON, from Aspinwall, on the 4th inst., with the mails, passengers and treasure, from California, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. She brings $885,924 in treasure.

DEAR SIR: I feel sure that if the members of the House of Representatives will consider the uses of the Coast Survey to the country in its present contest, they will be far from desiring to suspend the work. My duty will be fulfilled by stating the case, and then leaving it to their decision.

FRANCIS H. MURDOCK was arrested in Leicester on Saturday by U.S. officer BICKNELL, of this city, and this morning was examined before U.S. Commissioner C.W. TUTTLE, on a complaint which charged him with giving aid and comfort to the enemies of the United States.

Mr. PORTER, of Indiana, (Rep.,) adverted to the bill, and expressed the hope that Congress would distinguish itself by reforming abuses, and making the recipients pay postage on documents, instead of this being done by the public at large.

It is now quite apparent that the rebel force of Gen. HOLMES, at and about Ship Point, on the Potomac, has either been largely withdrawn, or has gone into Winter quarters in localities more effectually concealed from our view.

The Emperor, on New-Year's Day, made an address to the Diplomatic Corps, and received, as usual, the various state bodies. In response to an address from the Senate, he said he counted on the Senate to assist him in perfecting the Constitution, and at the same time maintaining intact the fundamental basis on which it rests.

We begin to pay the penalty for the act of Capt. WILKES in the volley of paper pellets of the diplomatic sort, that arrives from across seas. It is reported that Russia, at the commencement of the difficulty between American States, employed all her influence in favor of peace, and has recently taken steps to the same end. The Russian Cabinet has communicated to the great Powers all the reports received from her representatives at Washington.
The Senate in Executive session to-day, unanimously confirmed the nomination of Mr. STANTON as Secretary of War. He will enter upon the discharge of his duties on Saturday.

This regiment, which has been encamped at Camp Hale, Manchester, N.H., for some time past, arrived in Jersey City yesterday, by the steamer Con- necticut. On leaving camp, the men proceeded to Allyn's Point, Where they embarked. The regiment numbers one thousand able-bodied men, all of whom are uniformed, equipped and armed with the Enfield rifile. The baggage-train consists of one hospital, eight horses and the officer's baggage.

We have received the following account of the seizure of the brig Joseph Park, of Boston, by the privateer Sumter, and the subsequent escape of the latter vessel from the United States steamer Iriquois off the Island of Martinique, from the second mate of the Joseph Park, who was a prisoner on board the Sumler for upward of eight weeks.

It was rumored yesterday that Gen. PILLOW had resigned. The news ran through the army here like wildfire every tongue expressed regret and hoped it was only a camp rumor, but this morning we learned it was sadly true.

The regular Brokers' Circular is not completed. The sales of the week (four days) (foot up 80,000 bales, the market closing buoyant on Thursday, with a considerable advance upon all descriptions. The sales of Friday were 25,000 bales, of which 15,000 were to speculators and exporters, the market closing excited, and d, higher. The official figures call middling Orleans 12 3/8d,@12 d., while private authorities report an advance during the week to 13d.

The bill to authorize the Supervisors of Kings County to provide a tax for the support of the families of volunteers was reported favorably. A petition for tolling freight on railroads, competing with, canals, was received. Mr. OLVASY gave notice of a bill to prohibit suspension chain bridges at forty landings.

Tuesday morning, three companies, belonginging to the Twenty-ninth Regiment of Massachusetts, arrived in this City, by the steamer Connecticut. The companies are designated, respectively, F,G and H. Seven other companies of the Twenty-ninth are now stationed at Newport's News, and have been there end at Fortress Monroe since last May, having taken the place of the Third and Fourth Regiments lot Massachusetts, whose term of service had expired.

The Senate in Executive Session yesterday, confirmed the nomination of EDWIN M. STANTON as Secretary of War by a unanimous vote. The nomination of Mr. CAMERON was held over for further consideration.
The State Senate has partially organized. On the second ballot, Mr. CROWELL, Independent Democrat, of Union, voted for himself and was elected President.

The telegraph brings us what are called the results of the various conferences among themselves, and with the Secretary of the Treasury, of certain representatives of the Boston and Philadelphia Banks and three or four Bank gentlemen from this City.

Yesterday the Seventh New-Hampshire Regisment, Col. H.S. PUTNAM, arrived in this City from Manchester. It numbers 1,000 men, all of whom are armed and equipped. The regiment will remain in this City until further orders.

On Tuesday evening, the German "Teutonia Macnnerchor," one of the favorite singing clubs of the Union, held its eleventh annual festival at Hillebrandt's Metropolitan Rooms. About 600 persons partook of a handsome entertainment in the elegantly decorated saloons, and after hours spent in humorous, as well as serious vocal and instrumental music, recitations, pantomimes, etcetera, the spacious apartments were cleared for dancing, and a grand ball concluded the festival.

The steamship Arabia passed Cape Race on Tuesday night, having left Liverpool on the 4th inst., and Queenstown on the 5th. The news, of which we publish a telegraphic summary this morning, is one week later than previously received.

It will interest our readers, we believe, to know something of the current of public opinion about our and their terrestial luminary, as well as some facts bearing upon its present success and future prospects.
