On New-Year's Day the Pope received Gen. GOYON and French officers. Gen. GOYON spoke of devotion to the Pope, and the latter thanked GOYON for the sentiments expressed. The present French soldiers at Rome would not permit the fulfillment of any irreligious or impolitic act. The Pope concluded by bestowing the apostolical benediction on the Imperial family, the Emperor NAPOLEON, and the whole French company.

The United States vs. The Cargo of the schooner Solidad Co., formerly called the Anna Taylor. This vessel was captured, Sept 11, 1861, off Galveston Bar, by the United States vessel-of-war South Carolina, ostensibly bound on a voyage from Vera Cruz to Matamoras, or Key West. The owner of the cargo resided in Texas and Louisiana, and went out and returned on board the vessel.

Congress has yet taken no definite action upon the various schemes before it for the relief of the Treasury, but there is no doubt of the adoption, as soon as it can be matured, of a system of national taxation that shall at least assume to provide for the expenses of Government on a peace footing.

The public has a quiet confidence in the successful issue of the Burnside expedition. Whatever may be its work, and wherever it may be going, no one seems to doubt its safely reaching its destination, or that it will unfailingly achieve the purpose for which it has been sent.

On Monday last the Society of German Physicians, who have voluntarily undertaken to supply the destitute poor of New-York and Brooklyn with medicines and medical attendance free of cost, held a general meeting. The number present was large, and unabated interest was manifested in the cause.

A most fearful railroad accident occurred early yesterday morning, on the Delaware Railroad, just where the track crosses the canal, near St. George's station, by which seven persons lost their lives, and fifteen were more or less injured. A wood train, consisting of thirteen platform cars, empty, and one old passenger, in which the conductor, Mr. ALBERT BUTLER, and some twenty laborers were seated, went down the Delaware road for a load of wood.

The Senate in Executive session yesterday, spent four hours upon the nomination of Mr. CAMERON as Minister to Russia, without concluding to confirm it. The debate is reported to have been earnest and spirited.
The Senate spent four hours to-day in secret session, all the time devoted to the nomination of Mr. CAMERON as Minister to Russia.

Mr. BELL'S bill amending the act authorizing Notaries Public of the State of New-York to perform the duties now performed by Commissioners of Deeds, by adding after the words "Commissioners of Deeds." the words, "and Justices of the Peace in the several counties in the State."

A remarkably beautiful evening succeeded the brilliant sunshine and universal thaw of yesterday; and at 7 o'clock, the hour fixed for the opening of the Sigel Mass Meeting, announced to take place at the Cooper Institute, every space in the vast hall was almost uncomfortably crowded, several hundred ladies occupying the front seats. On the stage were assembled a large number of well-known Germans, representing all the professions.

When the new postal law came into operation, Mr. BELL, postmaster for this City, to be on the safe side, determined that the postage of letters between this place and the States east should he increased from the three-cent to the ten-cent rate. As has been before observed, this change was by no means popular here, begetting a great deal of grumbling, and some personal feeling toward our then new Postmaster.

His body was left on the field by his retreating army, and is now in charge of the National commander. On the evening of Dec. 30, a meeting to consider the question of war was held in the Town Hall of Brighton. Resolutions, and an address to the Crown, strongly favoring peace and a resort to arbitration, were adopted almost unanimously. Among the speakers were Messrs. CONYNGHAM and WHITE, the members for the borough, the former of whom thus referred to the London Times:

SIR: The letter of Lieut. M.F. MAURY, formerly of the United States Navy, to Admiral FITZROY which appeared in The Globe, induces a desire that your readers may have the opportunity of seeing a relief view of that highly colored picture of the American civil war; and for this purpose I beg to tax your courtesy and their patience with a brief reply to that extraordinary letter.

A picturesque little piece called the "Sentinel of the Watch" was produced here last evening with success. It is of very slight material, only a luminous thread from the consuming fires of the great French Revolution, but trembling with issues of life and death.

The Union Manufacturing Company vs. Lounsbery, Bissell Co. Notwithstanding the blusterings and vaporings of the London Times, and the war Press generally, there is a perceptible diminution of the war feeling throughout this Kingdom. Under this idea the clamor for prompt "chastisement upon the Yankees" was fired up to a great heighth; but the necessity of delay, and the consequent time afford.

JOHN TYLER, of Virginia, the only Ex-President resident in the seceded States, is dead. There are yet some gentlemen living who have sat in the presidential Chair VAN BUREN and FILLMORE in New-York, PIERCE in New-Hampshire, and BUCHANAN in Pennsylvania all in the loyal States. The events of Mr. TYLER'S career, though familiar to almost everybody, may, now that he has passed forever off the stage, be briefly recapitulated.

Yesterday afternoon, at 5 o'clock, the female prisoners, Mrs. GREENHOW and BAXLEY, who have been confined for some time past at the Sixteenth-street Prison, (Mrs. GREENHOW'S former residence,) under the care of Lieut. N.E. SHELDON, were, by order of Brig.-Gen. ANDREW PORTER, removed to the old Capitol Prison, where apartments have been provided for them.

Reverend and Dear Brethren: I have duly received your communication informing me of my election to the Episcopate of the Diocese of Alabama. I do not know how to express the mingled emotions to which your unexpected communication has given rise. But you will readily understand my difficulty.

We are not surprised at the sympathy with everything American which is expressed in the "Nationalist" prints. A hatred of England is common, not to Ireland and America, but to the two most worthless sections of those countries the Young Ireland and the Young American parties. These parties have, however, much more than this amiable feeling in common. They are cast apparently in the same moral and intellectual mould.
In the Case Of CRAWFORD vs. ROBINSON, contest ing the right to the Governorship, of Kansas, the Supreme Court have refused to grant the writ of mandamus applied for by the contestant, CRAWFORD.

TREASURY NOTES. The amount of treasury notes issued by the Department has now reached forty millions. About a half million is still being issued daily.
A general meeting of the influential organization known as the "German Society," was held, recently, in St. Matthew's Church, Walker-street. Mr. WILLIAM JELLINGHAUS presided.

A detachment of recruits, enlisted in Boston for the general service, arrived here on Wednesday, and were transferred to the principal depot, Governor's Island. This is the first batch of recruits sent from Boston during the present year.

The Constitutional Convention of this State has been in session at Springfield, since the first Tuesday of this month. But little progress has been made, as yet. The Convention started off with the assumption of some novel powers claiming to be the supreme authority in the State, and that they were neither bound by the existing Constitution or the acts of the Legislature.

The chemist LIEBIG affirms that the civilization of a people is accurately determined by the amount of soap it uses. Without disputing the justness of this standard we may hazard the assertion that it should not exclude others, and that one important measure of intellectual advancement is the degree of extension of epistolary correspondence.
Petitions for the erection of fortifications along the frontier, and in favor of the Metropolitan Health Bill, were received.

Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, Attorney-General of this State, repeated at Hoboken, last evening, with some additions, his lecture on "The Union; its Hopes and its Fears." He favored crushing the rebellion by the most efficacious and speedy means, especially by confiscating the property of rebels.
Mr. TRUMDULL, of Illinois, (Rep.,) presented peti tions from the officers and soldiers of Camp Douglas, and from citizens of Chicago, asking for the employment of homeopathic physicians in the army.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been 133 bbls. Ashes, 6,800 bbls. Flour, 4,995 sacks Corn Meal, 535 bushels Wheat, 3,883 bushels Corn, 1,703 bushels Rye, 7,295 bushels Oats, 2,813 bushels Malt, 3,615 pkgs. Provisions, 549 bbls. Whisky.

The Somerset correspondent of the TIMES says at 7 o'clock Sunday morning, the enemy drove in the pickets of the Tenth Indiana, stationed at the forks of the road, eight miles from Somerset. The Tenth were drawn up in line, and moved into the woods, where they were met by the enemy, 6,000 strong, who instantly opened upon them.

During the past fifty hours it has rained hard almost incessantly. The storm still continues, Yes- terday noon the water at Sacramento commenced rising again. The third complete inundation of that city is unavoidable.

Hon. D.S. DICKINSON, the Attorney-General of the State, lectured at the Hoboken Baptist Church, last evening, on The Union Its Hopes and Its Fears. The lecture was the third in the course before the Hoboken Baptist Church, and, as usual, the citizens of our promising neighbor turned out in large numbers in support of this, the first attempt to establish a course of lectures in Hoboken.

In the Senate yesterday, the bill appropriating $10,000 for the expenses of the Committee on Contracts, was passed. A bill to create two new bureaus in the Navy Department was referred. A bill providing a charter for certain banks in the District of Columbia was also referred.

Mr. STEVENS, of Pennsylvania, closed the debate in Congress on Thursday, upon a bill making appropriations for executive, legislative and judicial expenses. He began by announcing that he should avail himself of that opportunity "to speak to other questions than that before the Committee," which he proceeded to do at some length.

To-day a poor woman, a widow, arrived here from the neighborhood of Campton, county seat of Wolfe County, having left home (once a home) to try to avoid starvation. The rebels, under FICKLEN, a subordinate of HUMPHREY MARSHALL, had robbed her of her all. She left home to try to find bread by begging from Union men.

In the Senate, Saturday, a petition was presented for the incorporation of the State Homeopathic Society. A bill to stop the sale of swill milk was reported. The bill in relation to unauthorized banking was then debated in Committee of the Whole during the rest of the session, and finally passed to a third reading.

Few persons are aware of the very great expense attending the sessions of Congress. The mere hiring of persons to wait upon the Senate and House, and keep record of the proceedings, has been costing the Government $150,000 annually. The cost of furniture, lights, fuel, stationery, and so forth, is a sum large enough to be quite incredible.

By the arrival of the steamship Europe, at Halifax, we have advices from Europe three days later than were received by the City of New-York. She left Liverpool on the 11th inst., and Queenstown on the 12th. Neither troops nor stores were sent on board of her by the British Government, all such shipments by the Cunarders having been discontinued. The news generally is of the most gratifying character.

Mr. REYNOLDS, the agent sent by the Secretary of the Treasury to Port Royal, to take charge of the cotton on the islands in that vicinity, returned here yesterday. He had a long interview with Secretary CHASE last night. He says he has already secured about a million of dollars' worth of cotton. He has now in his employment about three thousand negroes, who are at work on the different islands, gathering cotton.

Some journals mis- interpret the late order of Secretary STANTON appointing two Commissioners who are to proceed South for the purpose of providing for the necessities and the comfort of our National prisoners of war, and give to the Commission the scope of negotiating a general exchange of prisoners.

The number of disposable seamen on board the North Carolina is eight hundred.

This was an action brought for an alleged infringement of the patent granted to the plaintiff on Nov. 12, 1846, for the discovery of sulphuric ether as an anaesthetic agent. The plaintiff called as witnesses Drs. Wood, Griscom, Barker, Parker, Stansbie, Noyes and Edwards.

Our legal columns this morning contain a case of very great interest to the medical profession. We refer to a suit brought by Dr. W.T.G. MORTON against the New-York Eye Infirmary, to recover damages for the infringement by them of the patent granted to him in 1846 for an "improvement in surgical operations," it being the famous patent for the use of sulphuric ether as an anaesthetic agent.

A member of a leading foundry establishment informed us that their chief business, at present, was the manufacture of sugar kettles. We were also informed by a grocery merchant that there is an extraordinary demand from the interior for buckets, some farmers buying as many as five dozen. This means extensive preparations for tha manufacture of maple sugar.

It is here predicted that Geb. THOMAS will be in Knoxville by the 15th or 20th prox. I am told his division consists of the brigades under SOHOEPF, BOYLE, R. L. McCOOK, MANSON and CARTER, with five to ten batteries--each brigade averaging 5,000 or more men. His command may be made still stronger.

A gentleman, living twenty-two miles south of the late battle-field at Mill Spring, on the main road leading South, gave me quite an interesting account of the flight of the rebels, and the manner in which they conducted themselves while in Wayne and Clinton counties, which I now furnish you.

We published yesterday a valuable letter, from an esteemed Manchester correspondent, which gives a luminous view of the state of things in the cotton districts of England, and of her prospects touching an adequate supply of the indispensable staple.

The steamship Northern Light, from Aspinwall on tthe 25th ult, is announced below, where she arrived last evening, but was unable to come up on account of the storm. She brings hundred passengers and $850,000 in treasure. She announces the total wreck, on Point Reinedios, of the Panama Railroad Company's steamer Columbus. No lives were lost.

He was permitted to proceed no further. The scaled communication was brought to headquarters here by Capt. DRONILLARD. The contents have not yet transpired.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The last performance but one of the season will take place to-night, and, by general request, VERDI'S latest opera, "Un Ballo in Maschera," will be given for the last time. If the weather is at all propitious the house will undoubtedly be brilliantly attended. The two American prime donne, Miss KELLOGG and Miss HINKLEY, together with all the leading male artists of the Academy, will appear in this favorite work.

Some misunderstanding seems to have prevailed as to what time the Senate adjourned to on Satur day. Several of the Senators went home, supposing it was until Monday evening, but those who were here met in the morning. Nothing of especial inter est, however, transpired. The vote on the Bright resolutions, as amended and mollified, was postponed until 1 o'clock to-day, for the benefit of the absentees.

A painful accident occurred in the Camp of the First Massachusetts Volunteers, to-day, resulting in the death of a soldier in that regiment. Two soldiers, named SWALLOW and BARLOW, were indulging in a little innocent badinage, when SWALLOW caught up a musket standing near him, and leveling it at the breast of BARLOW, exclaimed, "Now I will have a good pop at you," and immediately pulled the trigger.

Our mail from Bogota not being due till the 4th proximo, we have nothing further in regard to the troubles of the interior; neither have we had any thing from that disturbed district, the State of Cauca since my last.

The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Guatemala, Capt. Dow, arrived from Central American ports on the 20th inst. She brings dates from San Jose de Guatemala to Jan. 12, Salvador to the 14th, Nicaragua to the 16th, and Costa Rica to the 18th.

E.O. PERRIN, Esq., has just returned to the City, after an absence of about seven months in NewMexico. He has visited Fort Larned, Fort Union and Fort Craig, and been in Santa Fe a long time. He was a month in Albuquerque, where KIT CARSON is in command, with a regiment of New-Mexicans, one thousand strong, well armed, fully equipped and well drilled.

In the Senate yesterday, the resolutions instructing our Senators in Congress to vote for the expulsion of Mr. BRIGHT, of Indiana, were considered, the question being first on a substitute offered by Mr. BELL, declaring simply that Mr. BRIGHT is a traitor and ought to be expelled, A debate of considerable length took place as to the propriety of the proposed instruction.

Capt. J.D. BINGHAM, of the regular army, and for the last six months Assistant Quartermaster of Gen. BANKS' Division, has been transferred to Gen. BUELL'S army in Kentucky, where he will perform the duties of Quartermaster. Capt. HOLABIRD, who has been the Chief Quartermaster from the time this Division has been organized, will continue in the same capacity.

The emphatic refusal of Mr. SEWARD to permit the use of his name in connection with the next Presidential canvass, was announced, yesterday, in our Washington correspondence. Some ardent but injudicious friend of the Secretary of State, impresssed, no doubt, by the magnitude of that statesman's recent services in saving the country from a collision with a European Power, had sought permission to associate.

There are now employed in the United States Armory, in this city, 1,400 men. The number of guns fabricated during the last month was 10,500 the largest number ever made here in one month. The whole number turned out from June 30, 1861, to Jan. 31, 1862, was 44,072. These guns were issued as soon as finished, and are now, most of them, in the hands of soldiers.

In expectation that a vote would be had to-day in the Bright case, the galleries of the Senate Chamber were filled at an early hour, and all the available space in the Chamber was occupied by those entitled to the privilege of the floor. The interest in the proceedings was intense, and for five hours the vast concourse sat with enchained attention, awaiting the final issue.

In the Senate yesterday, the bill in relation to the punishment of crime in certain cases was reported favorably by the Prison Committee, which also recommended an alteration in the terms for sending criminals to the State Prisons, and in the law relative to the commutation of sentences. The report of the Select Committee, appointed at the last session, to investigate charges of malfeasance brought against certain Harbor-masters, was presented and ordered to be printed.

Several released prisoners came down from Baltimore this morning, to be sent South. They were taken to Craney Island by a flag of truce. No news relative to the Burnside expedition, or the movements of the Merrimac, was communicated.

The United States transport Constitution, which sailed yesterday forenoon for Ship Island, spoke the gunboat Miami about forty miles north of Hatteras last night, in a sinking condition, and unable to make steam enough to take her into port. The Constitution arrived here at 1 o'clock this afternoon with her in tow.

The Senate had only a very short session this morning, and then adjourned until Monday evening. Gen. CHARLES P. STONE, In command of a division on the Upper Potomac, has been arrested and confined in Fort Lafayette as a traitor. The charges against him are four misbehavior at the battle of Ball's Bluff; corresponding with the enemy, and two charges of recent treachery. He was brought to this City yesterday, and immediately transferred within the walls of Fort Lafayette. A court-martial will be speedily ordered in his case.

SERIOUS BURNING ACCIDENTS. A woman, whose name could not be ascertained, residing on the corner of North Seventh and Seventh streets, yesterday, afternoon, while intoxicated, set her clothes on fire, and was fatally injured. She was taken to the City Hospital for treatment. A little girl named SARAH FEUNY,whose parents reside on Hoyt, near Butler-street, was so badly burned by her clothes taking fire on Wednesday evening, that her life is despaired of.

A glorious day we have had at the National Capital. An atmosphere bright as youth, and inspiring as the presence of beauty, has enwrapped the earth; while an air, sweet as ever breathed over a bed of violets, sweeps from the warm South, as if to remind us of the love that once reached us from that land of flowers. This is the first utterance of Spring.

Our citizens were startled this morning by the announcement that Col. SAMUEL PRUYN was dead. The announcement came with paralyzing suddenness to those who met him, in his usual robust health and spirits, last evening--rejoicing with his fellow-citizens over the good news brought to us from the seat of war. No man was happier, or seemed more likely to pass on healthfully into a green old age.

A father of a family is liable to be sometimes resisted by disobedient and rebellious children. It often happens that he is compelled to chastise them sharply and severely before they will submit to his just commands. This is a duty, however painful in the performance, which a wise and Christian parent cannot safely forego.

My last left us at Camp Madison, on mile beyond Green River. To-day finds us at the notorious Bell's Tavern, long the haunt of rebellion and daring treason. Here, for the past two months, has been the general rendezvous of the rebel General, HINDMAN, and his gang of Vandals.

The costly tribute which the country is daily rendering to the National cause, cannot be counted in contributions to the Treasury. Thousands of loyal lives must be added to make up the fearful aggregate. We read of brilliant victories, and the National heart is made glad. Rejoicings pervade the land.

The crew of the British steamer Fingal, which ran the blockade of Savannah, mentioned in yesterday's dispatch, were returned to Craney Island last night. No boat came out, however, to receive them and they were brought back. They were carried over again this morning, and sent back to Norfolk.

Lieut. Col. GEORGE ANDREWS, Sixth Infantry, U.S.A., who has been placed on the retired list in consequence of incapacity resulting from long and faithful service and exposure in the line of duty, is a native of the District of Columbia and a graduate of West Point.

A reconnoissance was made this morning from the division of Gen. SMITH, consisting of the Cameron Dragoons and three regiments of infantry, all under the command of Col. FRIEDMAN. The infantry separated for several points, namely: Vienna, Flint Hill and Hunter's Mills, to temporarily remain there as a reserve for the cavalry, while the latter proceeded towards Centreville, making a circuit within the lines of the rebel pickets.

The fifth lecture in the series was delivered at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Sunday evening, Feb. 16. Prof. AGASSIZ proposed to devote this and the closing lecture to the consideration of the question of the existence of Providence in nature, as demonstrated on purely scientific grounds. The Author of Nature may work by one of two methods, viz.: 1. By established laws, or 2. By direct action.

We have possession of Clarksville. The citizens being alarmed, two-thirds of them have fled, and having expressed my views and intentions to the Mayor and Hon. CAVE JOHNSON, at their request I have issued a proclamation, assuring all peaceably-disposed persons that they may with safety resume their businesavocations, requiring only the military stores and equipments to be given up, and holding the authorities responsible that this shall be done, without reservation.

To the Officers of the Third Division: In our present situation, where the different regiments are suffering in a most deplorable degree by sickness, it should be the earnest duty of all officers and commanders to do their best for the comfort and moral support of their men.

To-day, although it is the Sabbath, has been the liveliest which has been witnessed in Louisville for some months. From the earliest dawn, the rumbling of wagons was to be heard along the main avenues, and the army vehicles were to be seen in all the principal streets.

They fortified along the sea-coast, along the Potomac, in Eastern, Central and Western Kentucky, in Central and Western Tennessee, in Missouri, and elsewhere.

Prof. AGASSIZ commenced at Irving Hall, last Monday evening, a course of six lectures on Natural History, for the benefit of the Cabinet of Natural History at Cambridge University. A very large audience was present. The platform was occupied by the Committee of the Athenaeum Association, under whose auspices the lectures will be delivered.

A brief dispatch from Louisville announces that Cumberland Gap and Russellville are in possession of the National forces. This is highly important intelligence. Cumberland Gap will undoubtedly be held as a rallying point for the loyal East Tennesseans, and ultimately as a base of operations against Knoxville; and Russellville, it will be recollected, is the seat of the rebel "Provisional Government" of Kentucky.

The Emperor is delivered of his speech to the Chambers, and our friends breathe more freely! Our enemies here, and in England, expected the Emperor to lead off in condemnation of our Blockade and of the Charleston Harbor obstruction. So general was the expectation, that the paragraph declaring that our Government had done nothing to which Europe can rightfully object, was received with marked satisfaction throughhout the Chambers.
We have undoubtedly captured the rebel Gen. JOHNSON, at Fort Donelson, and the rebel Gen. PRICE, in Missouri; and now hold both of them as prisoners of war.

A dense fog set in on Sunday night, about 11 o'clock, which continued up to noon yesterday. In the morning a light wind blew from the southwest with frequent showers of rain. Twenty-four sail of square-rigged vessels were at anchor in the North River, outward bound, many of which had been de- tained by the prevailing easterly winds over a week.

Resolved, By the Senate and House of Representatives, that the thanks of Congress are due and are hereby presented to Maj.-Gens. HALLECK and GRANT, for planning the recent movements within their respective divisions, and to both these Generals, as well as to the officers and men under their command, for achieving the glorious victories in which these movements resulted.

Notwithstanding the exciting news recently received from Roanoke Island, and the defeat of the comparatively small number of Confederate troops there by a fleet of gunboats and a large and welldrilled army, the principal subject of interest here now is the battle at Fort Donelson. The Yankee nation, elevated by the recent victories of its hireling armies, is entirely certain of the speedy and thorough subjugation of the South. It laughs to scorn any idea of any other possibility, and exults in delicious day-dreams of the degradation to which its enemy will be reduced. It glories in the consciousness of its brute strength, and intends to exercise it in the spirit of a brute.

By the capture of Nashville, we obtain possession of the largest city in the rebel States which has yet been occupied by our troops. Nashville, the capital of the State of Tennessee, is a city of 30,000 inhabitants. It is situated on the Cumberland River 200 miles (following the windings of the stream) above its junction with the Ohio. The city is built chiefly on the south side of the river'

The American Exchange Bank vs. George Webb and Cornelius Minor. This action was brought by the plaintiffs claiming as judgment creditors, to set aside a voluntary assignment of real and leasehold property made by the defendant Webb to the defendant Minor.

A fight occurred on White Oak Creek, in Campbell County, near Boston, on the 22d of January, of which Capt. ROBINSON, who commanded the expedition, gives us the following particulars: The Lincolnites had about 200 men, while we had only about 40 being a part of Capt. ROBINSON'S company and a part of a company of Minute Men under Capt. RICHARDSON.

Capt. NICHOLS, of the Petersburgh Artillery, arrived here this afternoon from Winton, where he had been stationed with a battery. On yesternay he was shelled out by the Yankees. They had seven steamers, all of which had passed up the river. Capt. NICHOLS had a horse shot from under him. Two of his men were wounded. The town of Winton is in ashes. Our troops retreat to Murfreesborough."

The auspices under which Mr. JEFF. DAVIS delivered his Inaugural on last Saturday, were certainly gloomy enough for him and his socalled Government. His throne, ere it had been well set up, was tottering to its base; the ground was sliding from under his feet; the air was thick with ill omens, and the lightning brought him messages of disaster by every wire.

The damages by the violent northwest gale of yesterday are extensive. The lofty steeple of the Thirteenth-street Baptist Church was blown down; its weighty and massive bell entirely crushed in the roof and side walls, leaving only the front and east wells standing. The injury is estimated at $10,000. The north wail in falling crushed in the walls of an adjoining dwelling.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara arrived at Boston from Halifax at 7 o'clock on Monday evening' and her mails were forwarded by the 8:30 P.M, train' due in this City at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. The train was detained on the route, however, by a heavy fall of snow, and our news packages did not reach us until last evening.

Edward Gould vs. William Mesick. This action was brought to recover the sum of $1,758, for merchandise sold by the firm of Rushmore, Cone Co., of this City, to the defendant. Rushmore Cone Co. assigned their claim to the plaintiff.
The United Staten steam transport Constitution Capt. FLETCHER, arrived on Monday evening, after a passage of six days. She does not bring any news of interest.

The steamship North Star, from Aspinwell, on the 15th inst., arrived at this port, yesterday morning, with mails, passengers, and treasure from California. The treasure list foots up $759,246. The news brought by the North Star is unusally uninteresting.

In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Anne M. Jennings, a German girl, 18 years of age, was tried for a felonious assault upon Gerhart Kieselhaus, and acquitted. It appeared that the complainant, Kieselhans, called at the premises of the prisoner's mother and behaved in a very rude and insulting manner toward the prisoner, whereupon he was ejected from the premises by the mother.

On motion of Mr. VAN VESSENDEN, of NewYork, (Rep.,) the motion agreeing to the report of the Committee of Conference on the Treasury Note bill was reconsidered, and the Senate disagreed to the report, and the bill was recommitted to the Committee of Conference.

This City has reason to be thankful for the excellent management of the Metropolitan Board of Police. The former slip-shod guardians of society, who used to hang about corner-groceries, and were in intimate relations of friendship with gamblers and pimps, are replaced by a well-dressed, orderly, disciplined force, with much esprit du corps, who are a real terror to evil doers.

Stephen Hallett, the father of the testatrix, owned all that valuable property known as "Hallett's Cove," in the village of Astoria, Long Island.

We notice that the House of Representatives, on Tuesday, passed a bill establishing a new Judicial District in this State. It diminishes the territory of this Southern District a little, but practically the only effect of it will be to divide the Northern District into two and this makes the remarks of Mr. DIVEN, who reported the bill, seem rather extraordinary, if correctly reported.

Both Houses of the Legislature met last evening, and both, contrary to the expectations of those conversant with the tardiness of members, generally, to return, had a working quorum, and disposed of a number of bills on the "general order" list.

A Fort Donelson dispatch to the Democrat of yesterday, says a boat just from Clarksville reports the evacuation of Nashville. The Union citizens of that place sent a boat to Clarksville, which towed one of our gunboats for their protection. The rebels, with Gov. HARRIS, retreated to Murfreesboro. HARRIS burned all the State documents before leaving.

Now that the legislators and the Convention delegates have returned to their homes in the various counties of the Territory, the city is sobering down to its ordinary quietness, and it is generally believed that the General Assembly of the Territory of Utah has met for the last time.

The House was engaged on Saturday in a discussion of the past and future conduct of the war. Mr. BOYCE, of South Carolina, argued at some length in advocacy of an offensive policy. The plan he proposed was the appointment of a Commander-in-Chief of the army, and leave to him the direction of military operations, and suggested TOOMBS, who possessed the revolutionary spirit.

The NEW-YORK WEEKLY TIMES, No. 545, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, FULL DETAILS OF THE SIEGE OF FORT DONELSON, accompanied by Maps and Diagrams, from our special correspondents, together with the official report of Gen. GRANT.

Our London correspondent transmits us a copy of the "Blue-book" relating to American affairs just laid before the British Parliament. As might be expected, it is extremely voluminous, consisting of six distinct sets of documents, covering the whole ground on which correspondence has been had between the two Cabinets.

Col. WASHINGTON SEAWELL, Sixth Infantry, and Major WILLIAM AUSTINE, Third Artillery, have been placed on the retired list on acconnt of incapacity, caused by long and faithful service, exposure in the line of duty, etc. Col. SEAWELL is a native of Virginia, and after graduating at West Point, was appointed from that State on the 1st of July, 1825, to a Brevet Second Lieutenancy in the Seventh Infantry.

Rev. Dr. VINTON, of Trinity Church, lectured last evening, at Irving Hall, before the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, on "The Cause and Cure of the Rebellion." He denied the right of revolution, the supremacy of State sovereignty, or the ennobling influences of Slavery, and saw in the triumph of the Union and the Constitution, and the laws, the only cure for the rebellion.

In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, James J. Wall, who was last week convicted of manslaughter in the second degree, in killing Owen Phelan, at Harlem, on the 31st day of December last was sentenced to the State Prison for four years and six months.

We seem destined to be blessed with a great variety of new postal laws. Our Congressional Post-office Committees, after sleeping for years, have at last waked up to the idea that our Post-office can be improved.

The President of the United States, yesterday, approved the Loan and Treasury bill perfected by Congress the day before, and this measure is now the law of the land. It creates a National Currency of United States Notes of the denominations of five dollars and upwards, made lawful money, and a legal tender for all debts, public and private,

The exultation of the North over the late success to their arms is as extravagant and delirious as their terror last Summer and depression through the Autumn. For this we night be well prepared. We are by this time sufficiently well acquainted with the Yankee character to understand their delusions, their panics, manias, excitements, unreasonable hopes and fears, and to give them the contempt that instability and levity merit.

Yesterday morning, soon after daylight, four armored gunboats, one wooden one, five transports partially filled with troops, and two mortarboats, left here in the direction of Columbus. Expectation--to use a not entirely original metaphor--stood on tiptoe. Everybody, including one or two reporters who had succeeded in getting an invitation to accompany the expedition, was nearly insane with relation to what the next twenty-four hours would bring forth.

JEFF. DAVIS' first regular Message to the "permanent" rebel Government is published this morning. It is a very curious and significant document. NORTH CAROLINIANS! Our country needs your aid for its protection and defence against an invading foe. The President of the Confederate States has made a requisition upon our State to complete her quota of troops in the field. Our own borders are invaded by the enemy in force, now threatening an advance, to deprive us of liberty, property, and all that we held dear as a self-governing and free people.

As a tittle varation from the incessant rain with which the Division of the Lower Potomac has been deluged for the last two months, that mythical personage, the clerk of the weather, treated us on Mondey last to a hurricane on a small scale. Tuesday, the gunboat Conestoga was ordered to proceed from Cairo to this place, for the purpose of conveying orders to such of the gunboat fleet as might be up the Cumberland River. The substance of the order was, I suppose, that all the boats which could be spared, should, together with the mortarboats, report immediately at Cairo, with a view to operations down the Mississippi River.

Col. WOOD yesterday morning proceeded to his home near Jamaica, L.I., where he met with a warm reception at the hands of his neighbors. The military, firemen and citizens turned out in full force, and escorted him to his house.

It is reported that insurances are daily effected on ships and their cargoes to run the blockade of the Southern ports. The highest premium paid is fifteen guineas, and the ships are entitled to select any port. In some instances the risk to ports easy of access are as low se ten guineas. Nearly all the vessels insured are steamers of 1,500 tons.

A large meeting was held at the Cooper Institute last evening, responsive to a call for a meeting to forward some plan for the regeneration of the army of outcast women of New-York. Ex-Mayor TIRMANN presided, and introduced the speaker of the evening, Miss EMMA HARDINGE.
James B. Colagate, vs. D.P. Buckingham -This was an action on a note made by the defendant, and given to the Granite Insurance Company the defendant receiving the scrip of that Company for it.

The resolution was passed.

There can be no longer any doubt touching the intention of the Allies to make an effort to impose a king on Mexico. Earl RUSSELL'S declaration, in a letter quoted in these columns the other day sets the matter at rest. "If the Mexican people," says his lordship, "by a spontaneous movement place the Austrian Archduke on the throne, there is nothing in the Convention to prevent it." Of course not.

On Wednesday night Capt. MONTGOMERY, of WRIGHT'S Battalion, with his company, was surprised at Keittsville, Barry County, by 850 rebels, supposed to belong to McBRIDE'S Division, but who represented themselves as Texan rangers. They fired into the house occupied by our men, killing two and wounding one. One of the rebels was killed. The balance fled, taking with them about seventy horses.

The third sale of Government cotton took place yesterday at the Atlantic Dock, Brooklyn. One hundred and sixty-four bales were sold, varying in price from 25 to 53 cents. Thirty-four more bales were offered, but were not sold, owing to 45 cents only being offered for them. For the future Government cotton will be sent to a foreign market for disposal.

According to a recent report, the number of paupers in England, which amounted to 835,129 at the end of the year 1860, has this year reached 892,990, showing an increase of about 58,000 during a year. The Nashville, from Southampton, has arrived at Beaufort, N.C. She passed our squadron with the Union flag flying, and then raised the rebel flag, and went into the harbor unmolested. She was loaded with bank paper and other valuables to a large amount, but had no ammunition on board.
COTTON The sales yesterday (Saturday) reached 8,000 bales, including 3,000 bales to speculators and exporters. The market remained firm, at unchanged quotations.
Mr. MINISTER: I have just received your dispatch, of the 30th December, and thank you for the intelligence you give on the affair of the Trent.

The new sloops-of-war Oneida and Octorara have returned to the Brooklyn Navy-yard, after very Successful trial trips. The officers' report to Commodore PAULDING are quite satisfactory. These vessels are already in commission, and may sail at any moment after taking in fresh provisions.
The brig Lincoln, from Elizabethport for Boston, struck on Minot's Ledge this morning and sunk; crew saved.

The Postmaster-General to-day addressed a let ter to the Post-office Committee of both branches, on the refusal of Commodore VANDERBILT to carry the South American mails, and insists upon legislation which will prevent the Government from being subject to the dictation of railroads and steamboat capitalists. The Committee intend to bring the matter at once to the attention of Congress, with a view of securing the necessary legislation.

The Committee on the Affairs of Cities had a session yesterday afternoon upon the proposed amendments to the City Charter. The advocates of the amendments said something in their favor, but in addition presented so modifications of the proposed printed amendments that but little progress was made.

Mr. FOLGER introduced a bill to promote the public peace on Sunday. It prohibits the sale of anything on Sunday except meat, milk and fish, and these before 9 o'clock in the morning; makes the violation of the law a misdemeanor, punishable with a fine of $50 for each offence.

In the Assembly on the 1st inst., when the bill to provide for the Public Defence was taken up in Committee of the whole, Mr. PHELPS, of New-York, said he did not intend to enter into any lengthened debate upon this question, which had already been very fully discussed, and on which many members of that body yet desired to be heard.

There have been no movements of special importance at the Brooklyn Navy-yard since Thursday. The two ship-houses are undergoing a thorough overhauling. No. 2 Ship-house, in which the frigate Lackawana is being constructed, is undergoing repairs to the roof, rendered necessary by the recent storm, and is also having additional windows put in for the convenience of the workmen.

The President has placed Richmond under the protection of martial law. If the entire Southern Confederacy were at this moment under that law, there would be a benefit to its cause, to its Government, and to every single citizen of its population.

The O'DONOGHUE moved an address for return of the number of British vessels, with the names, as far as can be ascertained, of their captains and owners respectively, that have succeeded, within the past six months, in running the blockade of the Southern ports of America.

We learn from St. Louis that Capt. W.D. PORTER is rapidly recovering from the injuries received during the bombardment of Fort Henry.
Readers of the TIMES are not recommended to believe that ROBERT TOOMBS has been made Lieutenant-General of the Confederate Army, with orders to carry the war into Pennsylvania and Ohio.

In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to prevent trade on the Sabbath was reported favorably, and the bill to amend the Usury laws was reported unfavorably. A bill to incorporate the Loaners' Association in this City was introduced; also, a general bill regardinq the construction of railroads in the State.

The message of President LINCOLN, suggesting the passage of a joint resolution providing for cooperation with any State for the abolition of Slavery, with pecuniary compensation, was read and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

By the steamer Mount Vernon, which arrived here yesterday afternoon, we hear of a serious disaster to the steamship Mississippi, chartered by the Government to carry troops to Ship Island, which sailed hence, with Gen. BEN. BUTLER and Staff on board, a few days since.
The bill to prevent trade on Sunday was favorably reported.

The more the President's Message is discussed the more difficult is it to define the position of parties in regard to it. One great point, however, is gained the subject is universally discussed with more calmness than has ever before characterized a question about Slavery.

SHERMAN, with six gunboats and four mortarbeats, the Twenty-seventh, Forty-second and Forty-fourth Illinois, and Seventy-first Ohio, left here this morning at daylight, for Columbus, which place they reached at 9 o'clock, and found it occupied by 250 of the Second Illinois Cavalry, under command of Lieut.-Col. Hon. ANDREW JOHNSON, Brigadier-General and Provisional Governor of Tennessee, left Washington yesterday afternoon for Nashville, accompanied by Hon. HORACE MAYNARD, Hon. EMERSON ETHERIDGE and others.

The House, last night, devoted the whole session to the discussion of the details of the Annual Appropriation bill, and did not then complete the bill. The appropriation for books for the State Library was cut down from $4,000 to $2,000, and, on motion of Mr. STETSON, backed by Mr. PHELPS, of your City, the appropriation to the Agricultural Societies was raised to $10,000 from $8,000, as reported.

In the Senate, yesterday, the Special Message of the President, relative to cooperation with States desiring to abolish Slavery, was read and referred to the Judiciary Committee. A memorial from merchants of New-York, asking immediate action to provide for the transportation of the mails to Panama, was presented.
The newspaper packages by the Canada, with dates from Liverpool to Feb. 22, were received here last evening.

SINGER Co.

GOUPIL Co., or rather their successor, Mr. K NOEDLER. have reopened their attractive gallery within the week, and offer to the lovers of art several rare and peculiar specimens. A portrait, half-length of GOTTSCHALK, while eminently correct and faithful as a likeness, is too Frenchy for the popular taste on this side the water.
Nothing of importance in a military view has transpired since the last dispatch. Some transitions of troops have taken place, but nothing to indicate any especial movement.

The exact time at which the French Emperor conceived or received the idea of placing a Hapsburg on a Mexican throne, is a matter of controversy. A dispatch of M. THOUVENEL distinctly declares the project not to be of French origin at all.

The following letter explains the position of Gen. J.H. LANE: LEAVENWORTH, Kansas, Feb, 26, 1862. SIR: There should be a perfect understanding between you, the local Representatives of the people of Kansas, and your Representatives in the National Congress. To this end, I make the following state- ment:

A PICKPOCKET ON THE CITY CARS. AN EXCITING SCENE. Yesterday afternoon a very exciting scene occurred in the neighborhood of Canal and Hudson streets, owing to the ingenious exploits of a pickpocket on one of our City cars. Capt. JACOB BUSH, of the schooner John J. Houseman, drew from the Manattan Bank the sum of $250, in specie, and deposited it in a woolen mitten in a pocket of his overcoat.

We made an advance on Saturday, demonstrating what we have all along suspected, that the enemy are determined not to make even a show of resistance anywhere in the neighborhood of Nashville. To crawl up at night and shoot a man or two on picket duty, seems to be the height of their ambition. They do not dare even to show themselves in broad daylight, at however remote a distance.

The two leading features of the battle were the storming of the enemy's works by Gen. SMITH'S Division on our extreme left, and their attack on our extreme right, where they advanced from their works and attempted to cut their way out, and where the conflict raged with varying fortunes during the most of the day.
THE ARMY OF THE POTOMAC. The arrangement of the army of the Potomac into corps d'armee is in harmony with Gen. McCLELLAN'S plans. It will not require over a week to perfect this reorganization.

It is an interesting study to note the difference at the present time in the South between the vaporing, gasconading followers and the clear-eyed military leader. The former talk loudly of all possible terrible means of war fare: of fearful and mysterious torpedoes, of mule-mounted cannon, of murderous machines; they propose to meet the iron-clad

Last night Col. GEARY left Lovettsville, with his whole command, and marched through Wheatland and Waterford, taking prisoners at both places, and putting the scattered forces of the rebels to flight. Shortly after sunrise he took possession of Fort Johnson, which was rechristened by the officers Fort Geary.

Recently the Illinois Constitutional Convention, now in session at Springfield, adopted a resolution ordering an inquiry into the condition of the troops which that State had put in the field. Mr. JAMES W. SINGLTON, Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs, undertook to act in accordance with these instructions, and received the following letter in reply to one of his notes of inquiry:

On the 9th inst. we had an addition to our fleet in the store-ship Release, Capt. UPTON. She is to be turned temporarily, I suppose into a gunboat. She has received on board a Dahlgren rifled howitzer, and with her other two 32-pounders makes a formidable appearance.
The following news was received, here, to-day by military express: A desperate and terrible battle, lasting all day, took place at Valverde, ten miles south of Fort Craig, on the 2lst of February.

The rebel army, in its haste to get away from Murfreesboro, is releasing many individuals who were held in confinement on account of their supposed unwillingness to see the National Government overthrown by traitors.
A special dispatch to the Cairo Times says that thirty cannon have already been found at Columbus, which had been thrown away by the rebels in evacuating the place.

To Colonel Granville Moody, Commanding Camp Chase Ohio: SIR: The recent large addition of prisoners sent to the prison at Camp Chase for safe keeping, renders it highly necessary that more definite and specific instructions be given you for your guidance in the premises. I do, therefore, order:

The most important news this morning is from the Upper Potomac. Leesburgh is now in possession of the National forces. Col. GEARY, on Friday night, left Lovettsville with his whole command, and marching through Wheatland and Waterford, taking a number of prisoners on the way, reached the vicinity of Leesburgh at sunrise yes-
"An old Western pioneer," writing to the Methodist of this City, under date of St. Louis, March 1, sketches a remarkable scene which transpired at the recent meeting of the Missouri Conference:

The resolutions of the Legislature of this State, complaining of the inequalities and injustice existing in our commercial relations with Canada, under the present "Reciprocity Treaty," having been referred to the House Committee on Commerce, an elaborate report, giving much new and instructive information, has been presented to Congress through Hon. E. WARD.

The Louisville Journal furnishes the following paragraphs: JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE'S HABITS. We have just had an interview with a gentleman of high character who lives in Hopkinsville. He says that he heard a lieutenant in the rebel army speak of JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE as a common drunkard.
It is proposed to introduce into our public schools, as a part of the system of education, a course of physical training consisting principally of military drill.
Mr. FARRAR reported, for the consideration of the Senate, a bill to improve Central Park.

It was on the brightest of bright Winter days that I entered New-York. The sky was blue, with a more than Italian depth of color, and the hot sunlight sparkled brilliantly on the white snow-covered roofs. But for this I should at first have had but little sense of being in a strange country.

In my letter of the 2d instant, I stated that Columbus had been evacuated and burned by the rebels. This assertion was based upon observations made by the officers of the gunboats Cincinnati and Pittsburg the two vessels engaged in the reconnoisances of Sunday last. Since Monday all sorts of rumors have obtained circulation in Cairo.

On our way hither yesterday, Surgeon HUGHES kindly furnished me with a complete list of the killed and wounded of the Iowa regiments engaged in the late fight at Doneison. The list was only completed yesterday, and as but little or nothing in relation to the Iowa regiments has been published, I inclose it:

The funeral of Gen. LANDER at Salem, this afternoon, was an imposing and solemn event. The body was escorted by a procession consisting of the four local military companies of Salem; the Boston Divisionary Corps of Cadets; a detachment of the Andrew Sharpshooters, who accompanied the remains home; Gov. ANDREW and Staff; the Municipal Authorities of Salem; the Fire Department; Officers
The Petersburgh Express contains the following account of the adventures of Col. CORCORAN and his companions, while spending a day in that city:

The President of the Confederate States has called upon the Executive of the State of Alabama to furnish twelve additional regiments to serve for three years, or during the war. A similar call has been made upon the other States, in proportion to their white population. This requisition is made necessary by the mighty power which the Lincoln despotism is now putting forth for our subjugation.
The Clarksville (Tenn.) Jeffersonian of Feb. 15 the last number issued, has this paragraph:
In acknowledging the receipt of late Nashville papers the Louisville Journal says:

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The special correspondent of the Tribune has done Gen. STEVENS the grossest injustice in a letter which was published in the Daily Tribune of Feb. 14 and which reached us yesterday. I will cut the extracts, and remark upon each:

A gentleman who left Nashville on Saturday evening informs us that the railroad connection between that city and Louisville is complete, save as to the bridge ten miles this side of Nashville, which was slightly damaged by water on Saturday evening.

The panic has subsided, and quietude takes the place of consternation. Contrary to the expectations of many, none of our troops are quartered in the city. Col. STANLEY MATTHEWS, of the Fifty-first Ohio, has been appointed Provost-Marshal. Under his military regimen the place is rapidly assuming its ancient appearance, and ere long reason will again control a people who have been maddened by the infatuation of secession.

Passing through the grounds of Fortress Monroe this morning, I directed my footsteps toward a substantial-looking mansion, in front of which a Zouave was pacing to and fro on guard, his uniform and equipments giving evidence of discipline and cleanliness. We inquired in what direction could be found the quarters of the General.

A dispatch to the Appeal, dated Jackson, Miss., Feb. 17, says: "A proclamation has been issued calling upon every citizen, able to bear arms, to have his arms in readiness. Troops are enlisted under the call for seven regiments to rendezvous at Grenada and Corieth.

A flag of truce from Norfolk to-day brought down the commandant of the French steamer. He represents that there is great excitement at Norfolk. The hotels are swarming with officers from the Gulf States. The Virginia troops have all been sent away. The people dread the destruction of the city in case of an attack.
A correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette gives the following sketch of the popular feeling at Clarksville:

Hon. W. P. HALL, Acting Governor of Missouri and a number of other prominent citizens, recently invites, Gen. HALLECK to accept a public dinner, in testimony of their appreciation of the gallant services which he has rendered the National cause. The General replied as follows:
Capt. J.T. DREW writes from Columbia, S.C. under date of Feb. 14, to the Burlington (Vt.) Free Press:

We had an opportunity yesterday of conversing with a gentleman who left Memphis last Saturday, and reached St. Louis yesterday morning. He came to New-Madrid by boat, thence by land to Price's Landing, where he crossed the river to Illinois, reaching the Central Railroad. He has been a citizen of St. Louis, but for some time past has been living at Memphis.

Gen. BUELL, with a large force, entered Nashville yesterday without opposition, and established the glorious flag of our Union in the Capital of Tennessee, and it is hoped that it is now, with the greater part of our State, fully redeemed from the braggart rebels, and that the rebellion in the South will be speedily put an end to.

By direction of Major-Gen. McCLELLAN, the following tariff of exchange of prisoners of war, adopted between the United states and Great Britain in the war of 1812, is substituted for that given in Gene- ral Orders, No. 30, current series:
A correspondent of the Lynchburgh Republi- can, writing from Bowling Green, under date of the 13th inst., says:

Prof. AGASSIZ delivered on Friday, the 7th inst., the third lecture in his course on Natural History, before the New-York Athenaeum Association, at Irving Hall, where, as usual, a very large audience attended.

In the Senate, yesterday, a bill to improve the Central Park was reported for consideration. The bill, heretofore noticed, to amend the law of divorce, was passed; also, the bill to prevent and punish frauds in the use of false stamps and brands. A bill to close Avenue B, from the north side of One Hundred and Sixteenth-street to the south side of One Hundred and Twentieth-street was introduced by Mr. CONOLLY.

I see in the New-York papers a controversy about the relative merits of McCLELLAN and STANTON. This is entirely out of place and the more so, since we in the West, looking from another point of view, consider that discussion particularly unjust to other parties.
Major KIMBALL, who led Col. HAWKINS' Zouaves in the charge upon the rebel battery at Roanoke, was complimented with a supper by the citizens of Montpelier, Vt., a few evenings since.
List of Americans registered at GUN Co.'s American Agency and Reading Room, No. 10 Strand, London, W.C., England, week ending Feb. 22, 1862:

Under date of Cairo, Feb. 24, the correspondent of the Chicago Post writes: "A 'great scare' pervaded that interesting town (Peducah) during, and for several days subsequent to the battle of Donelson. The report came that BEAU- REGARD was marching from Columbus, at the head of twenty thousand men, to assault and capture the town.

The amendments to your City Charter occupied the attention of the Committee on the Affairs of Cities yesterday afternoon. Mr. PURSER appeared against the proposed amendments, and Councilman ORTON, Hon. RUFUS ANDREWS and Hon. DAVID R. JAQUES in their favor. Mr. PURSER consumed the whole sitting in an argument against them, objecting to almost every feature that is new.

To-day a Mr. CARTER, a member of BAYLOR'S Cavalry, together with three valuable horses, a carriage and other articles, were captured and turned over to the Division Quartermaster. A considerable amount of Confederate scrip was also seized.
A dispatch from Atlanta, Ga., says that the National troops have possession of Murfreesboro, Tenn., and that Gen. A. SYDNEY JOHNSTON has retreated to Decatur, Ala.
HOLBROOK'S United States Mail publishes a letter written by a lady, formerly a postmistress in South Carolina, who remained loyal to the last. She writes:
The following standing appeal appears in the Richmond Dispatch:

For a Sea-piece, that fulfills all the conditions of dramatic art as completely as it is possible for a real event to do, commend us to the recital of the battle of Hampton Roads, which we publish to-day.

In the Senate, on Saturday, a bill to improve the Central Park was reported for consideration. The bill, heretofore noticed, to amend the law of divorce, was passed; also, the bill to prevent and punish frauds in the use of false stamps and brands. A bill to close Avenue B, from the north side of One Hundred and Sixteenth-street to the south side of One Hundred and Twentieth-street, was introduced by Mr. CONOLLY.

A SING-SING CONVICT ARRESTED.?Officer WILSON, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct, made an important arrest on Saturday, at the house of Mr. PETER CRAWFORD, in Varick-street. The prisoner is known to the policy as JOHN ANDERSON, alias Wilson, and is by profession a burglar. He was sentenced to the State Prison, about five years ago, for the term of 15 years, for having committed a burglary in this City.

Daniel Ball et al. vs. Wiliam Award. This was an action on two promissory notes of $1,000 each. The defence set up was that defendant owed the plaintiffs $2,000, to be paid out of certain moneys coming to him from the State of Michigan, for work done for that State. That the $2,000 was not to be paid until defendant had received his money from the State of Michigan.

We have news of the most exciting character from Fortress Monroe. The rebel iron-clad steamer Merrimac, about which so much has been said recently, came down from Norfolk on Saturday morning, accompanied by the steamers Yorktown and Jamestown, also iron-clad, and moving directly toward Newport's News engaged the sailing frigates Cumberland and Congress,

Mr. GOTTSCHALK, assisted by the artists of the GRAU opera troupe, has given three concerts in Washington with great success, the sale of tickets having, we hear, to be suspended. The popular pianist will play in Baltimore and Philadelphia during the present week, and perhaps return to Washington. It is understood that he will give three subscription matin es in this City, on his way to the West.

The enemy's pickets were found advanced two miles this side of Vienna to-day, and our army was led to hope that the fact indicated an advance along the whole line, of which the Merrimac performance was a part.

The most intense excitement was created in Washington, to-day, by the news from Fortress Monroe, which came by the Baltimore boat. Visions were freely indulged in, of the Merrimac running the blockade of the fort, getting to sea, entering NewYork harbor, and burning all the shipping at

The recruiting returns for last week show that fifteen men were enlisted in this City for general ser- vice and for the Fifth Artillery and Eighth and Twelfth Infantry. A detachment of recruits, enlised in Roch- ester, arrived on Saturday, and were transferred to Governor's Island to be drilled for general service.

The movement of the main body of the Po- tomac army has begun in earnest. Having crossed at Harper's Ferry, Gen. BANKS has gradually and cautiously urged forward his division, occupying successively Charlestown, ...

"Sebastopol est prise!" I am sure that when this somewhat celebrated announcement followed the termination of the eleven months' seige of the Russian stronghold, it did not, as it flashed along the wires, create much more delight and astonishment than that which informed the people of the loyal States that Columbus was occupied by the National troops.

CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE ARMY. Mr. Dow, Chairman of the Army and Navy Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association, acknowledges the receipt of the following donations since the last report: From Thomas R. Hunt, socks, , for hospital; "Two Little Girls," dried peaches and apples; L. Serrel, hospital comforts; Ormand-place Congregational Church, hospital comforts, mittens, socks, ...

Mr. HAMILTON BRUCE, Deputy-Collector and Storekeeper of the Port of New-York, has just published a Warehouse Manual and General Custom-house Guide, which is spoken of in the highest terms. In all Custom-house matters Mr. BRUCE "is to the manner born," having had twenty-five years' service in them, in one capacity of another.

We have not space this morning in our overcrowded columns to give a report in full of a sermon delivered to an immense audience last night, by Rev. HESAY WARD BEECHER, on the policy of Emancipation as suggested to the recent Proclamation of President LINCOLN; but the general drift of the discourse may be understood from the following brief sketch.

Col. Geary has taken Leesburgh and driven Gen. Hill, with his whole command, from the town and surrounding forts. The Stars and Stripes now wave over all. Gen. HILL'S army fell back toward Middleburgh.

The report last night that our forces had occupied Leesburgh, is officially confirmed. The enemy evacuated the town on Friday morning, taking at their supplies and baggage to Middlebury, but it is not known whether the troops retired thither or started toward Winchester.
Major KIMBALL, who led Col. HAWKINS' Zouaves in the charge upon the rebel battery at Roanoke, was complimented with a supper by the citizens of Montpelier, Vt., a few evenings since.

Yesterday, for the first time since our arrival, country carriages came into town, and the occupants held social intercourse with our officers and soldiers. Suits of secession gray are gradually giving way to other hues, and the ladies beginning to frequent the streets on business and pleasure.

The telegraph line to Fortress Monroe is just completed, and a message from there states that after the arrival of the Monitor, last night, she was attacked by the Merrimac, Jamestown, and Yorktown. After a five hours' fight they were driven off, and the Merrimac put back to Norfolk in a sinking condition.

U.S. steam transport Josephine, Grumley, Locust Point, in baliast. Steamship Plantagenet, (Br., of Liverpool.) Beard, Liverpool Feb. 15, with indee to Waldon Booth. From Flemish Cap to Cape Breton Island passed large quantities of field ice and several iceberge; has had strong westerly gales most of the passage.

The telegraph line to Fortress Monroe was built by order of the Secretary of War, under the direction of the General Manager of Military Telegraph Lines. The extension of the Government line from Harrington, Del., to Cape Charles, was constructed in twenty-three days. Thirty miles of the submarine cable was manufactured for the channel crossing in twenty days from the date of the order, by S.C. BISHOP, of New-York City.

In the Senate, yesterday, a number of petitions and memorials on various subjects were presented ?among them a memorial asking Congress to permit no abridgment of the liberty of the Press. A bill to fulfill treaty stipulations with Hanover, regarding the abolition of the Stadt dues, was passed. A joint resolution was offered by Mr.

Dispatches from Flag-Officer GOLDSBOROUGH, received at the Navy Department to-day, include the report of Commander ROWAN, commanding steamer Delaware, who furnishes an interesting account of his reconnoissance. On the 16th of February be moved his forces, and reaching Wiston, was in the act of letting go the anchor, when suddenly a force of North Carolina Volunteers opened a terrific fire of masketry and artillery on his vessel. Lieut. WISE arrived here this forenoon, bringing dispatches from Fortress Monroe. But few particulars have yet transpired, as his interview is not closed. The following items are reliable:

The following communication has been handed us for publication. We trust that the persevering efforts the gentleman to whom it is addressed is now making to bring the two countries within speaking distance of each other, will be crowned with success at an early day:

Before Justices Ingraham, Clerke and Leonard. The Board of Excise vs. Purity In this case and about fifty other, Mr. Justice LEONARD dismissed the complaints in the Court below, on the ground that they were commenced by Messrs. Sickles and Cashing, without the service of notice, as required by statute, upon the commissioners of Excise of an offense on part of the defendants.

The following is a report of the remarks made by Lord CLARENON PAGET, in the House of Commons, on the 29th ult., on this important subject:

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been; 54 bbls. Ashes, 10,072 bbls. Flour, 114 bbls, and 946 bags Corn Meal, 5,184 bushels Wheat, 845 bushels Corn, 3,001 bushels Rye, 6,493 bushels Barley, 4,363 bushels Oats, 8,956 pkgs. Provisions, and 2,385 bbls. Whisky.
Mr. PRUIN presented the petition of the Albany Institute to provide for the collection of statistics of the rebellion.

A gentleman who witnessed the naval engagement in Hampton Roads, on Saturday and Sunday, says that only one man was killed by the shelting of Newport's News. The fire of our ships had no effect on the Merrimac until the arrival of the Monitor. The

There is reason to believe the rebel army, that has so long threatened the capital of the union, is preparing for immediate retreat. The reports from the officer in command of the Potomac flotilla is that the batteries, which have decorated the right bank of the river, have been removed, the artillerists have gone, the blockade is ended. Mr. HARRIS, of New-York, (Rep.,) presented pettions in relation to homeopathic surgeons. Mr. HARRIS also presented a petition in favor of a bankrupt act.

Before Justices Ingraham, Clerks andn Leonard. Tunis S. Waring vs. Eleazar Ayres. This was an action to compel the specific performance of a contract respecting the conveyance of certain real estate The defence set up was that the contract was a nullity so far as any-obligations to convey lands was concerned, and that its provisions were too indefinite to be enforced. The action was tried before a referee, and judgment rendered for plaintiff.

The Navy Department has received the fol- lowing: BALTIMORE, March 10. To Hon. Gideon Welles, Secretary of Navy: I arrived this morning, and will come on in the next (four o'clock) train. The enemy has abandoned his heavy fortifications at St. Simons and Brunswick Georgia. Fort Clinch and Fernandina, and St. Marys, Florida, are ours.

Before Justice Shipman. John II. Meyers, the second mate of the ship Lammergeyer, was put on trial, charged with larceny on board. The captain of the ship was murdered by the steward, and after the murder, the ship putting back to London, suspicion being excited against the second mate, his baggage was searched, and several shirts marked with the Captain's name were found.
Yesterday in the Senate, M. BAROCHE, Minister without portfolio, replied to the attacks against the laws and the Government made by certain journals.

The long-expected Confederate steamer Merrimac has at last made her appearance, and yesterday afternoon, with the assistance of two gunboats which came out with her from Norfolk and Jamestown, down the James River, made an attack upon Newport's News and the naval vessels stationed at that place.

The discussion of the address in the Senate continues, and, we are compelled to say, it continues in the midst of storms. M. TROPLONG indeed opened the debate by inviting the assembly to calm and moderation, but the wise counsels of the President were thrown to the winds, and Saturday's sitting, even more so than those of the two preceding days,

Brunswick we described last Thursday, when the rumor of its evacuation by the rebels reached us. It is eighty miles from Savannah, is situated upon a bluff on Turtle River, and is a port of entry with a very fine harbor, with 13 feet of water over the bar at low tide. The town has but a hundred or two of resi-
