The United Sates steam gunboat Alabama, Capt. LANIER, arrived here this morning, direct from Fernandina, Fla., bringing Capt. DAVIS, late Flag-Officer of the South Atlantic Squadren, as bearer of dispatches from Commodore DUPONT to the Navy Department, announcing the capture of Fernandina and Brunswick by the fleet under his command.

The capture of Fernandina and the forts defending it., and the rout of the rebels there stationed, virtually gives us military possession of the entire State of Florida. Through Fernandina we control the whole eastern coast line of the peninsula. On the

By the arrival of the screw steamship City of Washington at this port, we have advices from Europe four days later. She left Liverpool on the 26th, and Queenstown on the 27th ult. There is very little political news of importance. The Liverpool cotton market was firm, and prices were unchanged. Breadstuffs were quiet and steady, and Provisions dull. Consols were quoted at 93 for money.

To Hon. Gifson Welles, Secretary of the Navy; SIR: I have the honor to inform you that yesterday, at 1 o'clock, one the look-out vessels reported by signal that the enemy was coming out. I immediately ordered the Minnesota to get under way, and as soon as the two tags appointed to how this ship came alongside, I shipped our cable. The Merri-
The funds continued firm and advancing. On the afternoon of the 26th ult., Consols Stood at 93 @ 3/8 for money and account.
QUARTREL'S band entered Aubry, Kansas, on the 7th, killed five men, and stole fifteen or twenty horses.

The Assembly met at 7 o'clock. A number of petitions being presented to allow the Supervisors of Madison County to grant licenses, a struggle took place in reference thereto, the prohibitory men desiring they should be referred to the Select Committee on Excise. The petitions, after a long debate, were referred to the Committee of the Whole.

A special dispatch to the Republican, from Cairo, says Gen. POPE'S forces have reached New Madrid, and heavy cannonading had been heard in that direction. The enemy are there in strong force and gunboats from here will soon move down to assist Gen. POPE'S force. The enemy have been endeavoring to drive the latter back by throwing shells among them from their boats.
The screw-steamer City of Washington, Capt. BROOKS, which sailed from Liverpool at 3 P.M. on the 26th, and from Queenstown on the 27th ultimo, arrived here yesterday morning.

The tide of triumph has set in so steadily and persistently, that it is difficult to keep with the torrent. A victory at the West is echoed by one from the East, and the sound scarcely dies away before the reverberation from a yet more distant West falls on the car. To-day we announce the splendid result of the pursuit of Gen. PRICE, It will be remem
The Minnesota had not been got off when so reported yesterday, but was finally got off during the night, and returned to her usual station at the entrance to the Recas, She is again ready for action.

Our readers will recollect in the diplomatic correspondence between Mr. SEWARD and Lord LYONS, published some time since, a complaint on the part of the latter of the conduct of one of our vessels, which, having taken a prize, sent her into port with the English flag flying under the American flag, and Mr. SEWARD'S prompt disavowal and apology for the act.

Before Justices Ingraham, Clerke and Leonard. The People ex rel. Brownson vs. The Marine Court. This was an application for a writ of prohibi- tion to restrain the Marine Court from exceeding its jurisdiction in the trial of a cause. The motion was made at Special Term and denied. Appeal was then taken to this Court.
The waning fortune of the Great Rebellion may be read this morning in the following brief synopsis of the principal news given in the TIMES:

We give in another column an abstract of an elaborte memorial to Congress, recapitulating the great features of the Stevens Battery, as approved by the whole Board of Gov- ernment Examiners, completely refuting the objections of the majority, and setting forth, in detail, the fighting qualities and the results of experiments relative to that vessel.

My dispatch last night stated that the appearance of rebel scouts near Vienna was a feint, to cover their retreat. The latter part of the message failed to reach you why, I know not, as it would have informed you of the great event that to-day convulses Washington the general abandonment by the rebels of their Potomac line of defences.

Lient. GWIN, in command of the United States gunboat Taylor, writes to Flag-officer FOOTE, from Cairo, under date of March 5, which is forwarded to the Navy Department by that officer, that he has just returned from up the Tennessee River, having left Pittsburgh, the place of the late engagement, on the night of the 4th inst. He reports that the enemy had
The House considered the Senate bill providing for the appointment of sutlers in the volunteer service, and defining their duties.
It is currently rumored and believed that Winchester was fully evacuated yesterday. A reconnoissance is out this morning to ascertain the facts.

Never, on any occasion, were greater successes chronicled than those we placed before our readers yesterday. Never was a campaign carried on, on a grander scale; nor one so well calculated to impress the imagination by the vastness of its plans, or the manner of their execution.

In the stormy debates which are now going on in the French Senate and Chamber of Deputies, the American question thus far has attracted but little attention. In the address to the throne in both Houses, the neutrality principle of the Government was warmly approved.
The papers relative to the blockade of the- Southern ports had been submitted to the British Parliament.
The New-Hampshire State election took place yesterday, and resulted in the reelection of Gov. BERRY, by an increased majority.

Before Justices Ingraham, Clerke and Leonard. James Shepherd vs. the People of the State of New-York Shepherd was tried at General Sessions, in December, 1857, for arson in the first degree, and found guilty. The offence alleged in the indictment was charged to have been committed in June, 1857. Sentence of death was pronounced upon him Dec. 21, 1857, and he was ordered to be executed on the 8th day of the following February.

The intelligence of the evacuation of Winchester, yesterday, was premature. It was Berryville that the reconnoissance reported evacuated. The latest intelligence from Winchester is to the effect that the town is occupied by at least one brigade of infantry. Other troops are also there. There is a strong suspicion that a portion of the forces which evacuated Centreville have been ordered to reinforce Winchester.

Mr. FOLGER, by consent, introduced a bill to amend the act for the speedy payment of the volunteers of the State, passed a few days since, in order to obviate the difficulty that has arisen between the State and General Government. Read a third time and passed.
A special to the Tribune from Cairo says that the bridges of the Cairo and Fulton Railroad are repaired, and trains run regularly from Bird's Point to Sikestown.

FLOUR dull. WHEAT 1c. lower; Sales at 78 c. @79c. for No. 1. CORN quiet and steady. MESS PORK dull at $11. BULK MEATS quiet. HOGS Dressed 5c.@ 10c. higher; sales at $3.30@$3.40; light, $3.60@$3.65; heavy live, fair supply at $3@$3.20. Prime BEEF CATTLE, fair shipping demand at $2.80@$3.25. Re- ceipts 2,500 bbls. Flour, 18,000 bushels Wheat, 10,000 bushels Corn, 1,100 Live Hogs, 600 Dressed. Exchange and Gold unchanged.
The boat from Old Point has arrived, but brings little news that has not been already telegraphed.
The steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 27th, via Londonderry on the 28th of February, arrived here at 7 o'clock this morning.

By the arrival of the steamship North American at Portland, we have advices frow Europe one day later than were received by the City of Washington. She left Liverpool on the 27th, and Londonderry on the 28th ult. The papers relating to our blockade had been laid before the British Parliament.
A meeting of the Clearing-house Association was this day held at the Clearing-house. GEO. S. COE, Esq,, on behalf of the Clearing-house Committee, reported:

Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) presented petitions for emancipation. Mr. SUMNER, from the Committee of Foreign Relations, reported on several memorials in relation to giving relief to Ireland, and asked to be discharged, also to be discharged from the consideration of the papers in relation to the Trent affair.

The general recognition by the public Press of all parties, and all degrees of opinion, on the subject of Slavery, of the conservative spirit of the President's Special Message, is a gratifying sign of the era of good feeling which is soon to succeed the present expiring rebellion.

Steamships Northern Light, Tinklepaugh, Aspinwall, D.B. Allen; Arabia, (Br.,) Shannon, Liverpool, E. Cunard. Ships Golden Gate, (clipper.) Thornhill, San Francisco, S.J. Reed Co.; D.H. Watgen, (Brem.,) Badger, Liverpool, Charles Euling.

At a time when we can reasonably look forward to a speedy supersedure of the blockade which for the past ten months the United States have established over the coast of the insurgent States, it is rather interesting to have assurance that the British Government considers it "effective."

Mr. BAKER, of New York, (Rep.,) introduced a bill, which was referred to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, for the establishment of a National Foundry at Chicago, Ill., and at Pittsburgh, Penn., and at Poughkeepsie, N.Y., for the fabrication of cannon and projectiles for the Government.

This was an action brought by the pliantiff, who is a baker, to recover damages alleged to have been sustained by him by reason of the flooding of his premises. The plaintiff claimed that the flooding was caused by the defective construction and bad condition of the sewers in Third avenue. The amount claimed is $1,519,66.

United States steam transport Philadelphia HENRY BARTON Commander, from Fort Pickens March 1, Fort Jefferson, Tortugas, March 4, and Key West March 6th, 8 A.M., arrived last night. The Philadelphia took out from New York 116 head of cattle and 50 sheep, and landed them all without losing one.

In the Senate, yesterday, a Bill to amend the Act for the speedy payment of the Volunteers of the State, passed a few days ago, so as to obviate the difficulty which has arisen between the State and General Governments, was passed. A Bill to repeal the Act to widen Tenth-avenue, Brooklyn, was reported.

Official information, to-day, reports that the enemy formerly encamped back of and below Occoquan have retreated, destroying everything they could not carry on their backs. They left on Saturday. Our troops took possession this morning, and were welcomed by a part of the inhabitants with great joy. Every boat in the vicinity, and anything that would float, had been destroyed. The rebels told the villagers they were going to fall back to the Rappahannock.

Manassas, the great Rebel stronghold in Virginia, has been evacuated, and the Union Flag now floats over the works there, which were occupied on Monday night by National troops. Persons in the vicinity allege that the evacuation was only recently resolved upon, and the removal of the guns was commenced only about a week ago the last rebel troops leaving on Friday last.

The rebels have evacuated Manassas. We occupied it this morning. Dispatches received at headquarters this forenoon stated positively that the rebels had not evacuated Winchester. If this is so, and those best authorized to know report it, Gen. JACKSON'S rebel army is assuredly cut off and will be captured.

A messenger who arrived this morning at 3 o'clock reports that the battle lasted from Thursday morning till Saturday evening, and that our loss was about 450 killed and wounded. The rebel loss was about 1,000 killed and wounded, and 1,000 taken prisoners, among them Col. McREA, of an Arkansas Regiment.

The location of the battle can be seen from any ordinary map of Arkansas, or of the United States. It was in the extreme northwestern part of the State, and in the northwesternmost county (Benton.) A range of hills (of the Ozark range) will be seen sweep [Continued on Eighth Page.]
Mr. GRAU announces that a short season of Italian opera will be given at the Academy of Music, commencing on Wednesday next. The novelty in preparation is AUBER'S celebrated "Masaniello."

Col. GEARY, Acting Brigadier-General of troops here, made a personal reconnoissance yesterday as far as CARTER'S Mills. The trail of the retreating enemy was blackened with the ruins of granaries, ashes of hay and grain stacks, fences, etc. He found the bridge over Goose Creek had been burned after our occupation here on Saturday. The enemy have completely fallen back. The command continues to make captures from rank Secessionists.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce, since our last, have been: 34 bbls. Ashes, 16,900 bbls. Flour, 345 bbls. and 1,002 bags Corn Meal, 7,216 bushels Wheat, 21,441 bushels Corn, 4,380 bushels Rye, 1,393 bushels Barley, 7,361 bushels Oats, 6,478 bushels Malt, 9,958 pkgs. Provisions and 2,733 bbls. Whisky.

The official bulletin of the National victory in Arkansas, leaves no doubt about the thoroughness with which the task of Gen. CURTIS has been done. The rebel force has been beaten and dispersed; hostile cavalry hang upon the rear of its escaping fragments. BEN McCULLOCH, the busiest of the conspirators in the Southwest, is among the slain. A better day's work has not been achieved since the war began.

The election for State Officers and the Legislature took place to-day. Three candidates for Governor were in the field, viz.: BERRRY, the present incumbent, supported by the Republicans; STARRE, Democrat, and WHEELER, nominated as an independent candidate. A majority is required to elect a Governor in this State. The following is the result for Governor in some of the leading towns:
The following is the official report of Gen. CURTIS to Gen. HALLECK:

About thirty State prisoners are now in prison here the prison, the engine-house rendered famous by JOHN BROWN. Among them are Lieut.-Col. WHITE of the Fifty-sixth Virginia, captured yesterday at Leesburgh, by Col. GEARY; and RITCHIE, also captured by GEARY, a farmer near Leesburgh, who stamped to death, at Ball's Bluff, a wounded soldier, while the latter was asking aid.
The purchased side-wheel steamer Ericsson arrived at the Yard yesterday, and was immediately floated into the dry-dock to be newly coppered, after which she will be armed and put into commission.

Matter of the Will of A.H.P. Edwards The executor of this will, Hon. Edwards Pierrepont, instituted this proceeding to obtain a judicial construction of the will. The case was stated in the TIMES of Feb. 6. The testator died in 1857, leaving no children. His personal estate was estimated at $132,000. The real estate, as stated, was unproductive, consisting mostly of wild lands in the State of Illinois. It was valued at $30,000.

Felt vs. Haye et al. Judgment reversed, and new trial ordered, costs to abide event. Pierrepont, Executor, vs. Edwards et, al. Judgment at Special Term modified as to payment of moneys out of income, according to opinion, and costs to be paid out of estate, and in other respects affirmed.

In this Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, Mary Thompson, an Irish girl, 25 years of age, was tried and convicted of stealing a gold watch and $7 in bank bills, from the pocket of Hamilton Brown, of No. 132 Sackett-street, Brooklyn, on the 18th ult. Remanded for sentence.

The United States transport Oriental, Captain TUZO, arrived at this port at 10 o'clock last night, from Key West and Port Royal. She left the former port on the 4th inst., at 4 P.M., and arrived off Port Royal at 4 P.M. of the 6th; was detained outside 20 hours for want of a pilot. She left Port Royal at 5 P.M. of the 8th, and experienced fine weather the entire passage.
This being General Order day, the bills of the calendar were taken up in Committee of the Whole. The bill to suppress Concert Saloons was taken up for consideration.

The following private letter, written by a gentleman of extended military experience, has been handed us for publication:

The Old Point beat has arrived. We learn through Lieut. HAYWARD that a copy of the Norfolk Day Book had reached Old Point. It contains a highly colored account of Saturday's fight, and pays a great compliment to the bravery of the crew of the Cumberland. It admits that some of the shot from that vessel entered the Merrimac. One shell killed 17 men and wounded Capt. BUCHANAN, who subsequently died.

In the Senate yesterday, petitions against emancipation, from Kentucky, were presented. The resolution for the expulsion of Mr. PEWELL, of Kentucky, was reported back from the Judiciary Committee, with a recommendation that it do not pass. The rage for testimonials is upon us, and not only with us, but with our brethren at the West. The Germans of Missouri have subscribed most liberally for a sword to be given to their favorite, Gen. FREMONT : Gen. SIGEL has also been a recipient, and we understand that Gen. ASBOTH will soon be.

This place is obtaining a prominence and importance of no factitious character, and during the few days which I have passed here, I lave learned much respecting the affairs of the island which should be of interest to the public.

A courier from the Union troops in the direction of Brentsville, Va., brings reports to 5 P.M. yesterday. Up to that time they had sustained Their difficult march with much fortitude, and but few lagged behind. All are much disappointed at the flight of the rebels. The smoke of burning property near Manassas can be plainly seen from camp.

Never was there a truer remark than, that of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, in his Inaugural, that the rebels had undertaken more than they could carry out. They started with the assumption of being a first-class Power; at the same time, in all that constitutes real strength,

A portion of the Union forces reached this point to-day. The infanty followed the railroad track; the cavalry and artillery came by a longer route. Two deserters, Irishmen, came into our camp before starting, and immediately joined Gen. MEAGHEE'S forces. They report that there are two hundred foreigners who had been impressed, now scattered through the woods, intending to join our forces.

CURTIS and the officers and men under his command, for their late brilliant victory in Arkansas, and sincerely sympathizing with the relations and friends of the officers and soldiers of the army who so bravely fell at Pea Ridge.

About 1 o'clock we make out, steaming down the Elizabeth River from Norfolk, the low, mastless hull of a floating battery. On she comes past the bristling batteries of Craney Island, whence ring the cheers of the rebel soldiery, past Pig Point, and now distinctly visible is the abortion of our glorious flag the Stars and Bars.

That was a remarkable admission of JEFF DAVIS, in his message to the rebel Congress, that his rebel Government "had attempted more than it had power to achieve." It stands out as one truth in the midst of a collection of remarkable falsehoods, true not only in the sense in which he meant it, but true in far more directions than he intended.
There is no change in the position of the Union army since my last report.

After two days' exploration for infernal machines, and to discover where the bluff had been mined, as was reported to have been done, Capt. W.A. SCHMITT and company, of the Twenty-seventh Regiment, discovered ridges of new earth, similar to Huges which are formed by covering up gas or water pipes in a city, and traced them to a cavern.

Four contrabands have escaped from across the river; their names are MANUEL WILKINS, GEMMA COOK, WASHINGTON ROBINSON and RICHARD STAIR. They have furnished the most important information of any contrabands that have ever left the enemy's lines. I herewith send you their statements.

The New-Haven Palladium had a correspondent on board the Cumberland, in the recent fight. He writes, under date of March 8:

OFFICIAL REBEL REPORT OF THE ENGAGEMENT. In the rebel Congress, on the 10th inst., the following communication was received from the rebel Executive, in response to the resolution of Mr. LYONS calling for the report of the naval battle in Hampton Roads. From the Suregon of the frigate Congress, who has arrived here from Newport's News, I have obtained some interesting and valuable facts in relation to the late naval battle in Hampton Roads, that have not before been published.
A special dispatch to the Democrat, from Cairo, March 12, says:

GEN. A.S. JOHNSTON Sir: Your order of the 12th of this month, transmitted to me by telegraph from Bowling Green to Cumberland City, reached me the same evening. It directed me to repair at once, with what force I could command, to the support of the garrison at Fort Donelson.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 782 is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, a graphic letter from our correspondent with the Burnside Expedition, and letters from other divisions of the army.

The Broadway Railroad project is again fairly before the State Legislature in a shape to invite intelligent discussion. The Railroad Committee in the Assembly has reported a bill authorizing the construction of the Road, on certain prescribed conditions.
Petitions were presented for an Industrial Home for cast-out women and for the passage of the Metropolitan Health bill and the Prohibitory amend- ment bill.
Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, (Union,) asked that the case of Mr. POWELL be taken up, as the Legislature of Kentucky were in session and would like to have the case settled.

The Senate has passed the Million Loan bill, allowing the banks to pay out the United States Treasury Notes in redemption of their circulation, and requiring the banks to receive these Treasury Notes "so long, and no longer, as said notes shall be and remain a legal tender, under the laws of the United States."

In the Senate yesterday several bills were reported favorably, among them the one to consolidate the several acts relative to the District Courts in this City. Notice was given of a bill for the appointment of a Receiver-General, and for the transfer to his hands of certain trust funds ...

Allow me to commend the wisdom and patriotism that shows itself in your urging upon Congress the completion of the Stevens Battery the most complete and powerful offensive and defensive implement of war that was ever attempted to be constructed in the history of the world.

Prof. Louis Aggasiz arrived from Cambridge yesterday morning, and in the evening lectured at Irving Hall. Prof. Agassiz leaves the Everett House this morning for home.
We understand that the Navy Department expresses a decided preference for thick plates of iron armor for ships in preference to several strata of thin plates of the same aggregate thickness.
All is quiet here. The Marrimac is being repaired at Norfolk. FORTRESS MONROE, Friday, March 14 P.M.

This afternoon, while twenty-six of our cavalry were foraging on the Strasburgh Road, three miles distant, they came upon a large barn, bearing evidence of having recently been occupied by ASHBY's men.
The special order, the bill for the reorganization of the militia, was postponed.

Jonathan C. Bryant et al vs. The American Telegraph Company This was an action to make the defendants liable for an alleged delay in transmitting telegraphic dispatch, to the extent of an indebtedness claimed to have been lost in consequence.

Another victory, or what is the same thing, another evacuation by the rebels, is chronicled this morning. New-Madrid is now in our possession the rebels having left it on Thursday night. Some fighting took place on Thursday between the rebel gunboats and our siege batteries. They left behind them a quantity of guns and stores. There is a report that Island No. 10 is also evacuated.

It is now about one year since the first Tariff Act of 1861 was passed; it is almost one year since the Rebellion became a settled fact, and war was rendered inevitable by the bombardment of Fort Sumter. The time is a fitting one for a review of the effects of the passage of the former and the influence of the latter on the commerce and foreign trade of our country.
The Royal Mail steamship Africa, which sailed from Liverpool at 9.30 on the morning of the 1st, and from Queenstown on the afternoon of the 2d instant' arrived here yesterday morning.

HAMILTON, yesterday afternoon, was waited upon by nearly all the officers of the Division to congratulate him on his advancement, and also to express profound regret at the necessity of his departure. The down train, with the Ninety-fourth Regiment on board, met with an accident. Five cars were thrown into the water near Tivoli, by a broken rail.

There are battles in history which are not merely the deadly struggle of two hostile forces, but which, from their dramatic character, or from their results, become events or eras in human affairs. Romance and philosophy both cluster around them, and however unimportant in themselves, they become turning points in history. Such we conceive was the naval battle of Saturday and Sunday in Hampton Roads.

The reader of our foreign news, received by the Africa, published yesterday morning, may have noticed the paragraph relating to German affairs, in which, under a double qualification and in a very misty way, allusion is made to the "question of Electoral Hesse," or Hesse Cassel, as the principality is generally called.

Of all schemers and planners, commend us to the Southern people. They were always so. They always were putting forth some marvelous idea, which was to bring about the most immense results, without trouble or expense. Speculators truly, who seemed always intent upon seizing those advantages at once which of right only follow long and ear nest toil, the very thing they most despised.

The down train on the Hudson River Railroad, last night, met with a serious accident. A broken rail threw five cars in the water, near Tivola, and six men belonging to the Ninety-fourth Regiment, which was aboard the train, were killed and ten others wounded. The train was detained two hours.

Mr. O'BRIEN'S bill provides that the Justices of the District Courts of New-York shall have power to open defaults to be made in any action commenced in said Courts on such terms as they shall deem just, and may allow such costs upon motion to open default in favor of the party obtaining judgment by default, and against the party in default, not to exceed $10.
Two deserters from the rebel army came in today and give interesting accounts of the stampede from Manassas.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: There is now before our Legislature a local matter which has been of great importance for many years, and is now more important than ever, since the National crisis has made individual economy the order of the day. I refer to the cab bills.

VERY CHRISTIAN-LIKE RESIGNATION. A frame of mind which resigns itself to whatever may befall, and finds "good in everything," is certainly one of the most desirable of blessings, especially when Providence puts one on the losing side of life. But the heroic lengths to which some of the rebel journalists carry this disposition are really sublime.

A naval expedition, composed of the gunboats Benton, Louisville, Cincinnati, Carondelet and Conestoga, under Flag-Officer FOOTE, left Cairo at 7 o'clock this morning. At Columbus they were joined by the Pitsburgh, St. Louis and Mound City, and were overtaken by eight mortar boats in tow of four steamers, with transports and ordnance boats. They arrived here at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

The Legislature of New-Jersey has appointed a Commission to set before the Naval Committee of Congress the great advantage and powerful claims of Perth Amboy as a permanent location for the Naval School, it having been determined to remove it from Newport. With all due reverence for the majestic sovereignty of New-Jersey, we shall set our face like flint against the proposal until the Legislature shall appoint a Commission for another, though cognate purpose.

Yesterday being St. Prtrick's Day, it was celebrated by our Irish citizens in the most magnificent manner. For years past there has not been so grand as parade. All the Irish Societies in this City and Brooklyn were represented. But the crowning feature of the day was the appearance of the gallant Sixty-ninth, the same that fought so nobly at the battle of Bull Run.
The noisy carnival is over, with its masqueradings, turbulence, licentiousness and tomfoolery that annual scene of dissipation when, as BYRON observes Gaiety on restless tiptoe hovers.

On BOARD THE MONITOR, Friday, March 14, 1862. The Monitor left the Navy-yard, New-York, Thursday, March 6. The vessel had been for several day previous with fires banked ready for a start, but delay after delay occurred, much to the disappointment of all on board. When on Thursday the order was given to start, both officers and men were very much delighted.

NEW MILITARY DEPARTMENT. A new Military Department has been created, composed of the States of South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, and Major-Gen. HUNTER has been assigned to its command. The headquarters are at Beaufort. Gen. HUNTER will rank Gen. SHERMAN, but this is not considered in a military sense as a supersedure of Gen. SHERMAN.

The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick celebrated the Anniversary of Ireland's Patron Saint by their customary dinner at the Metropolitan Hotel, last evening, the seventy-eighth meeting of the Society. The large dining-hall was set apart for the guests, tastefully ornamented with the interwined flags of Erin and America. The tables filled the room, and seated about three hundred guests.

The Marion leaves this port this afternoon with a mail for the Burnside Expedition. The mail closes at 3 P.M.
A communication from the Secretary of the Navy was received in answer to answer to the resolution asking why the Naval Academy had been removed from Annapolis.

Our dispatches still fail to bring us the information that Island No. 10 has fallen into our hands, though the result of the contest there can hardly be in doubt. A dispatch from Commodore FOOTE to the Navy Department, dated Wednesday, states that the island is harder to conquer than Colum- bus would have been, as the shores are lined with forts, each one commanding the one above it.

The latest advices from Nashville and more favorable to the gradually returning sense of loyalty to the Old Flag. Gov. ANDREW JOHNSON had arrived at the seat of the Tennessee Government, and after addressing the people of Nashville from the steps of his hotel, in a most feeling and effective style, was conducted to the Capitol, where he took formal pos- ...

Returns from nearly all the precincts of Accomac and Northampton Counties show that WATSON is ahead of SEGAR, for Congress, by nearly 100 votes. The result in Hampton Precinct, however, changes the result, and JOSEPH SEGAR is elected by 130 to 140 majority.

The action of the Government at Washington, in placing in the hands of ANDREW JOHNSON, United States Senator from Tennessee, the temporary Government that State, is one of the most important steps yet taken in the rebellion. It is really the first essay that has yet been made toward reconstruction.

Gen. HALLECK has issued the following orders; So much of the recent Department of the Ohio as is included in the present Department of Missouri, will be designated the District of Ohio, and will continue to be commanded by Major-Gen. BUELL.
To Flag-Officer L.M. Goldsborough, Commanding North Atlantic Blockading Squadron, Hampton Roads, Va.:

The House Committee on Judiciary, in their report made to-day, examine at large into the censorship of the Press. While they say that from want of qualification or proper discrimination on the part of the Censor has sprung much of the complaint made by the Press, they ramark that the censorship seems to have been without any clearly-defined limits, after the departure from the general agreement between Gen. McCLELLAN and the representatives of the Press.

THE SUSPENSION OF GEN. BLENKER. Gen. BLENKER has been suspended from his command, and it is thought will not return. Evidence of improper conduct has been found by the Committee on the Conduct of the War, and reported to the Senate to-day, and his nomination was unanimously rejected. The President, it is said, has been asked to bring SIGEL here to take his division.

The first principle of military or naval success is concentration of force. The force of a war vessel is the weight of her broadside. Iron mail, that the blow of a ton would shiver, might stand the blow of 500 pounds for hours. This much will certainly be admitted on all hands.

The Boston papers publish the following: NEW-YORK, March 11. MY DEAR SARGENT: I ac cept with great pleasure your congratulations, and assure you that every exertion will be made on my part to furnish the nation with war vessels that will enable us to defy Europe.

GENERAL ORDER NO. 4. By direction of the Secretary of War all cotton, tobacco and naval stores within this Department must be removed west of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad; or, if distant from any railroad or navigable stream, put in such places of security that then cannot be reached by the enemy.

An opportunity offering itself to reach Fortress Monroe by the way of the Potomac River, we gladly availed ourselves of the privilege. On board the boat we found that a fellow-correspondent and Professor LOWE, the celebrated aeronaut, were to be our traveling companions; we also learned from the Captain hat the boat would stop at various landings on the Virginia and Maryland side.

During the past week the slopes and hills in the immediate vicinity of Fairfax Court-house, thickly dotted with Union soldiers' tents, and exhibiting groups of baggage-wagons, lines of ordnance, masses of artillery and cavalry horses, and the outfittings and trappings of a large army, the soldiers themselves lounging carelessly upon the turf, or engaged in various pursuits, presented an attractive and interesting spectacle.

Late Eastern papers inform use that Mr. C.B. WAITE, of Chicago, has been appointed Associate Justice for the Territory of Utah, but nothing to said of whose successor he is to be. We but recently had four Judge appointees for this Territory KINNEY, CRADLEBAUGH, CROSBY, and FLENNIKEN.
All is quiet here. A severe northeast storm has been prevailing for the last two days.

Enough to say, that as the enemy ran into us on the starboard bow, she delivered a fire which was terrific, rendered more so by our being in the act of springing our starboard broadside on.

Clover Seed. On Sept. 17, 1861, the first parcel of new Clover arrived, which was readily...

ANDREW JOHNSON, EMERSON ETHERIDGE, HORACE MAYNARD, and other prominent Union exiles, arrived at a late hour of the evening before yesterday, and were welcomed on the other side by a number of friends, and conducted to the St. Cloud Hotel. The emotions of the distinguished loyalists upon treading once more securely the soil of their State may be easily imagined.

SOLDIERS: I assume this day the command of the army of the Mississippi, for the defence of our home steads and our liberties, and to resist the subjugation, spoliation and dishonor of our people. Our mothers and wives, our sisters and children, expect us to do our duty, even to the sacrifice of our lives.

The steamship Karnak arrived at this port last night, from Havana on the 15th and Nassau on the 17th inst. Advices from Vera Cruz to the 7th had reached Havana, but nothing of importance had transpired there. Small vessels continued to arrive at Havana, having run the blockade, with cotton.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The interest we take in the advance of the grand army, and the excitement attendant on a series of bloodless victories, are drawing our attention from our relations with Europe, and the importance of watching the movements of Powers that would be most happy to see this country dismembered, and a monarchy established where republican institutions are alone fitted to exist.

HON. JOHN HUTCHINS My Dear Sir: I address you with that freedom which should ever exist between constituent and representative. I ought to say that efforts of individuals in both Houses of Congress during the present session have been very satisfactory to the people here, and we trust that the action of the whole body will hereafter be equally so.
The investigation as to the circumstances attending the death of PAUL O'NEIL, shot on Tuesday morning last by Officer CONRADY, of the Ninth Precinct, was continued yesterday before Coroner HEGEMAN:

Last night the Provost-Marshal pounced upon a gambling-house recently opened, and arrested four of the proprietors and several officers. The latter were released on parole, and the others put in jail. The gambling apparatus and other property, amounting to five hundred dollars in value, were also captured.

The Artists' Reception in Brooklyn on Wednesday night was brilliantly successful. Everything was as it should be. The entire Academy was thrown open to the wandering guests, the full blaze of illumination was turned on, the choice spirits of the Philharmonic Orchestra played harmoniously, and every possible adjunct was provided that could secure comfort or produce pleasure.

Under Gen. HALLECK'S most Christian order, the wounded rebels sent to St. Louis are quartered in the fine hospitals of the Government, and treated in every respect like those of its own army. We visited a few of them at the hospitals on Fifth and Chestnutstreets, last week, with ladies acting under the Young Men's Christian Association. There were about thirty in the room visited, suffering from wounds and diseases.

Beyond the general fact that a large amount of Quartermaster's and Commissary's stores had fallen into our hands, nothing official has, as yet, transpired as to the quantity and quality of the spoils. This is owing, not to the slowness or indifference of the captors, but to the circumstance that the captured stores were scattered all over the city.

SIR: It becomes my painful duty to forward herewith a series of resolutions adopted by the commissioned officers of my regiment, expressive of their profound grief for the death of your gallant son, First Lieutenant HARRY B. HIDDEN, and in their name to condole with you in this your sad bereavement.

The First Georgia Regiment has been ordering home to be mustered out of service, their time having nearly expired. The Augusta Sentinel says this regiment has performed more labor, and seen more hard service than any regiment from that State; yet, notwithstanding this, nearly every man will immediately resuits.

The steamer Fulton, which has just returned from Ship Island, is expected to sail to-day or to-morrow for some place on the Southern coast, from which she will convey troops. She will not be absent more than two or three weeks, as she is advertised to sail for Europe on the 26th proximo.

"WHY DID NOT McCLELLAN HARASS THE REAR OF THE RETREATING REBELS ? ? ?" This is the last complaining cry of our goose-quill Generals. An easy answer may be found in the fact that the rebels traveled into the interior by railroad, and we had only horse-power.

Mr. TRAIN, on the 13th inst., to accompany him to the White House, and there witness the presentation of an elegant whip, made by a Massachusetts whip company. Mr. LINCOLN received the party in his council chamber, where Secretaries CHASE and STANTON were with him, and cordially greeted each one.

We have dates from Vera Cruz up to the 7th inst., brought by the Blascode Garay, a Spanish steamer-of-war, and in which came 143 sick soldiers. Little of interest has transpired there since our last dates, of the 4th. Brig.-Gen. LORENCEZ arrived on the 5th inst., in the Forfait, but as yet the French reinforcements had not.

The lines of JEFF. DAVIS' rebellion extend over a vast region of territory. The westernmost of his bloody outposts is among the far-distant, wild mountains of New-Mexico, on the upper waters of the Rio Grande. Of the fierce battle that was fought there on the 2lst ult., at the hamlet of Valyerde, we have already given the particulars.

The departure of Mr. STEVENS' gunboat, the Naugatuck, has been delayed several days in consequence of Government having directed that the monster Union gun now at the Rip Raps should be substituted in place of the 100-pound rifled gun. This order has been countermanded, and the rifled gun has again been remounted.

Gen. BURNSIDE'S official report, ascribing to Gen. McCLELLAN the credit of having directed the expedition to Newbern, is a severe blow to the wretched cabal who, in the Tribune and in Congress, have been striking at the President over the shoulders of McCLELLAN.

James C. Griffin vs. Albert H. Wright. The trial of this action created considerable interest, from the fact that it was the one in which Mr. Busteed was counsel for the defendant, and about which he published a card reflecting upon Justice JAMES for allowing a judgement by default to be taken during his engagement in another Court. The default was subsequently opened.

No subject is attracting more attention and interest in Washington, just now, than the construction of iron-clad ships-of-war by our Government. The argument as to their utility and necessity is past. The Merrimac taught in twenty-four hours what the patience, genius and skill of the STEVENS brothers were twenty-four years striving in vain to establish.

Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, (Rep.,) introduced a bill to provide for an equitable settlement of the accounts of the officers and sailors of the frigate Congress and other vessels. Passed.
There is inherent probability in the news which comes from Mexico of the signing and ratification of a treaty of peace. The basis of the treaty had been arranged previously.

In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to incorporate the New-York College of Veterinary Surgeons was ordered to a third reading. the Excise law, similar to the one introduced in the Assembly, was reported.

A man named PATRICK TRACY, residing at No. 13 State-street, was arrested yesterday, by Capt. SMITH, of the First Precinct, on a charge of beating his wife so that she cannot recover. Coroner NORRIS last evening made an ante- mortem examination, and the accused was committed to await the result of the injuries to his wife.
The rebel President was correct in saying that, in attempting to defend the whole territory of the Confederate States, seaboard and inland, he had undertaken too much.

By the arrival of the steamship America at Halifax we receive advices from Europe two days later than by the Anglo-Saxon. The expected debate had taken place in the British Parliament on the subject of the Southern blockade.
The opinion generally prevails in naval and military circles here that the Stars and Stripes by this time float over New-Orleans.
The Ohio River is rapidly rising at this point (Cairo.) In the last twenty-four hours it has risen a foot. The streets are covered to the depth of four feet in some places.
Our troops, under Gens. VAN DORN, PRICE and McCULLOCH, engaged the enemy for three days, the 5th, 6th, and 7th, at Perry's Ridge, in Benton County, this State, near the Missouri line.

For a long time past the inhabitants of the north side of Staten Island, is the neighborhood of Factoryville and Port Richmond, have been almost nightly aroused from their slumbers by alarms of fire. So frequent and disastreus were these conflagrations, that many of the most wealthy citizens in the vicinity were unable to rest quietly in their beds, un- less a special watchman were employed to guard their premises.

The Spanish steamer-of-war Blasco de Garay arrived at Havana on the 13th inst. from Vera Cruz. She brings information that the English forces had re- embarked on board their ships, with the exception of two companies, which were to remain in the castle of San Juan de Ulloa.

The nar- row and sectional quarrels of parties in Canada are the root of all the complaints made by the United States, as to the legislation of Canada on commercial subjects. The Western or Upper Province has long been in favor of a just and lib- eral policy.
The Philadelphia Bulletin publishes the following interesting private letter from an old citizen of Nashville:

The present time is furnishing materials for history of the richest and most costly sort; and the future historian who shall, in a spirit in harmony with the spirit of this time, give any adequate description of the occurrences of the past year, will be sure of a lofty name among historians.
The Royal Mail steamship America, from Liver- pool on the 8th, via Queenstown 9th, arrived at this port at 2 o'olock this morning.
We receive from Washington the highly-import- ant intimation that New-Orleans is now in possession of the National forces. This is given as the prevalent opinion in naval and military circles.

The main section of the bill about executions which passed the Legislature is, that all executions Issued on replevin bonds, or bonds having the force and effect of replevin bonds, executed after the passage of this act, and prior to the first Monday in January 1863, shall be made returnable to the first Monday in March, 1863.

We print elsewhere a letter from Mr. HAM- ILTON, Architect of that pretty structure, the Institute of Fine Arts, on Broadway, relative to his design for houses on the model so much in vogue in many of the leading capitals of Europe.

Prof. AGASSIZ delivered at Irving HalL on Friday evening, the last but one of his lectures on Natu- ral History before the Athaeneum Association. There was a very large audience present, in spite of the storm.

The reports which have been in circulation here for same time that there was a disagreement between the three European Powers on the Mexican question, have at last been confirmed. The Spanish steamer-of- war Blasco de Garay arrived on Thursday afternoon the l3th Inst., from Vera Cruz, at 2 o'clock P.M., after a voyage of six days.

All is quiet here. There is no news. A flag of truce was sent out this morning for the accommodation of an officer of the French Navy desiring to go South. The rebel officers and crew were very uncommunicative, and we gathered no news from them.

The severe gales that have prevailed on the coast during the last two weeks will be the occasion of a great many disasters, if many vessels experienced them to as great an extent as did the Kensington.

The National Intelligencer, on Tuesdtsy morning, published, from the New-York Observer, under the head of "The Law and the Testimony," the letter of GEORGE WASHINGTON addressed to the Continental Congress, when he submitted a copy of the Constitu- tion in 1787.
The Savanna, Tenn., correspondent of the St. Louis Democrat, under date of the 17th inst., says:

Among the notices of various kinds elicited by the recent article in the TIMES upon the revived misrepresentations of the conduct of our Government in the settlement of the Northeastern boundary, the following letter merits publication and attention, in order, as its writer says, that " Justice may be done and history truly written:"

SWORD PRESENTATION. Among the recently exchanged Union prisoners that have arrived in this City from Richmond was Lieut. JOHN S. WHYTE, of Company B, Seventy-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M. He was with his regiment at the battle of Bull Run in July last, and gallantly discharged his duty on that eventful day, until taken prisoner by the rebels.
We were glad to see, from Secretary CHASE'S recent letter in relation to the Port Royal con- trabands, or rather freedmen, that the Govern- ment is not wholly neglecting the condition of this class.

The Treasury Department is now issuing certificates of indebtedness at the rate of nearly two millions a day. This will soon clear off the accounts that have been audited, but not paid because of the want of Treasury Notes.
The Grinding Committee reported complete several bills of a local character.
Prof. Louis Agassiz and lady arrived yesterday afternoon from Cambridge, Mass., and are stopping at the Everett House.

Since I last wrote you, giving an account of the attack on the English Legation at Yedo, some few changes have taken place in the tactics of the English and French Ministers in their dealings with the Japanese Government, which may not be without interest to your readers.

PROBABLE LOSS OF 120 LIVES The Gloucester Telegraph says the gale of the 24th and 25th of February last has proved most disastrous to the Gloucester fishing fleet, and from present advises the loss of life will be very great, largely exceeding that of any previous season. The Telegraph continues:

A few days since, the TIMES noted briefly a report presented at a meeting of the Commissioners of Health, by Dr. LEWIS A. SAYRE, Resident Physician, on the subject of compulsory vaccination. The report, of which a large number were ordered for gratuitous distribution, has just been printed, and in view of the magnitude of the public interests involved, we present a very full abstract.

FELOW-CITIZENS: In the present trying crisis, much thought and anxious inquiry has been devoted by the City Council, the citizens and several of our friends from the country, including Gen. S.R. PYLES and Staff, to ascertain and determine what, under all the circumstances, is best to be done, and will best promote the safety, comfort and happiness of the people.

The screw steamer Glasgow, which sailed from Liverpool at noon on the 5th, and from Queenstown on the 6th inst., arrived here yesterday morning.

The recent statement of Lord CLARENCE PAGET to the House of Commons, gave that body information that before the end of 1863, the British Admiralty would have floating twenty-seven iron-plated ships. These have been built upon one general plan, of which the Warrior, the Defence, and Black Prince are illustrations.
Telegraphic despatches received here from Winchester, dated last night at half past ten, say:

To the Editor of the London News: SIR: This day's article on American affairs in your able journal concludes: "We cannot estimate the American case by gazing at the Capital and the camp, and reading partisan papers."

The church of Rev. Dr. HAGUE, corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-first-street, was crowded last evening, upon the call of a meeting to be held under the auspices of the Christian Commission, whose object is to disseminate religious reading matter through the ranks of our army. All sects are joining heartily in this good work, which was commenced last November.

A writer in the February number of Blackwood's Magazine, assuming war between England and the United States to be only deferred, addresses himself to the important question, How to prepare for such a contingency, and to conduct it when it comes. He takes it for granted that his countrymen will assail our harbors, burn our fleets, destroy our commerce, and keep our whole seaboard in a state of constant alarm.

We print in another column a full copy of the Metropolitan Health bill, now pending in the Legislature. A synopsis of this act has already been published, but its importance and interest to all our citizens will warrant this publication of all its details.

The number of men shipped here, last week for the naval general service, was one hundred and twenty fifty more than the week previous, and, at least, forty below the weekly average during the last six months. Seven hundred disposable seamen are now on board the receiving ship North Carolina.

We hear nothing of late from rebel sources of the financial exhaustion of the North and the bankruptcy of the National Treasury. From these causes, it was said, a few months ago, the Government would be compelled to stop the war, and recognize the separate Confederacy of the South. To the same effect ran the current of English journalistic opinion. The depreciation of United States Notes, and the appreciation of Gold,...

On Saturday, March 1, Prince NAPOLEON addressed the French Senate upon the paragraph of the address relating to Rome. He said: "I shall not follow the example of the eloquent orators to whom I am about to reply. I do not wish any more than they to infuse the heat of passion into this debate; but I shall, endeavor to be as clear and precise as their conclusions have appeared to me obscure and mysterious.
But little of interest has transpired, since my last, if I except the excitement manifested by the arrival of the English packet Oneida, which made its appearance on the 2d inst.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: The Herald and the Express, and a correspondent of the TIMES, having taken occasion, within a day or two, to attack the societies which have been formed to render aid to the colored people of the South, who have been abandoned by their masters on the approach of our armies, it is due to those societies, and to the public, that a statement should be made in refutation.

The work of cleaning out the rebel batteries recently evacuated is rapidly progressing. The guns shell, and other munitions of war found there, are being removed by soldiers detailed for that purpose. Several reconnoissances have been made a few miles into the interior, and now and then a rebel deserter comes in and details to gaping crowds the "story of his sufferings."
PROBABLE FALL OF NEW-ORLEANS. The Government has no news of an attack upon New-Orleans or its defences, but such an attack is doubtless made.

In the House of Commons on the 7th inst., Mr. GREGORY said : Sir, before going into Committee of Supply I wish to call the attention of the House to a subject which I conceive to be one of the most important that can be brought under its notice.

If the inventive genius of this country can have a fair chance if schemes for iron-clad protection can be adopted solely on their merits, we may indeed hope to have a formidable navy. An important element in such success will be unrestricted discussion. If any scheme can run the gauntlet of professional criticism, it is not likely to be a bad failure.
The ammendment to the Brooklyn Charter was concurred in.
Gen. BANKS is at Winchester. The rebels expected to steal a march on us, and were surprised at being met in force.

A special to the Chicago Tribune, dated Saturday night, says the gunboat Mound City fired twenty shot at the middle batteries with considerable effect. Our officers, with a glass, counted five rebels killed at a single shot. On Saturday our mortars fired with considerable regularity, but the results were not ascertained, owing to the unfavorable state of the weather. The balloon roconnoissance did not take place.

LONDON MONEY MARKET, SATURDAY EVENING. Consols closed firm at an advance of an eighth, and were quoted 93 @ for money, and 93 @ for April 10. Loans continue to be offered at 1@1 cent. About 20,000 was taken from the Bank. The Clutha has arrived from Australia with 90,640, and the Kooria Mooria with 47,856.

As the rebel armies in the respective seceded States are destroyed by our own, a grave question will arise as to the best means of preventing their reorganization, and of providing for the permanent pacification of those States.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 783 is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, graphic letters from our correspondents in Virginia and on the Potomac, and letters from other divisions of the army.

You have given the country very just conclusions in regard to the Government censorship, drawn from the revelations of the report of the House Judiciary Committee. It is simply impossible to enforce an equal system of newspaper supervision in a country as free as this; and any attempt at censorship must be attended with irritation and followed by failure. The Committee's report showed very clearly how the censorship established by the Government.
The steamship Hansa, of the Bremen line, from Southampton on the 12th instant, arrived last evening Her advices are three days later than those by the America.
The steamer Chancellor Livingston arrived from Hatteras Inlet last night.
Ex-Gov. Fairbanks and sons, of Vermont ; Capt. H. French of the United States Navy Horner Ramsdell, of Newburgh ; Capt. F.B. Myer, of London, and R.H. Gratrages, from England, are at the Astor House.

An arrival from the Tennessee River says 8,000 men under Gen. WALLACE, visited Adamsville, eight miles from Pittsburgh Landing, where there was understood to be a large rebel force. On arriving there they found the rebels gone. A gentleman just from New-Orleans says the rebels are building thirteen gunboats at that place, to be completed soon.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.-"Masaniello" was played here last evening, and not withstanding a curious thinness in the attendance at almost all the theatres, attracted a very good audience. The performance was the best that has been given so far, signor BRIGNOLL being in unusually good voice. The opera will be repeated in Brooklyn on Thursday evening.
The Suwanne sailed for Hatteras yesterday afternoon, with mails and passengers.

THE SUPPRESSION OF NEWSPAPERS. Certain newspapers having flagrantly persisted in the publication of military details, in violation of the Roles and Articles of War, and the orders of the War Department, thereby endangering the safety of our armies and the success of military operations, the Secretary of War has ordered the enforcement of the Penalties, and a special court-martial is to be assembled at Washington for the trial and punishment of the offenders.

Mr. TEN EYCK, of New-Jersey, (Rep.,) presented a joint resolution from the Legislature of New-Jersey, asking Congress to take immediate action for the defences of the coast of New-Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, and resolving that the several states loan funds for the purpose. Referred.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening Alderman DAYTON moved that the Board take immediate action on the application of the Independent Telegraph Company for the privilege of raising poles for their wires in the City of NewYork. Alderman BOOLE, on behalf of the Committee having the subject in charge, stated that the subject was under consideration, and the Committee would report soon. With that understanding the matter was dropped.

The Secretary of War, at a late hour last night had fully determined to arrest the publishers of certain New-York and Boston papers, as I telegraphed you, averring that their offence was flagrant, and he must either carry out his order, by their arrest and punishment, or suspend the censorship altogether.

The Times City Article says the funds opened yesterday at an improvement of 1/8. There was a temporary relapse, bat the advance was maintained at the close. Business in American stocks was restricted, pending another arrival.
COTTON dull. Sales of four days 21,000 bales, including 7,000 to speculators and exporters. Prices unchanged.

We have dates from Valparaiso and Santiago de Chile to Feb. 17; from La Paz, Bollvia, to same day; from Callao and Lima to Feb. 28; and from Quito, Ecuador, to Feb. 20. From San Juan, in the extinct Argentine Confederation, private letters to Feb. 5 have been received in Panama.

-A CHANCE FOR THE CHARITABLE. The heroism and the triumphs of the National soldiers in North Carolina have already been fully chronicled by the Press; and Roanoke and Newbern among battles, and Gen. BURNSIDE among commanders, and the Eastern troops among soldiers, now stand in the foremost rank in the mind of the nation.

U.S. steam transport George Peabody, Capt. TRAVERS, from Newbern, N.C., March 22, in ballast, to the U.S. Quartermaster, arrived at this port yesterday. She left in company with the steamer NewBrunswick for New-York, and passed over the Swash on Sunday, at 11 A.M. Found at the Inlet the steamer Port Royal, from New-York, all well.

In the French Legislative Body on the 13th inst., Count DE MORNY in the Chair, the order of the day was the adjourned discussion on the Address.

The French Legislative body has just been the scene of an extended discussion on the American question, which is the French parallel of the late debate, on the same question, in the English Parliament. We transfer to our columns the more practical portion of the discussion, which was characterized by all the French passion for glittering generalities and brilliant abstractions.

The conjoint raid into Mexico has been the subject of discussion in the French Legislative Chamber. The Liberal party took manful ground against the Government for thus deserting the traditions of the country by forcible intervention in the domestic affairs of another people, and argued cogently the folly of levying war on a grand scale to collect a debt of $150,000.

Mr. DAWES, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) rose to a privileged question, in behalf of the Government Contract Committee. He referred to the pamphlet issued by ALEKANDER CUMMINGS, who charged that the Committee had altered and falsified the record and the testimony furnished by them; and did all this wilfully and perversely, for the purpose of creating a sensation in the House and country, and convicting him of charges which the Committee knew were false.

Mr. HENDERSON, the newly appointed Senator from Missouri, has signalized his debut in the Senate by showing that one at least of the representatives from the Border States is able to appreciate the crisis, and to measure his duty.
Col. HARVEY BROWN, Fifth United States Artillery, has taken up his quarters at Fort Hamilton, of which post, as well as all the forts in the harbor, he is in command.
The following circular has been received by Gen. SHIELDS, and published to his Division at Winchester on the 26th:

Rebel writers own that Unionists by thousands are running away from East Tennessee, to join Gen. CARTER, near Cumberland Gap. It is said that he will in a month have ten regiments of East Tennesseeans enrolled. The Gap will confessedly be abandoned whenever we occupy Knoxville or London.
The House, in Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, resumed the consideration of the Tax bill.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mme. D'ANGRI, who is one of the few really great artists we have heard in America, will make her rentree to-night under Mr. GRAU's management, in ROSSINI'S delightful opera of the "Barbiere." The cast is otherwise good, and will, we are persuaded, fill the house with the most fashionable and appreciative audience of the season.

ACCIDENTS. As Mrs. ROBINSON, of Tillarystreet, was crossing Fulton-avenue, near Adamsstreet, yesterday afternoon, she was knocked down and run over by a heavily loaded farm wagon, by which she had one arm broken, and was otherwise severely injured. She was taken home by the Police. JOEN A. KENNEDAY had one of his feet badly crushed, yesterday afternoon, in a saw-mill, at the foot of North Third-street, Eastern District.

In the Senate, yesterday, the Committee on Naval Affairs was instructed to inquire whether there was any laxity on the part of any of the blockading vessels, and especially at Charleston. The joint resolution to give pecuniary aid to those States desiring to abolish Slavery was taken up, and Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri, made a speech in favor of its adoption.

The London Times draws from the late discussion on the blockade in Parliament, two or three conclusions for the especial benefit of people on this side of the water. Contrabands state that the rebel steamer Merrimac having been fully repaired was brought out of the Dry Dock on Monday morning; that her crew had been placed on board, and that she was ready for action. Several new guns of a heavier metal than she used before had been placed on board of her.

The various and contradictory reports that came to us on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, in regard to the fate of the rebel steamship Nashville, have now, apparently, brought-up with the fact that she was neither burned by the rebels nor captured by us, but that she has again escaped to sea.

John Hanna vs. John D. Dexter. The plaintiff claimed that the defendant transferred to him, in exchange for a bakery at No. 511 Canal-street, in this City, a bad title to certain lands in New-Hampshire, alleging that the defendant represented his title to be good, but averring that the lands belonged to the State of New-Hampshire, and not to defendant.

A railroad train on the Northwestern Railroad, running into Chicago, was smashed up on Wednesday night, through the breaking of an axle, and ten of the Third Wisconsin Cavalry were killed, three seriously wounded, and a number slightly hurt.

Although the announcement that Mr.PHILLIPS would address the people of Cincinnati at the Opera House, last evening, was only made in the morning papers of yesterday, the house was filled at an early hour with many of our best citizens, of all shades of politics, who went to listen to this great orator and champion of Freedom, on the all-absorbing topic of the war.

To the Edtior of the New-York Times: Your article in this morning's paper, on "The Wants of the Wounded Soldiers," sent me to the Park Barracks to contribute my mite, and I was glad to learn there that the ladies of our City were actively meeting the claims of our wounded brothers by giving them "aid and comfort."

The bodies of Col. SLOCUM, Major BALLOU and Capt. TOWER, of Rhode Island, killed at Bull Run, were received in this City yesterday, and escorted to the Astor House, where they now lie in state. Rev. Dr. BELLOWS lectured at Irving Hall last evening, on the "Field of Manassas," as viewed by himself at a visit on the 12th, 13th and 14th inst. The Doctor had quite a collection of trophies from the field, which, with the utmost nonchalance, he arranged on the stage in the presence of the audience, remarking that one of the lessons learned at Manassas was to wait upon one's self.

The public were notified, yesterday, that Hon. EMERSON ETHERIDGE would address the people of Nashville in the Court-house, and, accordingly, before 7 o'clock, persons began to assemble in the large hall, where a band was already stationed, and which soon after enlivened the room by sweet strains of music. By 7 o'clock there were probably five hundred persons in the room, nearly one-half of them in military uniform.

The Trustees of the New-York Homoeopathic Dispensary, located at No. 65 West Thirty-fourthstreet, held their annual meeting on Thursday evening, at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. The early hours of the evening were devoted to the discussion of the annual report and the transaction of business connected with the institution the later hours were devoted to the consumption of a supper.

Henry S. Scudder vs. R.B. Yond. This was an action to recover the sum of $259 for goods sold to one William J. Marshall, the payment of which, as alleged, was guaranteed by the defendant. The complaint alleged that the plaintiff trusted Marshall at the special request of the defendant, upon his guaranty that he would pay for the goods in the event of non-payment by Marshall.

We have before us a copy of the Norfolk Day Book, of the 26th inst. From it we learn that the North Carolina papers are loud in their censures of Gen. J. O'B. BRANCH, for his defeat at Newbern. MOVEMENTS OF NATIONAL TROOPS IN TENNESSEE.
Affairs remain quiet here, so far, at least, as regards news that can with prudence be communicated to the public.

A MAN WITH TWO WIVES. Officer VAN ARSDALE, of the Third Precinct, brought before Justice STEERS, yesterday, a man named CHARLES II. FLEMING, upon the charge of bigamy. From the testimoney elicited upon the examination, it appears that the accused was married to a Miss BUTT, on the 21st of December last. His lawful wife, Mrs. ROWENA FLEMING was at that time living in this City.

PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, March 29. JACKSON'S pyrotechnic factory, on Tenth and Reed streets, exploded early this morning. Four or five persons were killed, including a son of Mr. JACKSON. The head of one of the victims was blown nearly two squares, and various fragments of humanity were scattered about the ruins, presenting a most shocking sight. Ten or twelve others, boys and girls, were seriously injured.

A recent letter from Egypt to a Boston cotemporary gives an interesting account of an interview had by the writer with Mr. BUCKLE, the distinguished author of the History of Civilization in England, who is now temporarily sojourning for health in the mystic land of the Pyramids. From this source we learn that it is the intention of Mr. BUCKLE soon to pay a visit to the United States.
Davis vs. Hackley, Thomas Hope, Anthony Hope, and Robert T. Haws. This was an application for an order of injunction against the defendants, and for the appointment of a receiver.

It is difficult to change the routine of culture on a plantation, and it is natural to suppose that every planter knows his own business best. The suggestions of editors are generally treated with indifference, and their beautiful theories only amuse the practical planter.

The Winter campaign closed with definite and brilliant military successes on the Southern seaboard and in the Southwestern States and the Spring campaign opened under the most favorable auspices, which have been fully justified by the remarkable events of the current month.

Prof. AGASSIZ delivered, at Irving Hall, on Fri day evening, his sixth lecture, before the Athenaeum Association, previous to which he announced that, by request, he would deliver, on Monday, the 7th inst., a supplemental lecture, on which occassion he will endeavor to sum up the evidence in relation to the plan of creation.

The notorious female slaver, who was driven from this her native City, last Summer, owing to the action of the United States authorities in respect to those engaged in the Slave-trade, died recently in Cadiz, Spain, under circumstances of the most melancholy character. At the time she left this City, three charges were brought against her.

A correspondent of the Boston Journal writes from Ship Island:

The notorious brigand QUANTRELL, with two hundred of his guerilla band, made a sudden and unexpected attack on a detachment of Col. PHILLIP's Regiment of Missouri Militia, under Maj. FOSTER, at Warrensburgh, on Wednesday last, but after a spirited skirmish, they were driven from the town, with the loss of nine killed and seventeen wounded, and twenty horses captured. Yesterday the bodies of Col. SLOCUM, Major BALLOU and Capt. TOWER, of the Second Rhode Island Regiment, who met their death at the battle of Bull Run, were conveyed from the Astor House, where they had been lying in state, in order to be taken to Providence, Rhode Island, for interment. Detachments from the Seventyfirst, Thirty-seventh and Sixty-ninth Regiments formed the escort.

ARRESTS FOR PASSING COUNTERFEIT HALF DOLLARS. New York and Brooklyn have recently been flooded with counterfeit half dollars, and all efforts of the Police to ferret out the parties engaged in issuing this bogus coin seemed unavailing, until Friday night last, two men notified the Deputy-Inspector of Police that they had received four counterfeit half dollars at a drinking-saloon kept by EDWARD MOCAETY, corner of Bridge Road and Navy-Street.

By the arrival at this port of the steamship New-York; we have advices from Europe three days later than by the China. She left Southampton on the 19th inst., and brings London journals of that date. The news is not specially important.

The first detailed official report of the battle of Winchester is published this morning. It is written by Capt. SHRIBER, of Gen. The army correspondent of the Republican, writing undar date of Cairo, March 29, says the firing on Friday at Island No. 10 was quite heavy, the rebels opening from a new battery, mounting, it is supposed, 128-pounders. The enemy could be seen cutting away trees and rapidly pushing forward other means of defence. They seem to have no idea of evacuating at present, and are daily getting more cannon in position.

Gen. SHERMAN visited Jacksonville, Florida, in person on Wednesday evening last, 19th inst. A committee of the loyal citizens immediately waited on him and represented the feelings of all who remained in the town to be strongly loyal. Capt. KINSLEY, of the bark Princeton, arrived yesterday from Demerara, bringing datets to March 10. Business was dull. Money matters were very tight, owing to the American war.

In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to encourage the investment of small sums in State stocks was reported favorably. The bill making a new division of the Stato into Congressional Districts was made the special order for Wednesday. The bill amending the present Excise laws was then debated until the hour of adjournment.

The gunboat Bienville arrived at the Navy-yard wharf this morning, having left San Augustine on the 25th. She brings the bodies of Capt. BUDD, of the Benguin, and of Capt. MATHER, who were both killed at Mosquito Inlet.

The mail received on Sunday evening from England to the 19th of March, reports continued firmness in the London market for American Stocks. This fact speaks well for the due appreciation of our recent successes in the field and our financial measures in Congress, by the people of England.

The Conestoga, Lieut. GEORGE M. BLODGETT, now runs regularly between here and Cairo, carrying the mail both ways and thereby affords us regular communication with the outside world. By this means we get the daily papers, and are enabled, in addition to other valuable information, to learn how makers are progressing here all of which is, of course intensely acceptable besides being in the case of this point novel and interesting.

Vice-President HAMLIN, accompanied by the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs, and several other Senators and Representatives, arrived at Fortress Monroe on Sunday, and were expected to return to Washington yesterday.

By the arrival of the steamship Jura at Portland last evening, we receive advices from Europe two days later. The intelligence is in some respects important. President LINCOLN'S Message, proposing gradual emancipation, with pecuniary aid to the s ave-owners, had been received, and though there had not been much time for comment, that which had been bestowed upon it was of the most favorable character.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 787 is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, graphic letters from our correspondents in Tennessee and at Island No. 10, and letters from other divisions of the army.

The work on the frigate Roanoke progresses very satisfactorily. The energies of the Navy-yard seem concentrated on this vessel, and she will be completed as early as the resources of the yard will allow. It is said that the contract for the manufacture of the Roanoke's armor-plates has been divided among several firms, so that the armor may be ready without any avoidable delay.

SECRETARY CHASE ON A MISSION. Secretary CHASE left Washington to-day immedi ately after Cabinet meeting, on a very unexpected mission. He goes to Baltimore, perhaps further.

Gen. BANKS advanced from Strasburgh this morning towards this point. When approaching the town, ASHBY, with his rebel cavalry and infantry, disputed the passage to the place. We passed through the town, however, the rebels frequently stopping and throwing shells at us, to which we responded with effect.

The President's Emancipation policy has been made the policy of the Government. The joint resolution, which so readily passed the House of Representatives, was yesterday passed in the Senate, the vote being thirtytwo for the measure and ten against it. The Executive signature will at once complete this all-important act.

RUSSELL to the London Times dated from this side early in March returned by the last mail. In it he commends the moderate elation of the people of the North on the fall of Fort Donelson, and commends to the attention of the English public the "resolution and vigor" of the Southern Confederates at Richmond under this and other defeats.
A flag of truce from Norfolk, today, brought down letters from the National prisoners, and a dispatch from Gen. HUGER to Gen. WOOL.

The British brig J. Titus, of St. John, N.B., arrived at this port yesterday morning, having left Savanilla, New-Granada, on March 19. She reports that trade at Savanilla was very dull. There had not been any water in the canal for seven weeks, and there were no goods received from Baranquilla for shipment. Hopes were entertained of having water every day.

Navigation has opened on the Connecticut River. The steamer City of Hartford arrived here this morning, finding but little ice in the river.

The steamship Marion, which arrived from Hatteras Inlet yesterday, brings word that nothing of special interest had transpired at Newborn, since our last reports. Part of our force had advanced to within four miles of Beaufort.
