All was quiet on our outposts last night. We fired a few guns this morning to disperse some of the enemy's scouts on the heights beyond Edinburgh.

There is nothing easier than to exaggerate the force of armies in the field at a given point, or on a particular line of invasion or defence. The highest reasonably authenticated estimate of the whole force of the rebels is about 230,000, or 350 regiments of about 700 effective rank and file each.

The weather to-day is clear and pleasant, and everything is progressing in the most satisfactory manner. The rebels fired several shots from Sewall's Point last night, on the transports in the harbor, some of the shells falling within fifty feet of a vessel loaded with horses.
The following bills were put forward, and ordered to a third reading: For the completion and extension of the Buffalo and Alleghany Railroad.
Kellogg vs. Baker. This action was brought by the plaintiff, as assignee, to recover the value of a certain oil painting of a fish a salmon alleged to have been converted to his use by the defendant.

On motion of Mr. SPAULDING, of New-York, (Rep.,) the President was requested, if in his opinion not incompatible with the public interests, to communicate any information which may be received at the Department of State showing the system of revenue or finance now existing in any foreign country.

I am so far on my way to Port Royal. The crea- tion of a new Southern Department, embracing South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, and the appointment of Maj. Gen. HUNTER to its command, has given the public assurance of renewed activity in that now congested region; and wherever there is to be activity, there must also be ready the journalist to make his "abstract and brief" chronicle of and for the TIMES.
At the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, Messrs. Richard B. Connolly, Augustus W. Greenleaf, James B. Nicholson, Nelson Runyon and Henry M. Taber were elected members.

Our news by all the steamers that centre here and at Aspinwall, except from the United States, has been of but little importance the past ten days. We shall have nothing from Bogota till the 4th of next month, when we hope to hear of the termination of the civil war in this country.
A special dispatch to the Chicago Tribune, dated Cairo last night, says that a terrific storm has been raging in the vicinity of Cairo.

Mr. WILMOT, of Pennsylvania, (Rep.,) presented the resolutions of the Legislature of Pennsylvania, relative to the defences of Delaware River and Bay, recommending the construction of gunboats, and tendering the credit of the State to the amount of a million of dollars for the purpose, Referred.

Commodore FOOTE reports a gallant exploit performed by a small-boat expedition sent against Island No. Ten. On Tuesday he fitted out five boats, manned with a crew of 100 sailors, and dispatched them to spike the guns of the enemy's main battery on the island. They reached No. Ten at midnight, pulled directly in the face of the battery, carried it, spiked the six guns, scared off the enemy, and returned unharmed.

We have already published the appeal of the Missouri Congressmen to Secretary CHASE to arrange for a settlement with Government creditors in Missouri. The following is the supplementary portion of the correspondence:

The great billiard return match that was played on Thursday evening, at Irving Hall, between DUD- LEY KAVANAUGH, of New-York, and MICHAEL FOLEY, of Cleveland, resulted in the victory being gained, at an early hour on Friday morning, by FOLEY. He won it in a well-contested match by 34 points.
Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, (Rep.,) presented a petition of citizens of Ohio, in favor of a general bankrupt law.

A special to the Journal, dated Cairo, 4th, says; A boat arrived from Island No. 10 last night. Firing was resumed on Thursday morning by the gunboats and mortars. One of our shells burst upon the rebel steamer Winchester, which set her on fire and burned her to the water's edge.
Since my last I have been dodging about, and among other things, have had the extreme pleasure of seeing the clearing out of that pestiferous centrepot of treason, Union City.

Francisco Amodio, brother to the late celebrated baritone, and of the musical profession himself, ac-companied by Bernard Caraza and a valet, arrived from Central America in the steamship Northern Light, and are stopping at the Everett House.

It appears from the British Blue-Book on Mexican affairs, that Sir J. CRAMPTON, of contraband-enlistment notoriety, has again become ambitions of the attentions of the Press. The gentleman, who now represents England at the Court of Madrid, has a second time overstepped the limits of his authority, having assured Marshal O'DONNELL, during one of thier conversations touching intervention in Mexico, that "Her Majesty's Government could never recognize what was commonly called the 'Monroe Doctrine.'"

The crew of the steamer Huntsville, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, were mustered yesterday and inspected by Capt. GANSEVOORT, Capt. ALMY and Lieut. BARRETT. They then were put through the small arms and marine artillery drill, and acquitted themselves to the satisfaction of the above-named officers, who will report accordingly. The Huntsville will be put out of commission to-day. Lieut. HENRY ERBEN, Jr., of this vessel, has been detached, and ordered to report to Flag-Officer FOOTE.
Mr.VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, (Dem.,) asked unanimous consent to make a statement relative to the Democratic Conference which took place last week.
All is quiet in this camp, except occasional shots at long range with ASHBY'S rebel cavalry. Our troops are in good condition and anxious for a forward move.

Every day's advices confirm the views I advanced the other day of the rebel plan of operations. They are concentrating the forces of their "Army of the Mississippi" at the point on the Memphis and Charleston Railroad nearest to our positions on the river, and are preparing to move rapidly to the defence of the road, at any point we may threaten it.

Amidst the universal rejoicing of the patriotic and Union-loving people on the Pacific coast, incident to the brilliant victories achieved by the army and navy of the United States, let us pause a moment to do honor to the memory of the chief of that illustrious band of patriots who established the liberties for the preservation of which we are now battling.

There is no reason why the people of the Confederate States should allow their confidence in our ultimate success to abate or waver. At no time during the old Revolutionary war were the prospects of the Colonies as encouraging as ours are to-day. True, we have suffered reverses, but what man ever yielded the battle of life because he encountered occasional disappointments? Who succeeds at all times, and in all his undertakings?

Reporters have given to the Press full derails of the investment and attack of New-Madrid, some 18 miles up the river from this place, and the enemy's sudden panic and inglorious light from that place. It was truly a post of considerable strength to the rebels. Their fort, on which they had expended much labor, commanded the river, or rather each of the forts did so, as there were two of them.

EVENTS OF THE COMING WEEK. The coming week will furnish an interesting page in the history of the rebellion and the country. The War and Navy Departments to-day furnish no news that can be published.

At the general meeting of the Atlantic Telegraph Company the result of which was briefly stated in our impression of yesterday the Directors reported that the American Government had addressed a dispatch to their Minister in this country, offering, in a very handsome manner, to cooperate with the British Government in order that the telegraph might be laid between Newfoundland and Ireland, and for rendering it inviolate even in time of war.

A dispatch to the Secretary of War, dated NewMadrid, April 5, states that "last night, Capt. WALE, with the gunboat Carondelet, ran the gauntlet at Island No. 10, and is now available to Gen. POPE. She was fired on by the rebel batteries, but was not struck once."

Cannonading has been heard all the morning from the direction of Yorktown. No official reports have been received here, but it is rumored that the town has been burnt. This is probably incorrect, however. Another report says that a fight is taking place there this afternoon.

England has pretty well recovered from the shock of Union victories. The papers in the Southern interest have made it apparent that the surrender of Fort Donelson was not much of a disaster, and that the further the Union troops get into the South the worse it will be for them, and the better, of course, for the Confederates, which shows how foolish they have been in trying to keep them out.

The Milanese students have had an interview with GARIBALDI, informing him that they have formed themselves into a company of carbineers. GARIBALDI recalled the events of 1859, and encouraged the students. A number of ladies have associated them- selves with the institution for National Rifle Clubs. A crowd has assembled before the hotel of GARIBALDI, shouting "United Italy," "Rome and Venice." A distribution of medals was appointed to take place at 2 o'clock to-day.
In a former letter I indulged in a few remarks upon Generale in general. These random, pointloss arrows have been construed as strategical shafts, leveled directly at McCLELLAM. I am sorry for it.

The prevailing belief among military men in this City is that the rebels will fly from Virginia as a military necessity, fearing that they will be cut off from all railroad communication with their friends in the State of Virginia, that being the only means by which they can be reinforced and supplied, or by which they can escape.

Gen. FREMONT is stopping at "The McClure House," in this city. He is looking much better than when I last saw him, on his return from "The Hundred Days in Missouri."

In the Senate, yesterday, among the bills passed was the one authorizing the Governor to appoint persons to take acknowledgments of deeds in Great Britain and France, and the one making an appropriation for the payment of the State's quota of the direct tax to the National Government. The bill to provide for the examination of the accounts of the Treasurer and other State officers was made the special order for this evening.

COTTON. The Brokers' Circular reports the sales for the week at 23,500 bales. The market closed dull but firm, with an advance of 1/8 d. on middling grades. The sales to speculators were 4,500, and to exporters 1,500 bales. The sales to-day (Friday) are estimated at 4,000 bales, including 1,000 to speculators and exporters. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, graphic letters from our correspondents at Headquarters, and letters from other divisions of the army.

DEATH OF A WELL-KNOWN CITIZEN. NOAH WATERBURY, resident of the Eastern District, and for many years President of the Williamsburgh City Bank, died at an advanced age, Saturday evening last. Out of respect for the memory of the deceased the flags on the ferryboats and the shipping were raised at half-mast yesterday.

Mr. SUMNER, of Massachusetts, (Rep.,) presented a petition in favor of emancipation. Mr. WILLEY, of Virginia, (Union,) presented a petition of citizens of Virginia against the proposed tax on leaf tobacco.

Officers from Woodstock to-day report the bridge over Stony Creek as completed yesterday. To-day our brigades, when crossing, were greeted by a lively canonading from ASHBY's battery, but they were dispersed by our guns, and we are now in full possession of his late position. ASHBY retiring as usual, taking advantage of every position to retard our progress.

Three guns were opened by the enemy to-day, from a new position, upon our pickets. They were responded to by Capt. HUNTINGTON'S Battery, with a rapid fire. Our shells burst in their midst, scattering them suddenly.

The propeller Mary Stewart, of the Western Transportation Company, which was sunk by the ice on Saturday, while coming into our harbor, has been raised. She had a cargo of pork and flour.

RUMORS FROM YORKTOWN. The city is filled with a variety of rumors to-night about the fight going on at Yorktown. One moment we are startled with a defeat, and the next with a splendid victory. Up to the moment of closing this dispatch nothing is developed by the War Department.

Affairs at the Brooklyn Navy-yard remain much the same as last week. All the works in progress are going on as satisfactorily as can be wished, and the greatest activity prevails in all the departments.

Friday, the 4th inst., was the day fixed for the movement on to Yorktown. Gen. McClellan and Staff arrived at Fortress Monroe on Wednesday, on board the steamer Commodore. The troops were full of enthusiasm, and longed for an advance movement. They complained that the enemy would not stand to give them a "show" of Northern prowess. They, the soldiers, have great confidence in Gen. McCLELLAN.

We present to our readers, this morning, a statement of a portion of the work that has been completed within the last thirty days at our various shipyards and machine-shops. It will be observed that, notwithstanding our troubles, there has been, considerable activity manifested in these branches of industry.
The gunboat Carondelet ran the blockade at Island No. 10 on Friday night, and the gunboat Pittsburgh on Sunday night. All the batteries of the enemy opened fire, but not a shot struck either boat.

Sybelle is a beautiful creation. A young girl, in a seclu sion that is almost solitude, pants for the great outer world and its raging conflicts of passion and ambition.

The Press, echoing the impulses of the great popular heart, developes the military spirit as fast as the people can follow it. At the outset of the rebellion we had a correspondent to each regiment; soon they became so numerous that a " Press Brigade" was formed, and now we make another leap and divide our brigades and divisions into corps d'armees.

The Secretary of War received an official dispatch at noon to-day that Island No. 10 surrendered to our land and naval forces at sunrise this morning. It is expected that the rational forces will capture many prisoners, although it is said that large numbers fled upon the advance of our troops.

In the Senate, last evening, but little was done; most of the session was consumed in the consideration of a bill to amend the Code of Procedure, and to extend the term of office of the Commissioners of the Code appointed under the act of April 6, 1857. An amendment was finally adopted that no Justice or Judge shall sit as Referee in any action pending in any Court in which he is a Judge.

The President, in issuing his noble Proclamation setting apart to-morrow as a day of National Thanksgiving, has doubtless been mindful of the significance of the date, and has fitly chosen that the anniversary of the blackest day of our National annals shall be signalized by a devout recognition and grateful remembrance of all the Providential experiences that fill the intervening twelvemonths.
Since Monday morning, a steady northeast wind and rain-storm has been prevailing here, which has greatly retarded military operations in this region.

Henry W. Hicks, Jr., vs. The Staten Island and New-York Ferry Company. This was an action to recover the sum of $6,000 damages for injuries al leged to have been sustained by the plaintiff through the negligence of the defendants. The defendants run a line of ferryboats between Staten Island and the dock at the foot of Whitehall-street, in this City.

Joseph Hoxie vs. Daniel B. Allen. This action was commenced in 1853, to recover for labor and services alleged to have been rendered the defendant by the plaintiff, in procuring the release of three steamships plying between this port and San Francisco, which had been libeled for violation of the Passenger Act prescribing the number of berths and passengers for passenger craft.

This Club held its second meeting last night. A platform for the party, which was offered to the Club for adoption, was, on motion of WM. L.REED, Esq., returned to the Committee to embody the plank that the Democratic Party will support the decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States.

I have some reason to believe that the French Government is far from satisfied with the manner in which matters have been conducted by their own people in Mexico. It was understood that the French force would proceed at once to the capital and occupy it.

GENERAL ORDER, No. 20. The Governor congratulates the members of the Eighty-fourth and One Hundred and Tenth Pennsylvania Volunteers upon their gallantry in the recent severe and brilliant action at Winchester. Their bearing upon that occasion, under the formidable attack of a bold and desperate foe, was worthy the high reputation already won by the soldiers of Pennsylvania in the memorable fields of Drainsville, Roanoke Island and Newbern.

The Gazette's, Pittsburgh, Tenn., correspondent says the sum and sumstance of the battle is: On Sunday we were pushed from disaster to disas ter till we lost every division camp we had, and were driven within half a mile of the landing, when the approach of night, the timely aid of the gunboats, the tremendous efforts of our artillarists, and BUELL'S approach saved us.

The return of pleasant weather, to-day, brought the Merrimac, as was generally anticipated, She had been seen three days ago under steam at Craney Island, and as the evening of yesterday promised that the storm had exhausted itself, few were surprised this morning at the announcement that she was in sight coming down.

During all the horrors of last night, the steamers lying at this point, which were not too heavily laden with stores or too much filled with the wounded, were engaged in ferrying the troops belonging to NELSON'S Division from the opposite shore. Every. load was greeted with cheers from those on shore, and returned hastily by those who had so opportunely arrived to take part in the battle of to-day.

A Baptist clergyman in the interior of Missouri, some weeks ago, left his parish to take a Captaincy in PRICE'S army. Subsequently he turned chaplain, and now, having become disgusted with the rebellion, wants to return home. His wife very suspiciously asked to be made the bearer of Gen. HALLEOK'S answer to a request of this purport. The General wrote as follows to Mr. W. McPHERSON, who brought the case to his attention:
A correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer with Gen. BANKS' advance, writes from Strasburgh under date of April 1:

There is one characteristic of our people pervading them at tho South, possibly more than at the North, which accounts in some degree for what would be in many countries utterly inexplicable, viz.: That a people should so suddenly change their Government, and that to change so suddenly undertaken should, nevertheless, in so short a period be accepted so generally among them. Our people, more

The Committee on Canals, to which was referred the bill entitled, "An act for the enlarging the locks upon the Erie and Oswego canals, for enlarging the Champlain Canal and locks, and for the passage of boats, vessels, supplies, and munitions of war belonging to the United States Gorernment through said canals," have had the bill under consideration, and submit the following

The stirring news which the mails from the United States bring us this week again directs the public attention to American affairs. The power developed by the Ericsson Battery and the Merrimac in the Bay of Norfolk, and the President's Message on the emancipation of Slavery, are two subjects which naturally excite here the liveliest interest. The new naval force which has suddenly come into existence ...

The Old Point letter brings nothing later than the dispatch of Gen. WOOL last night, except that as the Merrimac remained stationary off Sewall's Point it was thought she was aground. The letter closes thus:

We have just received a mail from New-York, and there is, consequently, joy on board the saucy Gem of the Seas, as we are called. It is the first mail we have had since December, and we should still be without our letters and papers from home, were it not for the captain of another schooner.
A report from Gen. WOOL to the Secretary of War, at 5 o'clock, P.M., states that all is quiet and the weather fine. The last dispatch received at 8:90 P.M., is to the following effect:

I am writing this letter from Shelbyville, a point just thirty miles north of the Alabama State line. This is, perhaps, as far as any division of the Union army has yet penetrated by land, although we do not know but what Gen. BUELL may at this very time be fighting the enemy at Corinth, or some other place in "the South proper," as Mr. JEFF. DAVIS has it.

Correspondence of the St. Louis Democrat says the advance guard of our army, under Gen. OSTERHAUS, encamped at the point last evening, having marched 20 miles from their old camp at Cross Timbers. The people in this vicinity are mostly Union, there being but three Secessionists here on this road from Cassville to Fort Creek.

The steamship Baltic, J.J. COMSTOCK Commander, arrived at this port yesterday from a cruise in search of the missing U.S. ship Vermont. The Captain learned at Bermuda that the Vermont was in good condition, and had proceeded on her way to Port Royal.

Intelligence has just arrived that transportation, long since asked for this department, has at last been ordered; also that reinforcements under Gen. BLENKER are coming when and what number is not stated.

Col. DENT has forbid any sort of Southern Rights demonstration in honor of C.S. MOREHEAD. If Mr. MOREHEAD has returned home a wiser and better man, he will change his associates, and refuse any invitations or attentions from secession sympathizers.

SCARCITY OF NEWS. Washington seldom originates much news on a Sunday, Bull Runs being scarce in this country. We have had no occasion for a Cabinet meeting. To-day, Senators and Representatives have regaled themselves by attending church, visiting Manassas, writing letters, franking documents to their friends and constituents, and discussing military men in general and McCLELLAN in particular.

The Atlantic sailed this morning at 8 o'clock for New York, with a large number of passengers, including Mrs. Gen. STEVENS and Gen, SHERMAN. We shall all welcome the return of the noble vessel to Port Royal.

The steamship Baltic, from Bermuda, which arrived at this port yesterday, reports having learned from the schooner O.H. Booth that they had spoken the United States ship Vermont, and that the Vermont supplied them with provisions. She was in good condition, and expected to make Port Royal in a few days.

The following paragraph, from the Augusta, Ga., Chronicle and Sentinel, of March 18, shows that the action of the Navy Department is not regarded there as having been quite so inefficient as many of our people are inclined to pronounce it:

In my last letter I stated that I did not believe that any battle would take place for the next ten days between our forces and the rebel troops which were concentrated at Corinth. I was led to this belief by the opinion current among our officers, that the enemy would intrench themselves and await an attack

If the statement be correct that PRICE and VAN DORN, with their rebel troops, took part in the battle at Pittsburgh, then Arkansas must be nearly cleared of rebel soldiers, and the State is open for the march of our army to its capital.

In the Senate on Saturday, several bills of a local character were passed. The bill for the selection of a site for another State Prison was made the special order for Tuesday. The bill to provide for the enrollment of the Militia, and the organization of the American Guard, was ordered to a third reading. The Assembly amendments to the Concert Saloon bill were concurred in, and the bill goes to the Governor.

During all the horrors of last night, the steamers lying at this point, which were not too heavily laden with stores or too much filled with the wounded, were engaged in ferrying the troops belonging to NELSON'S Division from the opposite shore.
The steamer Minnehaha arrived here to-day with about 240 wounded from Pittsburgh Landing, whereof one-fourth are rebels.

The above diagram shows clearly the positions held by our army, and by the rebels, previous to and at the time of the battle at Pittsburgh, on Sunday and Monday last exhibits also the relation of Pittsburgh to Corinth, Florence and Purdy, and to the line of railroad running north and south, and that running east and west.

Yesterday, in accordance with the President's proclamation, prayers were offered in the various churches in this City, Brooklyn and Jersey City, and thanks given for our recent victories. The day was generally observed, many ministers selecting texts suitable to the occasion. Yet the gratitude for our successes was tempered with sadness on account of the many brave and gallant soldiers that have fallen. We give below notices of the sermons in some of the churches.
In the rebel House at Richmond, on Monday last, 7th inst., the "great victory" was announced and the following resolutions introduced:

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The LUBIN BROTHERS, magicians of the old fashioned kind, commenced here last evening. Their programme, so for as we witnessed it, did not present any novelty , or call for any special consideration.
I left Fortress Monroe last night. The Merrimac and her consorts lay off Sewalls' Point all yesterday, making no demonstrations whatever.

The following is a summary of the news taken by the City of Baltimore, which left Liverpool 2d and Queenstown 3d.
We have been having rain and snow here for the last two days, and it must have been much worse in the mountains, rendering army travel exceedingly difficult, not to say impossible.
Correspondence of the Missouri Democrat. The whole Confederate force in the late Pea Ridge battle have gone East down the Arkansas.
The steamship Norweigan, Capt. McMASTERS, from Liverpool, I.P.M. of the 3d, and Londonderry, 4th, arrived here to-night at 9:15 o' clock.

Mr. GLADSTONE has made his financial statement in the Commons, which is generally satisfactory. No taxes are to be remitted, and the only change of moment is, that in September the hop duty is to be re pealed, and transferred to an excise duty on beer.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No. 791, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, graphic letters from our correspondents at Headquarters, and letters from other divisions of the army.
COTTON--The sales of the past three days sum up 12,000 bale, of which 3,000 were to speculators and exporters. The market closed with an upward tendency, but quiet, at unchanged prices.

Information received from New-Mexico states that on the 26th ult. Col. HOUGH, with 1,300 men, reached the Apache Pass. His advance, consisting of three companies of cavalry, had an engagement, some distance beyond this place, with 250 rebel cavalry, and took 57 prisoners. The Federal loss was four killed and eleven wounded.

The United States steamer Hercules, THOS. S. DUNGAN, Lieutenant Commanding reached this port this morning, having with her the schooner Pride, previously noted as being captured, and the sloops Wren and Velma, both of Great Wycomlco River. Western shore of Virginia, also prizes.
The following dispatch has been received by the Secretary of War, dated Nashville, Tenn., April 14:

The following is the Select Committee appointed by the Speaker, on Gradual Emancipation in the slaveholding States, by the people or local authorities thereof, authorized by the resolution of Mr. WHITE, of Indiana, and adopted last Monday;

The following bills were reported upon favorably: Providing for licensing the ballast lighters of the port of New-York. Extending the time for the completion of the Erie and New-York City Railroad. Relative to the Justices of the Police Courts of Brooklyn. To amend the law of collection of demands against ships and vessels.

The thirty-seventh annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design opened, yesterday, at the new rooms of the Dusseldorf Gallery, No. 625 Broadway. The collection is placed in three apartment, two of which aro good; the third is without daylight, and is meanly illuminated by a series of upright jets (excellent for throwing a good light on the ceiling) from a gaspipe that surrounds the room....

phia, yesterday much consternation prevailed because of a Government order forbidding the exportation of coal. It was thought to have some relation to the Merrimac, and to be an awkward way of announcing that coal-bearing vessels, southward bound, were in special danger of that arch-adversary. Similar orders were doubtless sent to all the loyal seaports, and possibly provoked like irrational commentary.

Commodore DUPONT reports to the Navy Department, under date of April 6, that the schooner Julia Warden and schooner Lydia and Mary were captured in Cape Rowan Passage, between the Santee River and Charleston, the first on the 27th and the second on the 29th ult., by the United States armed bark Restless, Acting Volunteer Lieut. CONROY commanding. Their cargoes were rice and corn meal.
Mr. CARLILE, of Virginia, (Union,) presented petitions in favor of allowing Democratic papers the same privileges in the mails as the Republican papers.

A party of ASHBY'S Cavalry, said to number two companies, attacked a body of infantry at the railroad bridge, yesterday, east of Strasburgh. A squadron of the Vermont cavalry were called out, but no enemy was seen, and returned.
In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, Jeremiah Cook pleded guilty to petty larceny, and, was sentenced to the Penitentiary for six months.
I have just received the following under date of Fortress Monroe, April 14:

Our City Judge had an opinion which he has seen fit to make public. It purports to be a legal opinion, the drawback being that there was no case before him for adjudication, and that there is neither law nor common sense in his utterances. In these circumstances, the weight to be given to this ex-parte warrant for illicit Sunday ...

There is little of stirring importance to communicate by the mail of to-day. Since my last, dated on the 2d Inst., considerable progress has been made in the preparations for the taking of Port Macon, which is the next most essential step in the programme of the campaign in North Carolina.

The Navy Department has received dispatches from Commodore DUPONT, inclosing a communication from Commander GODON, dated United States steamer Mohican, March 30, from which it appears that on the 17th ult., with the launches and another armed boat, he entered Jekyl Creek, and proceeded to DUBIONON'S place, where he discovered a deserted

A force of four thousand men, on five transports, left this landing on Saturday night, accompanied by the gunboats Tyler and Lexington, and proceeded up the Tennessee River to a point near Eastport, Miss., where they landed, and proceeded inland to Bear Creek Bridge, and destroyed the two bridges on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, one measuring 121 feet, and the other 210 feet in length.

THE SOCCESS AT FORT PULASKI. The news of the recapture of Fort Pulaski comes through rebel sources, accompanied by evidences of the effectiveness of our bombs ann guns truly wonderful. The Government is highly delighted.
An order for the better regulation of Military Hospitals, and for facilitating the discharge of soldiers unfit for service, has been issued from the War Department.

The steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 2d inst., and Queenstown on the 3d, arrived at this port last night. Her advices are not so late as were received by the Norwegian. The Norwegian's mails also came to hand last night.

There seems to be no doubt about Greytown HOLLINS figuring among the prisoners in the hands of Gen. POPE. HOLLINS is an invaluable acquisition. In the calendar of Rebellion there are heroes of first rate, and heroes of second rate classification.

Mr. WILKINSON, of Minnesota, (Rep.,) presented a petition from the citizens of Minnesota, praying Congress to call on all the people of the United States, bond and free, to aid in the suppression of the rebellion, and assuring them of the protection of the flag therefor.

But time works changes as well as revenges, and it now seems likely that correspondents ...

The screw steamship City of Baltimore, Capt. JEFFERY, which sailed from Liverpool at noon on the 2d, and from Queenstown on the 3d inst., arrived here late last night. A summary of her news was received by the Norwegian, at Portland, and published yesterday morning.

The following bills were reported upon favorably: Extending the term of office of the Code Commissioners. Relative to the Commissioners and Jurors of Kings County. Providing for the public defence and protection of New-York harbor.
A National salute was fired at noon, to-day, in honor of the recent victories, by order of Gen. BANKS. Great enthusiasm is manifested throughout the division.

In the Senate yesterday, the bill relative to the Commissioners of Jurors of Kings County, was reported favorably; also the bill providing for the public defence and the protection of New-York Harbor. Among other bills passed was the one dividing the State into Congressional Districts; ...

Mr. TROWBRIDGE, of Michigan, (Rep.,) called up the motion heretofore made by him, to reconsider the vote by which, on the 24th of March, the House adopted a resolution requesting the Secretary of War to inform them the cause, if any, for the protracted delay in exchanging Col. CORCORAN, who has been a prisoner at the South since July, and directing him to stop all exchanges until Col. CORCORAN shall be released.

A let ter, published yesterday, from the rebel General JOHNSTON, who uses slain at the battle at Pittsburgh Landing, fully sustains the ground that we have always taken, that the number of the rebel forces have everywhere been greatly exaggerated.

The steamship Canada, from Liverpool on the evening of the 5th, and Queenstown on the 6th inst., arrived at this port at 7 o'clock this morning. She has 38 passengers for Boston, where she will be due at noon on Thursday.

The New-Albany and Salem Railroad Company vs. Simeon Lelandetal. This was an action to recover the sum of $328, which was alleged to have been stolen from the pocket of one James Patton, an agent of the Company, while he was a guest at the Metropolitan Hotel, in this City, of which the defendants were the proprietors.

Fellow-citizens of the Senate and House of Representatives: The act entitled "An act for the release of certain persons held to service or labor in the District of Columbia," has this day been approved and signed.

In the House of Commons, on the evening of the 3d, Mr. FITZGERALD gave notice that he would soon call attention to our relations with Mexico.

The Paris correspondent of the London Daily News says: The difference between England and France in Mexican affairs is very ticklish. It continues to be given out that Spain agrees with France and will disavow the Convention.
The United States steam transport Albany, Capt. LEWIS, from Newbern, N. C., in 51 hours, with passengers and rebel prisoners, arrived this morning. She brings as passengers:

By the arrival of the steamship Canada at Halifax, we receive advices from Europe two days later than were brought by the Norwegian at Portland. It is announced that the ship Yorktown, a regular packet running between London and New-York, had been captured by a rebel privateer-where or when we are left to guess.

NEW YORK, Wednesday, April 16, 1862 6 P.M. The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 61 bbls, Ashes, 9,363 bbls, Flour, 221 'bbls, and 1,204 bags Corn Meal 2,525 bushels Wheat, 32,700 bushels Corn, 506 bushels Rye, 1,705 bushels Barley, 3,800 bushels Oats, 1,70 bushels Malt, 2,377 pkgs. Provisions, and 435 bbls Whisky.

SIR: The Department desires to convey to the commander, HENRY WALKE,and the officers and men of the Carondelet, also to Acting First Master HOEL, of the Cincinnati, who volunteered for the occasion, its thanks for the gallant and successful service rendered in running the Carondelet past the rebel batteries on the night of the 4th inst. The following is an official and ably-drawn history of our affairs with Mexico, as transmitted by the President to the House of Representatives yesterday, in a cumbersome mass of documents, covering a message from the President of Dec. 17, 1861, transmitting a draft for a convention with the Republic of Mexico, with accompanying papers, and another message from the President of Jan. 24, 1862, transmitting a dispatch from Mr.CORWIN.

The President signed the District of Columbia Emacipation Bill yesterday morning, and accompanied his notice of the fact to Congress with a Message, in which he says he never doubted the constitutional authority of Congress to abolish Slavery in the District, and had ever desired to see the National Capital freed from the institution in some satisfactory way. Hence there had
Mr.BLAIR, of Missouri, said: The charge has frequently been heard, here and elsewhere that the President is without a policy in his Administration.

The news of the signing of the bill for the Abolition of Slavery in the District, seen spread through the city, and was the cause of great rejoicing among the black population, and especially those who have been secreted for days for fear of being carried beyond the limits of the District to prevent their obtaining their freedom.

From our Western exchanges we compile the following alphabetical list of those wounded in the battle of Pittsburgh Landing, most of whom are now in Hospital at Cairo:

In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, James Garland, indicted with Charles McGinnis and George Allen, for burglary in the first degree, was convicted of an attempt at burglary in the second degree, and was remanded for sentence.

Just one week this day, the forces under arms and encamped near and about James River, above Fortress Monroe, at early sunrise, took up their march toward Richmond, The left of the advancing column was the Third Brigade of SMITH's Division, KEYES' corps. The Third Brigade is commanded by Brig.- Gen. J. W. DAVIDSON, and as your correspondent's observations were confined mainly to this corps, it is of its operations that he proposes to write.

The act of the President, in signing a bill to put an end to Slavery in the District of Columbia, places the Government of this country in its proper position, in reference to the subject of human bondage. It is a declaration

Jane C. Englebrecht vs. The Eighth-avenue Railroad Company. The plaintiff claimed to recover of the Company damages for injuries sustained, as alleged, by reason of the negligence of one of their conductors.
Secretary STANTON received, early this morning, the following dispatch,dated.

Morton et al. vs. Sands et al. Demurrer to answer sustained; but leave given to defendants to amend the answer, on payment of cost.

CAPTAIN :It becomes my duty again to report another battle fought between two great armies, one contending for the maintenance of the boss Government ever devised,and the other for its destruction. It is pleasant to record the success of the army contending for the former principle.

The confidence of many people in the victorious result of the battle at Pittsburgh Landing, has been much shaken by the announcement of Gen. BEAUREGARD that he had taken eight thousand prisoners and thirty-six pieces of artillery. The doubt is, perhaps, natural; but
Samuel D. Haring vs. Joseph Shannon. This was an action for alleged fraud in obtaining nineteen head of cattle. The plaintiff, who resides at Bergen,

The French and Continental, as well as the English Press, discuss the great importance of the experience gained by the engagement between the Merrimac and Monitor. It is generally admitted that maritime warfare has undergone a change, and that the Monitor is a solution of the question between wooden vessels and iron ones.
Mr. MUNROE gave notice that he would move to suspend the rule requiring bills to be acted on in the order which they occupy on the Calendar,for the purpose of taking up the Metropolitan Health bill.
To the Senate and House of Representatives of the Confederate States of America:

REDEMPTION OF CERTIFICATES. Today the Secretary of the Treasury made an order to redeem twenty per cent. in cash of the certificates of indebtedness issued before the 7th inst., where the certificates are presented by the parties to whom they were originally issued. Some, it is said, were paid to-day.
The mortars opened on Fort Pillow on the 14th inst., and soon cleared the river of all vessels. Our shells fell in the rebel camp. The rebel works are strong and extensive.
The bill to prevent frauds in the opening and laying out of streets and avenues in New-York, and the City tax-levy, well reported favorably, and ordered to the Committee of he Whole.

Hon. R.E. Fenton of New-York; Hon. W.S. Holman, R. W. Bates and Thomas F. Andrews, the Congressional Contract Investigating Committee, arrived yesterday from Washington, and will resume their duties at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. An adjourned meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors was held yesterday afternoon, in the County Jail. A large number of bills were ordered paid, and several reports upon minor matters were received and acted upon. Supervisor KIRBY attempted to bring before the Board a complaint against the Commissionto pass. He was shut off by a motion to adjourn. The Board adjourned to the second day of May.

A force of cavalry and infantry, from Gen. BANKS' corps, yesterday captured a whole company of the celebrated Ashby Cavalry, comprising more than 60 men, with horses and arms, and all their officers except the Captain. The prisoners will be sent to Baltimore to-morrow.
Chaplain STOCKTON, in his opening prayer, returned thanks for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, regarding it as a divine intervention.

Map Showing the Line of the Mississippi from Cairo to Memphis, and the Rebel Forts, Including Fort Pillow, on its Banks; also, the Tennessee River, with Pittsburg, Corinth, and other Points of Interest.
The following reliable information relative to the visit of the French Minister to Norfolk seems to be sufficiently significant to justify particular mention.

Calm weather is prevailing in the Roads. It has been most propitious for the reappearance of the Merrimac, but as she does not come it is concluded that she was most likely injured by getting aground when last out.
Mr. WHEELER, by consent, made a minority report from the Committee to investigate the transactions of the State Military Board.

A few days ago, the TIMES laid before its readers a remarkably thorough and instructive history of the origin of the European coalition against Mexico. It was illustrated with the text of all the more important dispatches which had passed between the British, Spanish and French Governments, and with abstracts of papers of secondary moment. This remarkable chapter of diplomatic history we have now completed. On Tuesday, the

Gen. SCOTT reached his old residence in Elizabeth, N. J., on Wednesday, where, it is stated, he intends to remain for the future. He was met at Elizabeth Port by a large delegation of his old friends and neighbors who received him with the most touching demonstrations of delight, and escorted him to his residence with all the respect due to his exalted character and services.

The rebels have been for several days building large fortifications on the Gloucester side of York River, about two miles from Yorktown, and within sight of our gunboats; but their guns were of too long a range to allow of the approach of the gunboats to shell the works. About 1,000 men were at work on the fortifications, and the mortars were not of sufficient range to check the operations.

The Newbern prisoners who arrived here on Wednesday, in the transport Albany, were transferred to Governor's Island at noon yesterday. The com missioned Officers, viz., Col, AVERY, Captains RAN and MAYAN, and seven Lieutenants, are quartered in the Garrison, and the non-commissioned officers and privates, numbering one hundred and thirty, are confined in Castle William, which is surrounded by a cordon of sentinels.

The NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, No.792, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter, in wrappers, ready for mailing. It contains the LATEST INTELLIGENCE up to the moment of going to press. In addition, will be found, graphic letters from our correspondents at Headquarters, and letters from other divisions of the army.

Hon, Edwin M.Stanton, Secretary of War: During Tuesday and Wednesday, the gunboats amused themselves by shelling the woods below Gloucester. One of them approached within two miles of Yorktown yesterday morning, when the rebels opened from a new battery concealed in the woods. The boat having obtained the position of their guns, returned to her position without receiving any damage.

By the French steamer Le Tage, which left Havana on the 8th inst., we have received news from Mexico via the above-named port, brought from Vera Cruz by the English steamer Avon, which arrived at Havana on the 7th inst.
The following reports have been received at the Navy Department, to-day, detailing the valuable service rendered by our gunboats, at the battle at Pittsburgh Landing:

The bill to amend the act creating the Court of Claims, was received from the House, and referred to the Judiciary Committee.

The Select Committee of the senate, through Mr. HALE, made their report under the resolution adopted in July, last, instructing them to inquire into the circumstances attending the surrender of the Navy-Yard at Pensacola, and the destruction of the property of the United States at Norfolk Navyyard and the Armory at Harper's Ferry, and the abandonment of the same by the National forces, and also, whether there was default on the part of our officers.

The British brig Atlantic, of Nassau, Capt. STUBBS, from Nassau, N.P., on April 11, with merchandise to G. DARRELL Co., arriveed yesterday. She brings the following passengers: N.J. Davenport, D.A. Strong, H. Lampe, J. Chabau, W.S. Danvers, Miss R. Adams, Mrs. M.P. Davenport.

On the 26th of February we published the packing returns from 113 places, the footings up of which indicated pretty clearly that the quantity of pork packed in 1861-'62, was the largest ever cured in any previous season in the United States.

The old Capitol building, which has been used for the past ten months for the safe-keeping of Secessionists, both political and belligerent, has become one of the "institutions" of the Metropolis, Sightseers who come here to get a peep at our "elephants" never fail to include this prison among the things to be wondered at.
Our army probably reached New-Market last night. Officers who have returned hither state that when they left, our advance was five miles beyond Mount Jackson.

Mount Jackson was occupied this morning at 9 o' clock, the rebels showing feeble resistance, and burning the bridges as they retreated. Our advance was made by the turnpike and by a side road, Gen. SHIELDS upon one and Gen. WILLIAMS upon the other.

This morning opened cooler than yesterday a strong breeze blowing from the sea. Gen. BENHAM proposed a visit to Gen. STEVENS at Beaufort, and I was glad to accept an invitation to join his party.

Let us suppose a case of war. One of those English frigates perceives an enemy's iron-cased vessel, given ehaee, and cornes up with her. The latter, smaller, and less heavily armed, but perfectly under command, moderates her speed and resolutely prepares for action.

The constitution, prepared by the recent State Convention, has at length been published. It is to be submitted for adoption or rejection at an election to be held on the Tuesday next after the third Monday in June. The sections relating to banking, to colored persons, and to the Congressional districts, are to be submitted separately.

In the Senate, the Metropolitan Health Bill was considered in Committee of the Whole. It appeared during the debate that the Committee to whom it had been referred had agreed to strike out the "Police Commissioners," and insert the "Mayors of the Cities" in their place, but the bill had been printed without this amendment. After some argument, it was agreed to strike out all relating to the Police Commissioners, 14 to 13.

Lieut. A.B. Ely, Acting Assistant Adjutant-General, Northern District, Department of the South: SIR: I have the honor to report that several batteries established on Tybee Island, to operate against Fort Pulaski, opened fire on the morning of the 10th instant, at 8 o'clock, commencing with the 13-inch mortars.
The United States steamer McClellan, J.W. BOOTH, coming from Port Royal April l4, at 4 P.M., arrived yesterday.

The Selection of Col. BERRET, the ex- ... The selection of Col. BERRET, the ex Mayor of Washington, as one of the Commissioners under the District Emancipation act, has been sharply questioned. The fact of the nominee having been a prisoner in Fort Lafayette is assumed to be evidence of his disloyalty, and the President is accused of choosing a noted sympathizer with the Pro-Slavery ...
The House passed the bill making further appropriations for certain civil expenditures, including half a million of dollars for completing the west wing of the Treasury Department.
The bill to establish a land-office in Colorado was taken up and passed.
The steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning, with the mails, passengers and treasure $617,279 from California.

The correspondent of the Missouri Democrat says:
HALE'S report in relation to the loss of the Norfolk Navy-yard made to-day, is the subject of discussion in private circles, and will be the basis of an interesting debate in Congress hereafter.

The reported receipts of the principal kinds of Produce since our last have been: 36 bbls. Ashes, 2,078 bbls. Flour, 479 bbls. and 2,152 bags Corn Meal, 11,854 bushels Wheat, 8,850 bushels Corn, 9,745 bushels Rye, 23,619 bushels Oats, 5,503 bushels Malt, 4,832 pkgs. Provisions, and 2,070 bbls. Whisky.

Nearly $3,000 more for the wounded were collected here yesterday. Ward Committees to make and report daily collections, were appointed. Over two hundred applications as physicians and nurses were necessarily declined. Another steamer, chartered by our Mayor and Sanitary Committee, freighted with stores and bedding and carrying the Louisville and Frankfort delegations of surgeons and nurses, has left. Frankfort Sends four surgeons and seven nurses.
The Senate, in Committee of the Whole, Mr. YOUNG in the Chair, took up the Metropolitan Health bill.
I left Hilton Head to-day about 12 o' clock M. for this place, accompanying Gens. HUNTER AND BENHAM, and Capt. ROGERS, of the Watash, and the Government steamer McClellan.

Maj.-Gen. HUNTER seems likely to make his Southern Department thoroughly loyal, notwithstanding its inclusion of South Carolina. Wherever he advances the National flag the rebels either succumb or fly before it; and the following General Order, one of the most important of the campaign, and issued at Fort Pulaski the day after the surrender of that important fortress, shows how the number of loyal freemen in the State is likely to be increased:
The most extraordinary scene that met our observation on the return from near Yorktown to Fortress Monroe, was presented as we approached the entrance to Hampton Roads.

As we read in the military intelligence from across the Atlantic, there are immense armies, weeks of marching and countermarching, preparations always on the point of completion, movements always to be made, at last whole days of fighting and slaying; prodigious slaughter, unparalleled bravery, and, when the worst comes to be made out, fifty are found killed or missing on one side, and it is hoped as many on the other.

The bombardment and capture of Fort Pulaski whereof we to-day give a detailed description by our special correspondent is one of those actions which, like the combat of the ironsides in Hampton Roads, have a double significance being at once a valuable success in our scheme of seaboard operations, and adding most important contributions to the science of attack and defence.

In the Senate yesterday, the bill to establish a land office in Colorado Territory was passed. A report was made from the Special Committee appointed in July last to inquire into the matter of Government property at the Pensacola and Norfolk Navy-yards, and the Harper's Ferry Armory. A bill was introduced by Mr. HARRIS, of ...
Charles L. Young et al. vs. Thomas Lanigan. --This was an action to recover $227 32, the value of a promissory note, made by the defendant in October,... 1860.
The mails from Europe by the Canada, which left Liverpool on the 5th inst., calling at Queenstown on the 6th, reached this City last evening.

Since I wrote you, Col. SLOUGH'S column, thirteen hundred strong, have advanced to HOGAN's Ranche, twenty-five miles north of Santa Fe, where they encountered the enemy, whose strength was not known, and immediately engaged them. Major CRITTENDEN, with the First Colorado Volunteers, and two companies United States Infantry, Under Capt. LEW IS, were sent across the river to fall upon their rear.
Correspondents of Western papers give the following items regarding the battle at Pittsburgh:
SIR: The dispatches from the Commanding-General of this Department to the honorable Secretary of War will convey the gratifying intelligence of the fall of Fort Pulaski.

The Union battery on King's Landing, directly opposite to Fort Pulaski, mounts ten 13-inch mortars, two columbiads, and four rifled cannon, throwing either shot or shell. This battery will be by far the most effective in the coming bombardment, which may open now at any time.

As CURTIS has displayed no further stomach for the fray since the battle of Elkhorn,(Pea Ridge,) the indefatigable VAN DORN has pushed forward to the Mississippi with all rapidity.
The most important intelligence this morning is the announcement that a portion of Gen. McDOWELL'S army has occupied Fredericksburgh.
